questions.text: A mother of five, brings her youngest child, an 18-month-old girl, for evaluation. The child appears very thin with minimal fat distribution. There is severe wasting of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs as shown in the below image. The middle-upper arm circumference is less than 11.5cm. The child is alert and irritable. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The alert and irritable child with severe fat wasting in the areas of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs is likely to have marasmus. 

Marasmus is a type of severe protein-energy malnutrition which occurs due to insufficient calorie intake. It is characterized by severe wasting of fat and muscles. The child appears to be very thin,  having a 'skin and bones' appearance with no fat. 

The loss of buccal fat leads to the 'monkey facies' or 'old man face' due to its aged and wrinkled appearance. 'Baggy pants appearance' is due to the presence of loose skin in the buttocks that hangs low. 

Other features that may be present are hypotension, hypothermia, and bradycardia as well as micronutrient deficiencies. 

Diagnosis of severe acute malnutrition is made with the help of anthropometry.

  • Weight for height is below -3 standard deviations for the mean on the World Health Organization (WHO) chart  or,
  • Presence of bipedal edema or,
  • Middle-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is less than 115mm (in the red zone of the tape as shown below). 

 

The children should be assessed for the following: 

  • Severe edema 
  • Low appetite (failed appetite test) 
  • Medical complications 
  • One or more danger sign

If any of the above are present, the child should be treated as a case of complicated severe acute malnutrition and should have inpatient management. Uncomplicated cases can have supervised home management. 

The WHO recommends testing hemoglobin, total blood count, peripheral blood smear, blood glucose, serum albumin, electrolytes, stool microscopy with culture, parasitic evaluation, retroviral testing, and urine microscopy with culture. 

Other options: 

Option A - Kwashiorkor is another type of protein-energy malnutrition that is characterized mainly by pitting edema starting in the legs and feet that spread to the hands and face. They also show skin changes characterized by increased pigmentation and desquamation. They do not show signs of hunger and are difficult to feed. The weight for height may be normal. The following image shows the edema and the skin changes seen in Kwashiorkor.

 

Option C - Chronic pancreatitis can mimic protein-energy malnutrition. It can occur due to cystic fibrosis and obstruction of the pancreatic ducts due to roundworms. This would present with prolonged abdominal pain, weight loss, and steatorrhea. 

Option D - Marasmic kwashiorkor is a mixed form of malnutrition that presents with features of both marasmus and kwashiorkor. There will be edema, and growth stunting with less severe hair and skin changes of kwashiorkor.

questions.text: Water hammer pulse is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Water hammer pulse, also known as Corrigan’s pulse, is characterized by a sharp rise and a rapid fall-off and is seen in aortic regurgitation.

The water hammer pulse is appreciated by raising the arm rapidly and assessing the characteristics of the radial pulse. It is speculated to arise from the rapid ejection of a large left ventricular stroke volume into a low resistance arterial system.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings are seen in patients with chronic arsenic poisoning?

1. Raindrop pigmentation
2. Peripheral neuritis
3. Mees line
4. Luminous vomit
questions.solution:
Among the given options, raindrop pigmentation, peripheral neuritis, and mees line are seen in patients with chronic arsenic poisoning. Luminous vomit is a feature of yellow phosphorous poisoning. 

Arsenic is an odorless, tasteless, metallic poison. Gastrointestinal features of acute arsenic poisoning include nausea and vomiting, colicky abdominal pain, and profuse diarrhea with rice water stools.

In chronic arsenic poisoning, skin symptoms include erythematous lesions, flushing, and can also lead to hyperkeratotic skin and desquamation. Pigmentation is patchy and resembles raindrops on a dusty road. In the distal parts of the body, hyperkeratosis is present.  Mees lines are transverse white striae of the fingernails, called striate leukonychia. Renal manifestations include chronic nephritis and urine contains albumin, casts, etc. 

Arsenic can be detected in the bones for prolonged periods. Hence it can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body. Dimercaprol is the treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is associated with HLA-B5?
questions.solution:
HLA B5 (HLA B51) is associated with Behcet's disease.

Behcet's disease is a relapsing/remitting acute onset panuveitis with retinal vasculitis and often spontaneous resolution, even without treatment is the classical pattern of eye involvement. Retinal vascular disease (vasculitis and occlusion) is the main cause of visual impairment. It is non-granulomatous condition. A transient mobile hypopyon in a relatively white eye is characteristic.

Note: The association between HLA-A29 and birdshot retinochoroidopathy is the most consistent of any medical disorder. Approximately 95% of patients with birdshot retinochoroidopathy are HLA-A29–positive.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at term is admitted to the labor room for normal vaginal delivery. A per vaginal examination was performed and a pulsatile cord-like structure was felt. An immediate ultrasound revealed the baby was still alive. What is the definitive management in this case?

choices.text: Manual elevation of the fetal presenting part

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of cord prolapse and the definitive management in this condition is delivery of the baby by cesarean section.

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is the delivery by cesarean section when the baby is alive and mature as in this clinical scenario. Reconfirming if the baby is alive before the incision is important to prevent unnecessary trauma from surgery.

The contraindications of immediate delivery are fetal death, lethal fetal anomalies, and a pre-viable gestation.

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is the delivery by the caesarian section. Till then, the following first aid measures can be carried out:

  • IV fluids, oxygen by face mask, and continuous fetal monitoring.
  • Stop oxytocin, if ongoing.
  • Manual elevation of the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the whole hand through the vagina.
  • Positioning of the patient in a steep Trendelenburg position, exaggerated Sim’s position, or knee-chest position.
  • Vagos method: Foley catheter is placed and the bladder is filled with 500-750 mL of saline, and then clamped. The patient’s enlarging bladder provides upward pressure on the fetus and alleviates the compression on the cord.
  • Funic reduction: Gentle manual repositioning of the cord into the uterus. It is not preferred nowadays.
  • Tocolysis can be considered if there is a prolonged interval before delivery

questions.text: As an anesthesia resident, you're planning to insert a central venous line for a patient requiring inotropes and parenteral nutrition for a prolonged period. Which of the following veins will you choose so as to have reduced long-term complications?
questions.solution:
Among the given options subclavian is the best vein for long-term cannulation.

The usual complications of prolonged cannulations include line infection, sepsis, air or thrombus embolism, arrhythmias, hematoma, hemothorax, and thrombosis.

As compared to cannulation of other veins, subclavian vein cannulation has a reduced risk of complications due to prolonged cannulations. It is, however, associated with the maximum risk of pneumothorax.

Other options:

Option B- The internal jugular vein on the right side is better than the left side. Left-sided insertion has an increased risk of pleural effusion and chylothorax.

Option C- The external jugular vein is less preferred because it enters at an acute angle into chest veins, hence there are decreased chances of easy access.

Option D- Femoral veins are less preferred for long-term usage because they are associated with frequent line-related sepsis.

questions.text: A patient presented the clinical finding shown in the image. His showed serum cholesterol is 283 mg/dL and his serum LDL is 202 mg/dL. His triglyceride levels are within normal limits. Which of the following is most likely defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with tendon xanthomas and elevated serum LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and elevated serum cholesterol points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia(FH)(type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia). This is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors and Apo B100.

This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and cholesterol are elevated. Such patients are at increased risk of developing atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

Features of FH: 

  • Painful polyarthritis and tendinitis are common.
  • Physical findings seen are corneal arcus and tendon xanthomas over the Achilles tendon and the dorsum of the hands. Xanthomas are tumorous masses produced by foamy cell clusters (lipid-laden macrophages) found in the connective tissue of the skin and in tendons.

Diagnosis is done clinically based on hypercholesterolemia with 

  • LDL >190 mg/dl, 
  • Family history of hypercholesterolemia and/or
  • Premature coronary artery disease.

Treatment includes lifestyle changes, restriction of a fatty diet, and pharmacotherapy with statins.

Recent drugs for the specific treatment of homozygous FH are:

  • Lomitapide, a microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) inhibitor, and
  • Mipomersen, an antisense oligonucleotide against apoB.

 A plain lateral radiograph of both ankles shows bilateral symmetrical swellings (arrows) superior to the calcaneum.

Patients can also have yellowish plaques around the eyes (Xanthelasma) and corneal arcus.

Other options

Option B: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Low HDL levels are seen. There is an increased risk of atherosclerosis.

The image below shows enlarged yellow-orange colored tonsils in Tangier's disease.

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes type I hyperlipoproteinemia due to defects in LPL or apo C-II. Eruptive xanthomas are seen. Chylomicrons and VLDL are elevated. LDL and HDL are low. There is no risk of coronary disease. Instead, patients have an increased risk of acute pancreatitis. This is due to very high triglyceride levels. It can also cause a milky appearance of plasma.

 

Option D: Acid lipase deficiency can lead to Wolman's disease which is a lysosomal storage disease. The pathognomic feature of this condition is adrenal calcification. Patients are generally neonates who present with adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: What is the gauge of the cannula used here?
questions.solution:
The given cannula is an 18G IV cannula as its color code is green. Its flow rate is 103 mL/min

Other Options :

Option A: The blue IV cannula is 22G with a flow rate of 42 mL/min.

Option B: The orange IV cannula is 14G with a flow rate of 270 mL/min.

Option D: The pink IV cannula is 20G with a flow rate of 67 mL/min.

A standard wire gauge (SWG) is used to size cannulas. It is a measure of the cross-sectional area. Larger cannulae have a smaller gauge number.

Tip:

A simple mnemonic to remember these in descending order of their flow rates is nature. The mantle zone of the earth is orange, the land is grey, the grass is green, the butterfly on the grass is pink, the sky is blue, and the sun is yellow.

questions.text: While examining a patient with right upper quadrant pain, you note the abdomen is soft with localized tenderness. CT abdomen findings are given below. Based on these findings, you post the patient for a PAIR procedure. Which of the following is not used in this procedure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and CT findings are suggestive of hydatid disease of the liver. Hypotonic saline is not used as a scolicidal agent for the PAIR procedure (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, and Re-aspiration) which is the treatment of choice in the early stages of this condition.

Computed tomography (CT) scan is the best imaging modality for hydatid cyst. It shows the presence of a space-occupying lesion with a smooth outline with septa.

In PAIR the steps involved are:

  • USG or CT guided puncture of the cyst
  • Aspiration of the cyst fluid
  • Injection of scolicidal agent
  • Re-aspiration of fluid after 5 minutes

The following agents can be used as scolicidal agents:

questions.text: A 48-year-old man has come for a routine medical check-up. His chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows popcorn calcification (A well-defined round opacity seen at the left upper lung zone) which is suggestive of pulmonary hamartoma.

Pulmonary Hamartoma is the most common benign tumor of the lung and it is manifested by the overgrowth of connective tissue. Pulmonary hamartoma is typically seen in 40-60 years old and is more commonly found in males. 

It is usually discovered as an incidental, rounded coin-like radio-opacity on a routine chest film. Typically solitary, <4 cm, composed of disordered but mature hyaline cartilage, fibrous tissue, smooth muscle, and fat, sometimes with calcification/ossification.  It is usually present peripherally and has slow growth in the lung.

The presence of fat in a well-circumscribed solitary pulmonary nodule which does not demonstrate significant growth is pathognomonic of a pulmonary hamartoma.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male was brought to the ER after sustaining an astride injury. Following the trauma, he experienced an urge to urinate but was unable to pass urine. On examination, blood was present at the urethral meatus. What is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of an astride injury, blood at the tip of the meatus, and inability to pass urine are all suggestive of an injury to the bulbar urethra.

Astride injury refers to trauma that occurs when a person falls with their perineum straddling a hard object, leading to blunt perineal trauma.

Urethral injuries can be classified into:

 Type Proximal urethral injury Distal urethral injury
Site of injury
  • Prostatic urethra
  • Membranous urethra
  • Bulbar urethra
  • Penile urethra
Mechanism Secondary to pelvic fracture

Occurs due to a blow to the perineum by:

  • Straddle injury
  • Gymnasium accidents
Clinical features
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • High-riding prostate on digital rectal examination (Vermooten sign)
  • Deep perineal hematoma
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • Perineal hematoma (Butterfly hematoma)


Note: Urinary bladder rupture occurs due to an injury to the suprapubic region. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is more common and associated with pelvic fracture. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by a blow or a fall on the distended bladder. It manifests as sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium and syncope.

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with complaints of passing loose bulky stools that were associated with abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks. The stool examination shows the following organism. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and an image showing a pear-shaped / pyriform-shaped trophozoite is suggestive of giardiasis caused by Giardia lamblia.

Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is a common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans.

Infection occurs by the ingestion of mature cysts in contaminated water and food. and may also be transmitted by the faecal-oral route.

It is weakly pathogenic in humans. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemia, or malnourished individuals.

Clinical features:

  • Diarrhoea 
  • Fat malabsorption
  • Dull epigastric pain
  • Belching and flatulence
  • Iron deficiency and growth stunting.
  • The stool will have excess mucus and fat but no blood.

Detection of antigens by ELISA is more sensitive and specific than microscopy. Entero test /string test is also used in the diagnosis.

Histopathology of the duodenum reveals several heart-shaped or pear-shaped trophozoites. The trophozoite is heart-shaped or pyriform-shaped with 2 equally sized nuclei and 4 pairs of flagella. It exhibits slow oscillating motility that resembles falling leaf motility. 

Other options:

Isospora belli is a coccidian parasite that can cause protracted diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. The oocyst is not easily seen on stool-wet mounts. It may be visible after stool concentration and staining with acid-fast stain, as shown below.

Cryptosporidium parvum, commonly causes diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals. The oocysts in the stool can be visualized by modified Ziehl-Neelsen staining. It appears as red acid-fast spheres. It can also be used for specimens such as sputum and bronchial wash. The image given below demonstrates uniformly acid-fast oocysts of Cryptosporidium parvum.

Trichomonas vaginalis is found in the genital tract. The image given below shows the trophozoite of Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.text: A patient presents with the following skin lesion. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a skin lesion that is red, edematous, and well-demarcated from the surrounding skin. These features are suggestive of erysipelas. 

Erysipelas is a skin infection involving superficial lymphatics. It is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (β-Hemolytic Group A Streptococci). It presents with raised, erythematous sharply demarcated rapidly spreading skin lesions, along with systemic symptoms. Legs and face are the most common sites affected.

Other options:

Option B: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) is caused by the exfoliative toxin and presents with peeling of the affected skin. Separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis, by a shearing force, indicating a plane of cleavage is called the Nikolsky sign. Thus, Nikolsky's sign is positive in SSSS.

Option C: Gas gangrene is a form of myonecrosis. It is a bacterial infection in which tissue gas is produced in gangrene. It is usually caused by Clostridium perfringens. The given image of gas gangrene shows necrotic bullae, erythema, and edema.

Option D: Erysipeloid is caused by Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae (Different from erysipelas). The most common site of involvement in erysipeloid is the fingers, leading to a condition known as “ seal finger” or “whale finger.”

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not likely to cause an abnormal sign pertaining to the clinical finding being tested in the image below?
questions.solution:
By asking the patient to keep the dorsal surfaces of his fingers opposed (Schamroth sign), the finding being elicited is clubbing. Clubbing is seen in conditions like lung abscess, cystic fibrosis, and aortic aneurysm, but not in irritable bowel syndrome.

Digital clubbing is a focal bulbous enlargement of the terminal segments of the fingers and/or toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue between the nail matrix and the distal phalanx. Clubbed fingers are also known as watch-glass nails, drumstick fingers, and Hippocratic fingers/nails.

Hypoxia causes increased release of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). This leads to increased vascularity, permeability, and connective tissue changes.

The image below shows clubbing.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing are:

  • Schamroth sign: It is performed by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, but this window is obliterated in clubbed fingers. 
  • Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: It is the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, this angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.
  • Hyponychial angle: This is constructed by drawing a line from the distal digital crease to the cuticle and another line from the cuticle to the hyponychium (the thickened stratum corneum of the epidermis under the free edge of the nail). The normal angle is less than 192°.
  • Phalangeal depth ratio: This is defined by the ratio of the digit's depth measured at the nail bed and distal interphalangeal joint. Normally, the depth at the distal interphalangeal joint is more than that at the nail bed. A phalangeal depth ratio of more than 1 is indicative of clubbing.
  • Digital index: This is the sum of the phalangeal depth ratios for all 10 fingers. A digital index of 10.2 or more is indicative of clubbing. This is more specific for clubbing than pharyngeal depth ratio.

The causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Diffuse pulmonary disease - pulmonary fibrosis, asbestosis
  • GI
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • CNS
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)

questions.text: Which of the following drugs if taken during pregnancy can lead to this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
The baby has features suggestive of phocomelia and it results due to the consumption of thalidomide during pregnancy.

Phocomelia is associated with underdeveloped limbs and absent pelvic bones. Both upper and lower limbs are affected and a part of the limbs may be missing. Fused fingers and missing thumbs are also seen.

Thalidomide was originally used for the treatment of pregnancy-associated morning sickness but was withdrawn due to this adverse effect.

It re-entered the market for the treatment of erythema nodosum leprosum. It also has antiangiogenic and immunomodulatory effects.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with frequent episodes of nose-bleeds. She also complains of frequent episodes of headache and fever. The following test is positive in this patient. Which of the given findings is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Cottle’s test which is positive in patients with deviated nasal septum. Septal perforation is not associated with DNS. Septal perforation usually occurs as a consequence of septal abscess.

Cottle's test: The cheek of the patient is drawn laterally during quiet breathing. If this improves the airway on the test side, the test is considered to be positive. This suggests an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve causing nasal obstruction.

DNS is associated with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal obstruction: Deviated nasal septum may lead to obstruction of the nasal cavity at different levels based on the type of deviation.
  • Chronic sinusitis: Deviated septum causes obstruction to the ostia of the sinuses. This causes poor ventilation of the sinuses leading to sinusitis.
  • Middle ear infection
  • Epistaxis: There is drying of the mucosa over the deviated septum due to air currents. This leads to the formation of crusts which, on removal, cause epistaxis.
  • Anosmia: reduced airflow may lead to anosmia
  • External deformity: External deformities of the septum may be seen due to deviation of the cartilaginous or the bony part of the nasal septum. Deformity of the tip or columella may also be seen.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and pain in the right iliac fossa. He had a history of nausea and vomiting 3 days back and was not taken to the hospital. The surgeon suggested percutaneous drainage as the CT of the right iliac fossa showed a well-circumscribed fluid collection.  What is the most likely diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
The history of right iliac fossa pain with fever, nausea, and vomiting is suggestive of acute appendicitis, which in this case has progressed to an appendicular abscess as suggested by the radiological findings.

An appendicular abscess is a very common complication of an untreated or perforated appendix. It can occur retroperitoneally or intraperitoneally.

Investigations include USG or CT of the abdomen which shows a well-circumscribed, rounded, or ill-defined, irregular fluid collection in the appendicular region. 

With the recent advances, early laparoscopic drainage or radiologically assisted percutaneous drainage followed by delayed appendicectomy is also done. If these are unsuccessful or there is leakage into the peritoneal cavity a midline laparotomy can be done. 

Note:

The popular management of an appendicular mass is the Oschner-Sherren regime which is conservative management as the inflammatory process has already been localized and surgery is complicated now. 

If it progresses to an abscess, it must be drained radiologically or laparoscopically along with intravenous antibiotics.

The indications for stopping the conservative management include:

  • Rising pulse rate
  • Increasing or spreading abdominal pain 
  • The increasing size of the mass.

A follow-up CT is taken in case of conservative management to ensure that there is a complete resolution of the inflammatory process.

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT a feature of re-feeding syndrome?
questions.solution:
Refeeding syndrome is associated with hypophosphataemia, hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia.

Refeeding syndrome is a potentially lethal condition that can occur with rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition due to starvation, alcoholism, delayed nutritional support, anorexia nervosa, or massive weight loss in obese patients.

  • It can occur with either enteral or parenteral nutrition, but is more common with the latter.
  • Symptoms: Electrolyte abnormalities can result in cardiac failure and dysrrhythmias, respiratory failure, neu­rologic disturbances, and renal and hepatic dysfunction.

Prevention and treatment:

  • Correct underlying electrolyte and volume deficits.
  • Additionally, thiamine should be administered before the initiation of feeding. Caloric replenition should be instituted slowly and should gradually increase over the first week.
  • Vital signs, fluid balance, and electrolytes should be closely monitored and any deficits corrected as they evolve.

questions.text: A salesman met with an unfortunate accident that led to him eventually losing his left foot. Which of the following is the salesman suffering from?
questions.solution:
This salesman had lost a foot, which indicates that he has an impairment. 

The WHO definition of impairment is "any loss or abnormality of psychological, physiological or anatomical structure or function". E.g., loss of a foot. An initial impairment may cause a secondary impairment as well.

Some examples of the other types of disability events are given below:

Event Example
Disease/Disorder Accident
Impairment Loss of foot
Disability Cannot Walk
Handicap Unemployed

 

The WHO defines disability as ''any restriction or lack of ability to perform an activity in the manner or within the range considered normal for a human being". Because of this, the affected person may be unable to carry out certain activities and hence the person is considered disabled.

According to the WHO, a handicap is "a disadvantage for a given individual, resulting from an impairment or a disability, that limits or prevents the fulfilment of a role that is normal (depending on age, sex, and social and cultural factors) for that individual". The disadvantages experienced by a person as a result of disability makes them handicapped.

questions.text:
In a village with 200 eligible couples, the data on contraceptive methods used by the couples are given below. What is the couple protection rate in the village?

Vasectomy – 30
Tubectomy – 30
IUD users – 12
Oral pill users – 30
Condom users – 18
questions.solution:
Couple protection rate (CPR) is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.

In this scenario, a total of 120 couples out of 200 eligible couples are using contraceptive methods.

Therefore, CPR = (120/200) x 100 = 60% 

Eligible couple: It refers to a currently married couple, wherein the wife is at the reproductive age, which is generally assumed to lie between the ages 15 and 45 years.

questions.text: A patient presents with pruritic hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest as seen in the image. On KOH mount, spaghetti and meatballs appearance is noted. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The characteristic appearance of ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ or ‘bananas and grapes' on KOH mount and microscopy (shown below) is suggestive of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor. 

Pityriasis Versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales (branny/furfuraceous).

Tinea versicolor is usually caused by the lipophilic fungi Malassezia globosa and possibly Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur.

Mechanism of hypopigmentation in P. Versicolor: Azelaic acid produced by Malassezia species.

Pale yellow fluorescence in Wood’s lamp examination is another characteristic finding of tinea versicolor. Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail): When the fine scales are not visible, an important diagnostic clue may be the loosening of barely perceptible scale with a fingernail, which is called as the scratch sign.

Patients are treated with Topical azoles.

Option A: Tinea cruris, also known as jock itch, is a dermatophyte infection affecting the inguinal folds, which may extend to the vulva and perianal area. 

Option B:  Tinea capitis, also known as scalp ringworm, is a fungal infection affecting the scalp. 

Option C: Tinea corporis, is a fungal infection, which can occur anywhere in the body, with the classical ring shaped/annular rash. 

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's Lamp Examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp. Black light is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A case-control study was done among 500 lung cancer patients and 400 controls. In the study groups, 400 and 50 smokers were identified respectively. Calculate the odds ratio for this study:
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the odds ratio (OR) is 28, hence smoking acts as a risk factor for lung cancer.

Disease  -

= (400 x 350) / (50 x 100)

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.

  • If the frequency of exposure is higher among cases, the OR will exceed 1, which indicates increased risk.
  • If the frequency is lower, then it will be <1, which can indicate possible protection.
  • If the OR is 1, then there is no association of risk with exposure or that the event is equally likely in both groups.

  • In a case control study, progression is from effect to cause as outcome or disease has already occurred.

questions.text: The image below shows the dissection of the right side of the neck and the red arrow denotes the right subclavian artery. What is not true about the structure labeled as A?

choices.text: Arises mainly from C4 spinal nerve
The right side nerve is shorter than the left
It is formed at the lateral border of scalenus anterior
It is purely a motor nerve

questions.solution:
The structure labeled as A is the phrenic nerve and all of the following are true about the phrenic nerve except for option D as it is a mixed nerve (both sensory and motor nerve).

Each phrenic nerve provides the sole motor supply to its hemidiaphragm. In its thoracic course, each phrenic nerve supplies sensory branches to the mediastinal pleura, fibrous pericardium, and parietal serous pericardium.

 

The phrenic nerve is a mixed nerve derived mostly from the C4 ramus and also receives contributions from the C3 and C5 ventral rami.

It is formed at the lateral border of the scalenus anterior. At the root of the neck, the right phrenic nerve runs anterior to the second part of the right subclavian artery from which it is separated by the scalenus anterior muscle. The phrenic nerve lies posterior to the right subclavian vein.

The right phrenic nerve is shorter and more vertical than the left. The right phrenic nerve passes through the vena caval opening. The left phrenic nerve passes through the muscular part of the diaphragm just anterior to the central tendon.

*Clinical note - The phrenic nerve is responsible for the referred pain which usually occurs when there is inflammation of the diaphragmatic pleura, e.g. in basal pneumonia, pleural effusions, or with irritation of the peritoneal pleura, as with a subphrenic abscess. It is frequently felt at the tip of the shoulder due to the common root of origin of the phrenic nerve and the nerves supplying the shoulder.

questions.text: A 29-year-old presented with purple, pruritic plaques on the flexor aspect of the left forearm for 7 months. On examination, Koebner's phenomenon was elicited. A skin biopsy showed Civatte bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with symptoms of purple, itchy, plaque exhibiting Koebner's phenomenon is suggestive of lichen planus. It is characterized by the presence of Civatte bodies or colloid bodies.

The colloid body is a homogeneous, eosinophilic, rounded body resulting from the degeneration and death of keratinocytes, particularly in the lower layers of the epidermis. This structure is found in various lichenoid tissue reactions.

Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membrane. Microscopy will show :

  • Acanthosis of the epidermis.
  • Irregular thickening of the granular layer.
  • Hyperkeratosis.
  • Colloid (civatte) bodies due to degenerating basal epidermal cells. 
  • Sawtooth appearance of rete ridges.
  • Max Joseph spaces due to focal separation from the dermis.
  • Band‐like infiltrate of lymphocytes and histiocytes near the dermo-epidermal junction.

Patients present with pruritic, purple, polygonal, papules. The lesions have thin white lines on their surface known as Wickham’s striae (seen below). They are commonly seen on the volar aspect of the wrists, the lumbar region, and around the ankles.

The mucosal involvement is also seen. The commonest mucosal sites are buccal mucosa and tongue, rarely it can also be found on the anus and genitalia. 

Option A: Copper penny bodies are seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Option C: Donovan bodies are seen in granuloma inguinale.

Option D: Kamino bodies are eosinophilic globules seen in the epidermis or in the region of the dermal-epidermal junction in the spindle and epithelioid cell (Spitz) naevi.

questions.text: A primigravida patient at 26 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with acute appendicitis. what is the best step of management for this patient?

choices.text: Laparoscopic appendicectomy before 28 weeks of gestation
Conservative management till term and operate after delivery
Laparoscopic appendicectomy after 28 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
The best step of management for this patient with acute appendicitis is laparoscopic appendicectomy before 28 weeks of gestation. In cases of appendicitis in pregnancy, once the diagnosis is suspected, it is essential to operate at the earliest, than to wait, as there is a risk of developing generalized peritonitis.

Acute appendicitis is the most common surgical non-gynecological cause of acute abdomen in pregnancy.

The diagnosis of acute appendicitis in pregnancy is difficult due to the following factors:

  • Nausea and vomiting may be considered normal, especially in the first trimester of pregnancy
  • Leukocytosis is a physiological finding in pregnancy
  • A gravid enlarging uterus can push the appendix upward and outward, causing the pain to localize in the right flank or right upper quadrant.

Acute appendicitis in pregnancy is associated with miscarriage, preterm delivery, increased risk of peritonitis, perinatal and maternal mortality.

USG abdomen is used to confirm. USG abdomen would reveal a >6mm diameter, aperistaltic, non-compressible, dilated appendix seen as a blind-ending structure arising from the base of the caecum. MRI abdomen can be done if USG is inconclusive. Operative laparotomy with minimal uterine manipulation should be done at the earliest. Laparoscopic appendicectomy can be done before 28 weeks of gestation. Intraoperative fetal monitoring should be considered.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the phases of the ventricular muscle action potential as shown below. Which phase represents the closing of fast sodium channels?
questions.solution:
Phase 1 represents the closure of fast sodium channels.

Phases of cardiac muscle action potential.

  • Phase 0 (Depolarization): Opening of fast sodium channels. When the cardiac cell is stimulated, the fast sodium channels(voltage-gated sodium channels) open and causes sodium influx. This depolarizes the cell and the membrane potential becomes positive. It reached about +20 mV and the sodium channels close. 
  • Phase 1 (Initial repolarization): Closing of fast sodium channels. The fast sodium channel close and the potassium channels open. the potassium ions leave the cell leading to repolarisation. 
  • Phase 2 (Plateau): Fast potassium channels close and calcium channels open. The slowly opening voltage-gated Ca2+ channels start opening. The influx of calcium through these channels is balanced by the decrease in potassium efflux via the potassium channels. This produces the plateau. 
  • Phase 3 (Rapid repolarization): Slow potassium channels open and calcium channels close. The potassium ions leave the cell through slow potassium channels and the calcium channels close stopping the influx of calcium ions. This ends the plateau and brings the membrane potential to resting level. 
  • Phase 4 (Resting membrane potential):  around −80 to −90 millivolts.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents at 33 weeks gestation with intermittent uterine contractions. On per vaginal examination, the cervix is 80% effaced and 2.5cm dilated. To allow fetal lung maturity, what is the dose of betamethasone to be given?
questions.solution:
To allow fetal lung maturity, the dose of betamethasone to be given is 12mg IM 24 hourly 2 doses.

Antenatal corticosteroids are recommended in a pregnancy less than 34 weeks to allow fetal lung maturation and to reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), and necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). 

  • Betamethasone is the steroid of choice and it becomes useful if the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours of the first dose with the effect lasting for about 18 days. 
  • Dexamethasone is another steroid that can be given in a dose of 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses IM.  

Preterm labor is the onset of labor before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days of gestation). It can occur in patients with a history of prior preterm birth, multiple pregnancies, and genital tract infection. Evaluation of cervical anatomy is the most important step in women with a history of preterm labor to look for cervical incompetence. 

It is diagnosed by:

  • Uterus - regular contractions at least one in every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes or 8 contractions in 60 min with/without pain. 
  • Cervix - dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80% 
  • TVS - length of cervix <2.5 cm and funneling of the internal os >1 cm
  • Pelvic pressure, backache, vaginal discharge, or bleeding PV

The best predictors of preterm labor in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetal fibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on transvaginal ultrasound.

Management includes short-term therapy with tocolytics, given in conjunction with steroids for 1-3 days to delay labor for at least 48 hours or to transfer the patient to a tertiary center (centers with NICU). The tocolytics include terbutaline, indomethacin, nifedipine, and atosiban. Contraindications to tocolysis include chorioamnionitis, preeclampsia/eclampsia, fetal distress, pregnancy >34 weeks, active labor, and placental abruption.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids. A barium swallow revealed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the barium swallow showing a bird beak appearance is suggestive of achalasia cardia. 

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) in response to swallowing. 

The patients present with dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. The dysphagia initially begins with liquid foods and then progresses to solid foods. As the food gets accumulated in the esophagus, patients may complain of halitosis. With further progression of the disease, the patients may develop pneumonia, lung abscess, etc.

The initial diagnosis is made by barium swallow or endoscopy, which shows the presence of dilated esophagus due to the constriction of the lower esophageal sphincter (bird-beak appearance). The gold standard test to confirm achalasia cardia is esophageal manometry.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A 45 year old female presented with abnormal uterine bleeding. The images below shows transverse section of uterus and histology of the specimen. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen shows thickened myometrium with spongy, trabeculated surface, with focal areas of haemorrhage. The histopathology specimen shows endometrial glands and the surrounding stroma within the uterine myometrium. These findings are suggestive of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis is a condition caused by the ingrowth of the endometrial tissue into the uterine wall. The presence of endometrial glands and stroma with the uterine myometrium eventually leads to the thickening of the uterine wall.

Women present with menorrhagia, progressively increasing dysmenorrhea, pelvic discomfort, backache and dyspareunia. Clinical examination revealinf a painful, symmetrical enlargementy of the uterus should suggest adenomyosis. On bimanual examination, the uterus is softened and tender. This is known as Halban's sign. 

TVS findings include the salt-and-pepper appearance of the myometrium and the presence of sub-endometrial striations producing the Venetian blind appearance (shown in the image below). 

MRI can also be done for diagnosis. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination.

Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger women.

questions.text: The pressure-volume curve is shifted to the left in:
questions.solution:
The pressure-volume curve is shifted to the left in mitral stenosis.

The PV loop is shifted to the right when there is volume overload (increased end-diastolic volume).
The PV loop is shifted to the left in case of increased contractility or decreased compliance (decreased end-diastolic volume).

Effect of valvular diseases on PV loop:

  • Mitral stenosis: Left and down.
  • Mitral regurgitation: Width increased and height decreased.
  • Aortic stenosis: Tall with steep slope.
  • Aortic regurgitation: Right and tall.

questions.text: A boy was brought with complaints of pain over the right flank associated with fever and chills with leukocytosis. A CT scan showed the following finding.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with flank pain, fever, leucocytosis, and a CT scan showing a mass in the psoas muscle lateral to the vertebral column is diagnostic of a psoas abscess.

Psoas abscess occurs due to a collection of pus due to an infection in the iliopsoas compartment. The compartment is retroperitoneal and hence, the abscess is a retroperitoneal abscess. The compartment contains the iliacus and iliopsoas muscles. 

Psoas abscess is either primary or secondary. Tuberculosis of the spine leading to Pott's abscess was the leading cause of psoas abscess. But, recently, the hematogenous spread of infection from an occult primary site (gastrointestinal or urinary tract) has become common, especially in immunocompromised patients and the elderly. It can also occur due to contiguous extension of infection from neighboring structures.

Clinical features include:

  • Back pain and fever.
  • Soft, fluctuant swelling pointing towards the groin (hip).
  • Pain on passive hip extension or active flexion of the psoas - Positive psoas sign.

Lab investigation - Leucocytosis, increases ESR and mild anemia may be seen.

Diagnosis - Commonly confirmed using a CT scan. Blood culture and abscess material should be obtained in all cases to guide therapy.

Percutaneous CT-guided drainage and antibiotic therapy are useful in the treatment of the condition. 

Radiological images showing psoas abscess (mass lateral to the vertebral column).

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the immunization programme?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a ten-year-old schoolchild will be administered the TT/Td vaccine according to the National Immunization Schedule.

The Tetanus and adult diphtheria (Td) vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen (d) as recommended for older children and adults. The MoHFW recommends the replacement of TT vaccine with Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5ml is administered in the intramuscular route in the upper arm.

Scheduled to be administered at 10 and 16 years of age.

For pregnant women :

  • Td-1: early in pregnancy
  • Td-2: 4 weeks after Td-1
  • Td (Booster): if pregnancy occurs within 3 years of last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.

Other options:

Option A - According to the National Immunization Schedule, BCG should be given at birth or as early as possible up to 1 year of age. It provides protection against CNS and disseminated TB. A dose of 0.1 ml is administered intradermally in the left upper arm.

Option B - Measles/MR is given at 9 completed months (1st dose) and a second dose is given at 16-24 months. Measles can be given till 5 years of age. A dose of 0.5ml is administered subcutaneously in the right upper arm.

Option D - DPT vaccine is administered as a part of the pentavalent vaccine at the 6th, 10th and 14th weeks of life. DPT booster doses are administered at 16-24 months (first booster) and 5-6 years (second booster). It can be administered until 7 years of age (with booster doses). A dose of 0.5ml is administered in the anterolateral aspect of the mid-thigh. The 2nd booster dose can be administered in the upper arm.

questions.text: The position of the patient in the image shown below is known as:
questions.solution:
The above image shows a reverse Trendelenburg position, where the patient's head is elevated 15 - 30 degrees higher than the feet. It is named so, as the position is reverse of the Trendelenburg position, where the head end is lower and the feet are at a higher level.

The Trendelenburg and reverse Trendelenburg positions are used in surgeries that are required to move the abdominal viscera, such as the small bowel, away from the operative field. Restraints and sideboards are placed to prevent the patient from sliding from the bed.

In laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the patient is placed in a reverse Trendelenburg position slightly rotated to the left. This exposes the fundus of the gallbladder which is retracted towards the diaphragm.

questions.text: Which of the following would not be seen in Samter's triad?
questions.solution:
Epistaxis is not a feature of Samter's triad.

Samter's triad is also known as aspirin-induced asthma or aspirin-sensitive asthma. It consists of:

  • Nasal polyposis
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance

Patients with Samter's triad will have persistent nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, anosmia, nasal polyps, and recurrent chronic rhinosinusitis. Asthma and aspirin intolerance develop later.

Acute asthma attacks usually occur 3 hours after intake of aspirin or NSAIDs. Severe rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection, facial flushing, and periorbital edema are also seen. Aspirin-induced hypersensitivity reactions also may occur. 

Patients should avoid aspirin and NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1. Treatment may involve aspirin desensitization and endoscopic sinus surgery.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 18-month-old son to the outpatient department with complaints of repeated urinary tract infections. During diagnostic work-up, pelvic USG shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the USG showing the key-hole sign is suggestive of the posterior urethral valve (PUV). It is seen due to dilatation of the bladder and the proximal urethra.

The posterior urethral valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit, which lies just distal to the verumontanum. They function as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow.

The posterior urethral valve is the most common congenital cause of bladder outlet obstruction in males. PUV is classified into three types based on Young's classification.

Diagnosis is made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder. If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then neonates typically present with recurrent urinary infections or uremia and renal failure. 

The investigation of choice for a posterior urethral valve is micturating cystourethrography (MCUG).

Initially, the obstruction is relieved by catheterization to preserve renal function. Definitive treatment is by urethroscopic destruction of the valves with lifelong supportive treatment.

questions.text: A patient on anti-tubercular treatment presents with a tingling sensation and paresthesia in the lower limbs. Her peripheral blood smear examination shows microcytic anemia. Which of the following enzyme assay is used to diagnose the deficient vitamin in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of tingling sensation, paresthesias , and microcytic anemia in a patient on anti-tubercular treatment are suggestive of the adverse effect of isoniazid. The vitamin deficient in this patient is pyridoxine/vitamin B6. Therefore, the RBC transaminase enzyme assay is used to diagnose vitamin B6 deficiency. 

Isoniazid is the first-line antitubercular drug that inhibits the production of mycolic acid. It is a bactericidal drug against tubercle bacilli.

Peripheral neuritis occurs due to interference with the production of active coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate from pyridoxine. Patients present with clinical features of pyridoxine/vitamin B6 deficiency, which include paresthesias, numbness, and tingling sensation. other features include seborrhea, glossitis, convulsions, neuropathy, depression, confusion, and microcytic anemia.

The most widely used method to know the vitamin B6 nutritional status is by measuring the RBC transaminase activity.

Therefore, pyridoxine 10 mg/day (vitamin B6) is given prophylactically along with isoniazid to prevent neurotoxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension?
questions.solution:
Liddle's syndrome is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension.

It is an autosomal dominant condition due to a gain of function mutation in the ENaC gene. This gene codes for the epithelial sodium channels present in the kidney. This leads to increased sodium retention and results in a state of pseudo-hyperaldosteronism. The following findings are seen:

  • Hypertension
  • Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis
  • Normal-low aldosterone
  • Low renin 

Treatment is with diuretics that directly block the ENaC channels, like amiloride and triamterene. Spironolactone is not effective as it is an aldosterone-receptor antagonist.

Other options:

Option A- Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to defects in various genes involved in the regulated Na+, K+, and Cl– transport by the thick ascending loop of Henle (TALH). There is extracellular fluid volume depletion with low or normal blood pressure. It is characterized by metabolic alkalosis, decreased potassium and chloride, and, occasionally, hypomagnesemia. 

Option C- Gitelman syndrome is due to a loss of function mutation in the thiazide-sensitive Na+-Cl– cotransporter of the distal convoluted tubule. It is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypomagnesemia and hypocalciuria with low blood pressure.

Option D- Gordon syndrome is a state of pseudohypoaldosteronism. It is characterized by hypertension, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and low-normal plasma renin activity and aldosterone concentrations.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: A 60 year old man was referred for severe anemia and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear showed teardrop cells, nucleated RBCs, and giant abnormal platelets. Bone marrow aspirate reveals a dry tap despite multiple attempts. The bone marrow biopsy findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings with a history of a dry tap and the image showing the deposition of numerous collagen fibers in the bone marrow indicate marrow fibrosis. Hence the likely diagnosis here is primary myelofibrosis.

Primary myelofibrosis (myelofibrosis with myeloid metaplasia/ agnogenic myeloid metaplasia) is a myeloproliferative disorder characterized by fibrosis of the bone marrow. It commonly occurs in individuals over 60 years of age. JAK2, CALR, and MPL mutations are seen in the majority of the cases. 

The chief pathologic feature is the extensive deposition of collagen in the marrow by fibroblasts. The fibrosis of bone marrow is thought to be caused by the inappropriate release of platelet-derived growth factor and TGF-β.

clinical features include:

  • Early phase:
    • Thrombocytosis with large, abnormal platelets and leukocytosis (WBC count elevated up to 100,000 cells/mm3)
    • Hypercellularity of bone marrow with an increase in the maturation of cells of all lineages
  • Late phase: As the disease progresses, there is increased collagen deposition and the bone marrow becomes hypocellular and diffusely fibrotic leading to,
    • Pancytopenia 
    • Fibrosis of bone marrow leading to dry tap on bone marrow aspirate.
    • Teardrop-shaped RBCs a.k.a dacryocytes, and leukoerythroblastosis (premature release of nucleated RBC and immature granulocytes into the blood)
    • Hepatosplenomegaly - due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.
    • Subcapsular infarcts are common and there may be moderate enlargement of the liver.

questions.text:
Match the following disorders causing secondary amenorrhoea with their respective lab findings.
Condition Lab markers 
1. Sheehan's syndrome A. Normal FSH, Normal LH, Normal estradiol
2. Premature Ovarian failure B. High LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
3. PCOS C. Low LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
4. Asherman's syndrome D. High LH, High FSH, Low estradiol
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A.

Condition Lab markers 
1. Sheehan's syndrome C. Low LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
2. Premature Ovarian failure D. High LH, High FSH, Low estradiol
3. PCOS B. High LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
4. Asherman's syndrome A. Normal FSH, Normal LH, Normal estradiol

Secondary amenorrhoea is the absence of menses for more than three months in girls or women who previously had regular menstrual cycles or six months in girls or women who had irregular menses.

Premature Ovarian failure or premature menopause is the development of menopause before the age of 40 years. It is diagnosed when at least 2 serum FSH levels are elevated (>40 mIU/l) when measured at least 1 month apart in a woman <40 years. The other findings consistent with POF include low estradiol and an elevated FSH/LH ratio.

Asherman's syndrome is the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of large areas of the endometrium, most commonly as a result of trauma to the endometrium following pregnancy-related curettages. Oligomenorrhoea, amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, abortion, and infertility are seen with uterine synechiae. The laboratory investigations and hormonal assays are generally normal in isolated cases of uterine synechiae. Diagnosis is generally established using hysteroscopy. Moth-eaten appearance on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome. Treatment is by hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.

PCOS is a multisystem, metabolic, endocrine dysfunction that commonly occurs among women in the reproductive age group. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls. Estrone(E1) levels are elevated but estradiol level in PCOS is low in comparison to Estrone (E1). 

Sheehan's syndrome/ pituitary apoplexy is hemorrhagic infarction of large pituitary adenomas or pituitary infarction due to traumatic major blood loss. If this blood loss occurs during delivery, it's called Sheehan's syndrome. Affected women may present with panhypopituitarism and may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, and lactation failure. The most prominent symptoms are lactation failure (due to the deficiency of prolactin) and postpartum amenorrhea (due to the deficiency of gonadotropins).

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: A female patient presents with numbness in her fingertips. On examination, her face appears tightened. The antinuclear antibody(ANA) is found to be positive and immunofluorescence demonstrates a nucleolar pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Numbness of fingers (associated with Raynaud's phenomenon), facial tightening, and positive anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) with nucleolar pattern in immunofluorescence are highly suggestive of systemic sclerosis.

Systemic sclerosis/ scleroderma:

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune connective tissue disorder that results in fibrosis of the skin, vasculature, and internal organs. It is of two types, namely diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis and limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. 

Scleroderma is characterized by Raynaud's phenomenon, digital ischemia, sclerodactyly, calcinosis, telangiectasia, and cardiac, lung, gastrointestinal and renal disease. Skin thickening is the hallmark of SSc. Patients have a characteristic expressionless facial appearance with taut and shiny skin and microstomia.

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are positive in SSC. The presence of anti-topoisomerase 1 (Scl70) and anticentromere antibodies are seen in diffuse cutaneous SSC and limited cutaneous SSc respectively.

The nucleolar pattern of ANA staining in immunofluorescence is most commonly seen in systemic sclerosis. A centromeric pattern is also seen.

The image below shows the nucleolar pattern in immunofluorescence seen in systemic sclerosis.

Other options:

Option B: Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disease characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of salivary and lacrimal glands. 

Patients present with dry eye (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia) due to fibrosis of the lacrimal and salivary gland respectively.

Anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies are positive in Sjogren's syndrome. ANA and RF (Rheumatoid factor) can also be seen. Centromeric patterns and speckled patterns of staining are seen in Sjogren's syndrome.

The image below shows a speckled pattern of staining.

Option C: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that most commonly presents with arthralgia with early morning stiffness. 

Other important features of SLE include malar rash, discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, pleuritis, pericarditis, and lupus nephritis.

ANA, Anti-dsDNA antibodies, anti-smith antibodies are positive in SLE. Homogenous or diffuse staining and peripheral staining pattern are most commonly seen in SLE.

Image below shows a homogenous or diffuse stained immunofluorescence pattern seen in SLE.

Option D: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a multisystem disease that classically presents with pain, joint swelling, and stiffness of the small joints of the hands, feet, and wrists in a symmetrical manner.

RF and anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies are positive in RA. Homogenous staining is the most common pattern seen in RA.

questions.text: You were posted as a medical officer in a Kala-azar endemic area. There was a rise in the number of insects shown in the given image below. Identify the insect:
questions.solution:
The image given is that of a sandfly (Phlebotomus), which is the vector for Kala-azar.

Sandflies are generally small insects, light or dark brown in color. They are smaller than mosquitoes. Their body and wings are densely clothed with hair. Their wings are up-right and lanceolate in shape and their legs are longer compared with the size of the body. They hop about and do not fly much. The species of sandfly responsible for transmitting the disease kala-azar is Phlebotomus argentipes. 

Kala-azar or visceral leishmaniasis is a protozoal infection mainly affecting the reticuloendothelial system. It is caused by various species of the genus Leishmania. It can present as visceral leishmaniasis, cutaneous leishmaniasis, ad mucosal leishmaniasis. Clinical features of the visceral form include moderate to high-grade fever with chills and rigors, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. 

The gold standard test for the diagnosis is the demonstration of amastigotes in the smears of tissue aspirates. Another commonly used test is the detection of antibodies to a recombinant antigen called rK39 by a rapid immunochromatographic test. In immunocompromised individuals, parasites can be isolated from the buffy coat. Amphotericin B is the first-line drug used in India. 

Other diseases transmitted by sandflies include sandfly fever and oriental sore.

For the reduction of sandflies, a  single application of DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) or lindane has been found effective. 

Other options:

Option A: Tsetse flies or glossinae are the blood-sucking flies that resemble the common houseflies. They are yellow or dark-brown in color. When folded, their wings overlap each other like the blade of a scissor. They have a non-retractile proboscis which is rigid and adapted for piercing the skin and sucking the blood. They are vectors for trypanosomiasis or sleeping sickness and are only found in regions in Africa.

 

Option C- Rat flea is the vector for plague and typhus. They are wingless, their head is conical in shape, and is directly attached to the thorax without a neck. The head has piercing mouth parts that are conspicuous and project downward for sucking blood. They have 3 pairs of legs attached to the thorax. 

Option D: Black flies are small robust flies. They are black short stout legs, large broad wings, and a short proboscis to suck blood. They are the vectors of onchocerciasis in Africa, Mexico, Central, and South America.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), oriental sore, sandfly fever and oraya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

questions.text: Specific binding of the HIV to the CD4 receptor occurs via which of these structures?
questions.solution:
The specific binding of the HIV to the CD4 receptor is by the envelope glycoprotein gp120.

Other options:

Option B - Cell fusion occurs via binding to gp41. Cell fusion is essential for infection to take place.

Options C and D - Binding to CD4 receptor requires the participation of co-receptors, CXCR 4 for T cell - tropic HIV strains and CCR 5 for macrophage-tropic strains.

questions.text: Arrange the cyclins in the correct sequence according to their roles in the cell cycle, starting from the G1 (Gap 1) phase and progressing to the G2 (Gap 2) phase.

choices.text: Cyclin B- Cyclin E- Cyclin A- Cyclin D
Cyclin E- Cyclin B- Cyclin A-  Cyclin D
Cyclin D- Cyclin E- Cyclin A-  Cyclin B
Cyclin B- Cyclin A- Cyclin E-  Cyclin D

questions.solution:
The correct sequence of cyclins through the G1- S- G2 phase is  Cyclin D- Cyclin E- Cyclin A- Cyclin B.

Cell cycle progression is driven by the formation of complexes of proteins called cyclins and associated enzymes known as cyclin-dependent kinases. Cyclins are synthesized only during the cell cycle to regulate the progression of the cell across the phases of the cell cycle, while cyclin-dependent kinases are constitutively present irrespective of the cell cycle.

Cyclins D, E, A, and B appear sequentially during the cell cycle and bind to one or more CDKs.

  1. G1-S transition: Cyclin D-CDK4, cyclin D-CDK6, and cyclin E-CDK2.
  2. S-phase: Cyclin A-CDK1 and cyclin A-CDK2.
  3. G2-M transition: Cyclin B-CDK1.

CDK inhibitors (CDKIs) enforce the cell cycle checkpoints. There are several families of CDKIs:

  • CDKIs that broadly inhibit multiple CDKs: p21, p27, p57
  • CDKIs that inhibit CDK4 and CDK6: p15, p16, p18, and p19

The image below shows the different checkpoints and cell cycle regulators :

CDK: Cyclin-dependent kinase

questions.text: A young patient was diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma. Which of the following is not a 'B symptom' expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Pruritus is not a b symptom of Hodgkin's lymphoma. The b symptoms of Hodgkin's lymphoma are persistent fever (>100.4ºF), drenching night sweats, and unexplained weight loss of >10% body weight over the past 6 months.

Hodgkin's lymphoma is a lymphoid neoplasm characterized by the histological presence of Reed Sternberg cells on a background of non-neoplastic inflammatory cells.

The patient commonly presents with palpable, firm, rubbery, non-tender lymphadenopathy in the cervical or supraclavicular region. Systemic symptoms that are classified as B symptoms are important in the staging of the disease. Hepatosplenomegaly is rarely detected clinically. 

Ann Arbor Staging of Hodgkin’s Lymphoma:

Stage I

Involvement of a single lymph node (I) or of a single extra-lymphatic organ or site (IE)

Stage II

Involvement of 2 or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm (II) or localized involvement of an extra-lymphatic organ or site and 1 or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm (IIE)

Stage III

Involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm (III), which may be accompanied by

involvement of the spleen (IIIS) or

by localized involvement of an extra-lymphatic organ or site (IIIE) or

both (IIISE)

Stage IV

Diffuse or disseminated involvement of 1 or more

extra-lymphatic organs or tissues with or without

associated lymph node involvement
 

B symptoms

  • The presence of fever >38°C (100.4°F) for 3 consecutive days
  • Drenching night sweats
  • Unexplained loss of >10% of body weight in the 6 months

questions.text: The rescue team has found a 33-year-old man on an island where he was stranded after a shipwreck. He was missing for 5 days after the disaster and was found in an extremely weak and dehydrated state. His breath has a fruity smell and urinalysis shows a positive Rothera's test. The activity of which of the following enzymes is increased in him?
questions.solution:
A fruity smell (presence of acetone in breath) and positive Rothera's test with a history of prolonged starvation are suggestive of starvation ketosis. This is characterized by increased activity of the HMG CoA synthase enzyme.

Prolonged starvation implies a catabolic state in which there is excessive β-oxidation leading to increased production of acetyl CoA. The excessive acetyl CoA is utilized by the hepatocytes to synthesize ketone bodies for extrahepatic utilisation.

HMG CoA synthase is the enzyme required for ketone body synthesis, it is also the rate-limiting enzyme.

Other options:

  • HMG CoA reductase is involved in the synthesis of cholesterol.
  • Acetyl CoA carboxylase is involved in fatty acid synthesis.
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase converts pyruvate into acetyl CoA.

All three enzymes are inactive in low insulin states (such as prolonged starvation).

Rothera’s test using a nitroprusside reagent is a specific test used to detect ketone bodies like acetone or acetoacetate present in the given sample of urine. A purple ring at the junction of two liquids (shown in the image below) indicates a positive test. Rothera's test does not detect β-hydroxybutyrate.

questions.text: In a normal distribution curve, what is the percentage of the distribution, that falls within two standard deviations of the mean?
questions.solution:
Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 standard deviations of the mean.

Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within ±1 standard deviations of the mean.

Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 standard deviations of the mean.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

  • Normal distribution is the most widely used continuous distribution.
  • It is also called bell curve (bell shaped) or Gaussian distribution after a mathematician named Karl Friedrich Gauss.
  • The following is an image of three different types of normal distributions.
  • Normal distributions are defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation.
  • The mean, median and mode are all equal in a normal distribution.
  • All normal distributions are symmetric and have bell-shaped density curves with a single peak.
  • Exactly half of the values are to the left of the centre and the other half to the right.
  • The total area under the curve is 1.
  • The density of a normal distribution is more around the centre and less around the tails.
  • There is no skew in the curve.
  • Looking at the figure below, we can understand the empirical rule of a normal distribution which states that:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 1 SD).
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD).
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD).
  • Many data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution.
  • A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of prerenal AKI?
questions.solution:
Non steroidal anti inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and ACE inhibitors cause prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI). 

The use of NSAIDs causes reduced production of vasodilatory prostaglandins. This leads to decreased renal perfusion and glomerular capillary pressure. NSAIDs can also lead to acute interstitial nephritis, a cause of renal AKI. However, this is relatively uncommon.

ACE inhibitors cause inhibition of efferent arteriole vasoconstriction, leading to reduced renal perfusion.

Nephrotoxins like myeloma light chains, snake venom, myoglobin (due to rhabdomyolysis) cause acute tubular necrosis (ATN). This leads to renal or intrinsic AKI.

questions.text: Which of the following is a penicillinase-resistant penicillin?
questions.solution:
Cloxacillin is penicillinase-resistant penicillin.

Penicillinase is a beta-lactamase enzyme that inactivates penicillin by destroying the beta-lactam ring. This enzyme is produced by most staphylococci, some gonococci strains, Bacillus subtilis, E.coli, Hemophilus influenza etc..,

Penicillinase-resistant penicillins are not inactivated by penicillinase. But, they are less efficient than penicillin G against penicillin-sensitive pathogens. They are used to treat staphylococcal infections that are sensitive to methicillin. Penicillinase-resistant penicillins are:

  • Cloxacillin
  • Dicloxacillin
  • Flucloxacillin
  • Methicillin
  • Nafcillin

Other options:

Option A: Penicillin V is an acid-resistant penicillin preparation that is administered orally. But it has limited use against penicillinase-producing organisms.

Option C: Benzathine penicillin G and procaine penicillin G are repository preparations of penicillin G and are long-acting. They are given as deep I.M. injections. Benzathine penicillin has the longest half-life and is administered every 2-4 weeks. It is sensitive to penicillinase. 

Option D: Ampicillin is an extended-spectrum penicillin but is not resistant to beta-lactamases.

questions.text: An annual symposium on diabetes mellitus is being conducted by a medical college. The event would most likely comprise of _______.

choices.text: A series of speeches on the topic with the chairman summarizing at the end
A series of meetings with emphasis on individual work within a group
4-8 qualified persons  discussing the topic in front of an audience

questions.solution:
A symposium comprises of a series of speeches on the topic with the chairman summarizing at the end.

A symposium is a series of speeches on a selected subject by experts. Each expert presents an aspect of the subject briefly, after which the audience is allowed to ask questions. There is no discussion among symposium members. The chairman makes a comprehensive summary at the end of the session.

Other options:

Option B - A workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within a group, with the use of external consultants or experts. It can be divided into small groups each with a chairman and recorder. Each individual solves a part of the problem and leaves the workshop with a plan of action.

Option C - Role-playing is the dramatization of social situations for health education by those taking part in it. The group members enact the roles while the audience is actively concerned with the drama. Role-playing is useful in discussing problems of human relationships. The group size is recommended to be about 25.

Option D - A panel discussion is where 4 to 8 experts are allowed to have a discussion on a topic in front of an audience. There is no specific agenda or set speeches. The audience is also invited to take part after the main discussion.

questions.text: Identify the MRI image.
questions.solution:
The given MRI is a T2 weighted image as the CSF appears bright/hyperintense and white matter appears dark. 

In T1 images CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white and grey matter is dark.

Many pulse sequence techniques are used in MRI, of which the most classic are T1 and T2 weighted images.

FLAIR (fluid-attenuated inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. As a result, CSF is dark. However, white matter is dark and grey matter is bright similar to T2 imaging.

STIR (short tau inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fat from T2. So, fat is dark. It is done to detect bone marrow edema in body part scans.
