questions.text: A post-menopausal woman presents with a history of pain and swelling over the wrist after falling down the stairs. Plain radiograph is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The plain radiograph showing an extra-articular fracture at the distal end of the radius with dorsal angulation of the distal fragment is characteristic of Colles' fracture. 

Displacements in Colles' fracture:

  • Dorsal tilt/ shift
  • Lateral tilt/ shift (Radial tilt/shift)
  • Supination
  • Impaction of fragments

The clinical feature includes dinner fork deformity with prominence on the back of the wrist and depression in the front. It is treated by a Colles’ cast, which immobilizes the wrist in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation.

The below image shows dinner fork deformity in Colles' fracture.

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

questions.text: An intern decides to insert a central venous catheter through a femoral vein in a burns victim to administer IV fluids. However, while inserting the needle, he accidentally injures the structures lying in the femoral sheath. Which of the following is unlikely to get injured here?
questions.solution:
The structure unlikely to get injured here is the femoral nerve, as it is not a content of the femoral sheath. The femoral nerve lies lateral to the femoral sheath.

The femoral sheath is divided into three compartments:

  • The lateral compartment contains the femoral artery and femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve.
  • The intermediate compartment contains the femoral vein
  • The medial compartment which is termed as femoral canal contains lymphatic vessels, areolar tissue, and the lymph node of Cloquet.

Related Pearl: Anatomy of femoral canal

questions.text: In a patient suffering from parkinsons's disease, what is the most likely reason behind the gradual decline in the therapeutic effect of L-dopa?

choices.text: Inhibitory pathways grow into the basal ganglia from the frontal lobe.
There is an increase in circulating α-synuclein.
The dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra continue to degenerate.

questions.solution:
The most likely reason behind the gradual decline in the therapeutic effect of L-dopa in a patient suffering from Parkinson's disease is the continued degeneration of the dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. Since endogenous production of dopamine continues to decline, the exogenous source of dopamine (i.e. L-dopa) alone fails to maintain the same level of therapeutic effect.

Parkinson's disease (Paralysis Agitans) was shown to result from the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta. The fibers to the putamen (part of the striatum) are most severely affected.

Dopaminergic neurons and dopamine receptors are steadily lost with age in the basal ganglia in healthy individuals, and an acceleration of these losses apparently precipitates parkinsonism. Symptoms appear when 60–80% of the nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons degenerate.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a history of repeated multiple long bone fractures. On examination, there is the presence of blue sclera and dental abnormalities. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of repeated multiple bone fractures, blue sclera, and dental abnormalities are suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta.

Osteogenesis imperfecta(or brittle bone disease) is a connective tissue disorder that occurs due to abnormal type 1 collagen production. It occurs most commonly due to mutation in the COL1A and COL2A genes. These mutations lead to the replacement of glycine amino acid with another amino acid resulting in an abnormal triple helix of collagen. This results in the abnormal formation of type 1 collagen.

The main features are joints that are vulnerable to fracture (joint laxity), scleral alterations(blue sclera), dentinogenesis imperfecta, and deafness. Multiple bone fractures are a consequence of bone fragility. Bowing of the long bones, wormian bones, and multiple diaphyseal fractures of long bones with various stages are the common radiological findings that are observed. Management comprises the use of bisphosphonates, along with physiotherapy and walking aids.

The images below show blue sclera and wormian bones in osteogenesis imperfecta:

Other options:

Option A: Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant skeletal dysplasia with disproportionately short limbs, sleep apnea, and kyphoscoliosis. Facial features include button nose, frontal bossing, macrocephaly, etc. 

The images below show the features of achondroplasia:

(a) Prominent forehead and body asymmetry, (b) a low nasal bridge, (c) trident hands, (d) scoliosis 

Option C: Cretinism occurs due to iodine deficiency. Its clinical features are deaf-mutism, squint, mental retardation, and spastic or rigid neuromotor disorder. 

Option D: Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder. The affected persons will be tall with long limbs and digits. Spontaneous pneumothorax, aortic dissection, and lens dislocation are also seen. An early diastolic murmur is heard on auscultation.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with complaints of bed-wetting almost twice a week for the past 1 year. A detailed investigation was done to rule out an organic cause. What will be the most effective treatment plan for this child?

choices.text: Bladder training, with reward for delaying micturition during daytime
Bell and pad based classical conditioning

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of nocturnal enuresis. Bell and pad-based classical conditioning is the most effective treatment.

Nocturnal enuresis refers to the occurrence of involuntary urination at night after 5 years of age. It may be a normal phenomenon in children up to 5 years of age.

Treatment for nocturnal enuresis may include:

Behavioral therapy:

  • Classic conditioning with the bell (or buzzer) and pad (alarm) apparatus is the most effective treatment for enuresis.
  • Dryness is achieved in 50% of the cases.
  • Bladder training with encouragement or reward for delaying micturition for increasing times during waking hours is useful but considered inferior to bell and pad.

Pharmacotherapy:

  • Medications should be considered if behavioral therapy has failed, and if enuresis is causing impairment in social, family, and school function.
  • Desmopressin (an antidiuretic) and Reboxetine (a norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor) are commonly used drugs. Reboxetine is considered a safer alternative to imipramine.

Psychotherapy:

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presents with recent onset of photosensitivity and the development of vesicles and bullae on the sun-exposed areas of his skin. A urine analysis showed the presence of elevated levels of uroporphyrin I. Investigations revealed a deficiency in the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT).

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the most common type of porphyria and presents with cutaneous and hepatic features. It is caused due to a deficiency in the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase, which converts uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III.

The accumulated porphyrins are transported to the skin and act as photosensitizers. Hence, the patients usually present with skin friability, milia, and bullae on the sun-exposed skin of the dorsal aspect of the hands, forearms, face, legs, and feet. Hypertrichosis, mottled pigmentary change, and scleroderma-like induration are associated features.

The porphyrins accumulate in the liver and are excreted in urine and bile. Hepatic iron stores are increased as PCT is an iron-related disorder. Liver dysfunction is common in these patients and the risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma is increased. 

Diagnosis is made by the classical clinical feature of photosensitivity with elevated urine, stool, and plasma uroporphyrin with normal red cell uroporphyrin. 

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic porphyria

Hepatic porphyria is caused due to enzyme deficiency early in the pathway of heme synthesis. There is an accumulation of ALA and PBG. The patient principally presents with neurovisceral symptoms.

Erythropoietic porphyria is caused due to enzyme deficiency late in the pathway of heme synthesis. There is an accumulation of porphyrins which leads to cutaneous photosensitivity.

questions.text: The image shown below shows the technique of insertion of which of the following devices
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the technique of insertion of the laryngeal mask airway.

The laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device that is positioned in the hypopharynx.

Supraglottic airway devices are used with both spontaneously and mechanically ventilated patients during anaesthesia.

LMA has the advantages of being used in many settings, including the operating room (alternate route of ventilation), the emergency department (difficult intubation), and out-of-hospital care (paramedics).

This is because it is easy to use, quick to place even for inexperienced providers, and has a very high success rate.

The technique of insertion:

  • The deflated cuff of LMA is lubricated and inserted blindly into the hypopharynx. Once inflated, the cuff forms a low-pressure seal around the entrance to the larynx.
  • Correct placement of the tube is confirmed by giving gentle positive pressure ventilation while checking for chest rise and ETCO2 using capnography.

Other options:

Option A: Oropharyngeal airway is inserted in the patient’s mouth with concavity towards the hard palate. As the airway is inserted it is rotated 180 degrees (concavity towards the tongue) until the flange comes to rest on the patient’s lips. 

Option B: Nasopharyngeal airway is inserted through the nostril (after lubrication) along the natural curvature of the floor of the nasal cavity with the bevel pointing towards the septum. Once the device is inserted the flange should rest on the nostril opening.

Option D: Endotracheal tube is inserted infraglottically after visualizing the vocal cords with direct laryngoscopy.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with mild ptosis and proximal lower limb weakness. Nerve conduction studies show incremental response following brief exercise. Further investigations reveal antibodies against presynaptic P/Q voltage-gated calcium channels. Which of the following malignancies is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). It is associated with small-cell lung carcinoma.

It is an autoimmune disorder caused by antibodies that block acetylcholine release by inhibiting a presynaptic calcium channel. In contrast to myasthenia gravis, rapid, repetitive stimulation (muscle activity) results in an increase in muscle response and strength.

Patients typically present with weakness of their extremities. In about half the cases, there is an underlying malignancy; most often, neuroendocrine carcinoma of the lung (Small cell lung carcinoma). The stimulus for autoantibody formation in paraneoplastic cases may be the expression of the same calcium channel in the neoplastic cells.

Patients without cancer often have other autoimmune diseases, such as vitiligo or thyroid disease. Treatment consists of drugs that increase acetylcholine release by depolarizing synaptic membranes (pyridostigmine), plasmapheresis, and immunosuppressive agents, similar to myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: An elderly man is brought to the hospital after he complained of sudden jerky movements of his hands, which persist even when he is asleep. There is also a history of impaired memory. He underwent a corneal transplant 3 years ago. His electroencephalogram showed periodic slow sharp waves. His MRI scan is shown below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The MRI shows the presence of cortical ribboning. This finding, along with the presence of dementia, periodic slow sharp waves on the electroencephalogram, and myoclonic jerks are suggestive of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a prion disease that causes higher cortical function deficits. This infection can be acquired by corneal transplantation, contaminated electroencephalogram (EEG) electrode implantation, dura mater grafts, and contaminated human growth hormone (HGH) preparations.

Patients commonly present with myoclonus and dementia. EEG shows characteristic periodic electrical bursts. MRI shows increased intensity in the basal ganglia and cortical ribboning (ribbon-like signal hyperintensity of cerebral cortical gyri). On light microscopy, the pathologic hallmarks of CJD are spongiform degeneration and astrocytic gliosis.

The image below shows the presence of periodic electrical bursts of triphasic sharp waves on the electroencephalogram of a patient with CJD:

The given image shows increased intensity in the basal ganglia and cortical ribboning in a CJD patient:

 Other options:

Option A- Sturge Weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by angiomas of the leptomeninges and in the ophthalmic and maxillary nerve areas of distribution. Affected patients might have developmental delays, learning difficulties, and seizures. CT shows the presence of a tram track appearance.

Option C- Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a progressive demyelinating disease of the brain that occurs due to a previous infection with the measles virus. Most patients have a history of measles infection from many years ago. SSPE presents with intellectual disability, poor school performance, and mood and personality changes. EEG shows high voltage slow sharp waves that occur every 3-8 seconds followed by a flat background.

Option D- Patients with tuberous sclerosis present with seizures, mental retardation, adenoma sebaceum (facial angiofibromas), shagreen patch, hypomelanotic macules, periungual fibromas, renal angiomyolipomas, cardiac rhabdomyomas. Imaging may show the presence of subependymal nodules, cortical tubers, and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding population pyramids:

choices.text: They shows the distribution of ages across a population.
They can be used to compare the male and female population.
Youngest of the population is represented at the bottom.
Narrow base and wide middle is typical of developing countries.

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding population pyramids is option D. Population pyramids of developed countries typically have a narrow base and wide middle, whereas those of developing countries have a broad base and a tapering top. 

A population pyramid is a graphical representation of the age and sex of the population, and therefore, it is also called an age and sex pyramid.

The youngest of the population is represented at the bottom and the oldest at the top of the pyramid.

Besides showing the distribution of ages across a population, the pyramid is divided across the center to separate the male and female members of the population; therefore, they can be used to compare the difference between the male and female populations of a given area.

It also shows the number of dependents in the population at any given time.

Related Pearl: Population Pyramid

  • The age or population pyramid is used to represent the age/sex structure of a population.
  • Below is the age pyramid of India (2017).
  • The age pyramid of India has a broad base and a tapering top, as it is with most developing countries.
  • As a nation develops the lower portion of the pyramid will start constricting and the upper portion will start increasing. 
  • Developed countries usually will have a bulge in the middle with a narrow base, as shown below in the age pyramid of Switzerland.

Half-hourly for 2 hours,
Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
Then 2-hourly thereafter.

questions.text: A boxer is wheeled into the ER with complaints of double vision after suffering a severe blow to his face during a match. On examination, there is a flattening of malar prominence, trismus and a step deformity of the infraorbital margin. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of diplopia, flat malar prominence, trismus, and step deformity in the infraorbital margin is suggestive of fracture of zygoma or tripod fracture.

Zygoma is the second most frequently fractured bone in the face. The zygoma fracture is separated at its three processes - the zygomaticofrontal suture, infraorbital margin, and the zygomaticotemporal suture. It has the following clinical features:

  • Flattening of malar prominence. 
  • Trismus, due to depression of zygoma on the underlying coronoid process. 
  • Anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve. 
  • Step deformity of infraorbital margin.
  • Oblique palpebral fissure, due to the displacement of lateral palpebral ligament. 
  • Restricted ocular movements, due to entrapment of inferior rectus muscle. It may cause diplopia. 
  • Periorbital emphysema, due to escape of air from the maxillary sinus on nose blowing.

questions.text: Identify the test shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shows a tear strip placed in the lower lid of the eye. This is the Schirmer test.

Schirmer's test is used for the assessment of aqueous tear production by measuring the amount of wetting of a special filter paper (no. 41 Whatman). <10 mm of wetting after 5 minutes without anesthesia is considered abnormal. However, a single Schirmer test should not be used as the sole criterion for diagnosing dry eye.

Dry eye disease occurs as a result of inadequate tear volume and function which results In unstable tear film and ocular surface disease. The causes are: 

  • Sjögren syndrome
  • Ocular rosacea
  • Vitamin A deficiency
  • Follicular conjunctivitis
  • Age-related dry eye 
  • Wearing contact lenses 
  • Trachoma

Related Pearl: Tear film tests used for the diagnosis of dry eye

Schirmer test

Inference 

  • 15 mm: Normal
  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

Tear film break up test (TBUT)

Inference 

  • 15-35 seconds: Normal
  • < 10 seconds: Unstable tear film

Rose Bengal staining

Inference

  • A pattern: Confluent staining → Severe KCS
  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS
  • C pattern: Fine punctate stains → Mild KCS

Tear osmolarity test

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text:
A young patient presents with a history of increased urinary frequency, nocturia, and excessive thirst. Her laboratory investigations are given below. Brain MRI shows the absence of a bright spot in the pituitary. Her past medical history includes an episode of viral encephalitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Urine osmolarity <300 mOsm/L
Urine output >50 ml/kg/day
Random blood glucose 150 mg/dl
Antidiuretic hormone level (ADH) Decreased
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the lab results indicating increased urine output with low urine osmolarity and decreased ADH levels suggest a diagnosis of central diabetes insipidus. 

Diabetes insipidus can be of two types - central or peripheral (nephrogenic). Central DI occurs due to a deficiency of ADH. 

Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is a disorder of the posterior pituitary. It is characterized by decreased ADH leading to large volumes of urine production. Patients present with excessive thirst, nocturia, and urinary frequency. The urine is dilute with an osmolarity of < 300 mOsm/L. The 24-hour urine volume is >40 ml/kg and the basal plasma ADH is <1 pg/ml.

Central DI occurs due to damage to the neurohypophysis in the posterior pituitary. It can be congenital or acquired. In this patient, it is likely that her prior episode of viral encephalitis has led to the development of DI. 

Central DI can be treated with desmopressin, an ADH analog. Nephrogenic DI requires treatment with a thiazide diuretic, amiloride, a low sodium diet, and indomethacin. 

Other options:

Option A: In nephrogenic DI, ADH levels may be normal or increased because the kidney has become resistant to its effects. The two can be differentiated by the water deprivation test. (Option A)

Option B - Primary polydipsia would have a bright spot on the brain MRI. Primary polydipsia presents with an excessive thirst that reduces the serum osmolarity. There is a compensatory increase in free water excretion that offsets the increased intake to maintain a normal serum sodium level. 

Option D - Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion would have increased ADH secretion, concentrated urine, and hyponatremia. 

Related Pearl: Causes of Central Diabetes insipidus

  • Neoplasms: 
    • Pituitary adenomas (most common)
    • Meningioma
    • Metastasis from lung and breast cancers
  • Infiltrative: 
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Genetic: 
    • Wolfram syndrome
    • Hand-Schuller-Christian disease 
  • Infections: 
    • Chronic meningitis
    • Viral encephalitis
    • Toxoplasmosis
  •  Inflammatory:
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
    • Lupus erythematosus
    • Scleroderma
  •  Vascular:
    • Sheehan’s syndrome
    • Aneurysm (internal carotid)
  • Head injury (closed and penetrating) including pituitary surgery
  • Snakebite
  • Lymphocytic hypophysitis

 

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality.

Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change

questions.text: A baby was brought to the clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, failure to thrive, and hair loss. On examination, the following findings are noted. Identify the mineral deficiency leading to this condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical features shown in the images are periorificial dermatitis and alopecia. These features in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica, which is seen with zinc deficiency.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a condition that occurs due to zinc deficiency and presents after weaning. Clinical features include failure to thrive, anorexia, diarrhea, recurrent infections, alopecia, male hypogonadism, and neurological manifestations like tremor, nystagmus, photophobia, hypogeusia, irritability, etc.

Skin manifestations such as vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities and periorificial (perianal, perigenital, perioral) regions are commonly seen as shown below. Affected infants require long-term supplementation with zinc.

Other options:

Option A: Niacin deficiency leads to Pellagra which is characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. Dermatitis is seen in sun-exposed areas and presents as hyperpigmentation around the neck known as Casal's necklace. An image of Casal's necklace is shown below.

Option C: Riboflavin deficiency manifests as glossitis, cheilitis, magenta-colored tongue, angular stomatitis, and circumcorneal vascularization, as shown below.

Option D: Selenium deficiency is implicated in keshan disease (Endemic cardiomyopathy) and kashin-Beck disease (Chronic, endemic osteoarthropathy).

questions.text: You are assisting your professor during a breech delivery. You notice that she performs the maneuver given below to deliver the extended arms of the baby. This maneuver is known as:
questions.solution:
The maneuver shown in the image is Lovset's maneuver used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Loveset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A pregnant woman with cardiac disease is on warfarin therapy. When will the final switch to heparin be advised?
questions.solution:
The final switch to heparin in pregnant women is advised at 36 weeks of pregnancy.

The choice of anticoagulants is the main problem in pregnancy due to the following reasons:

  • Warfarin: Although safe for the mother, can lead to warfarin embryopathy, miscarriage, IUGR, and stillbirths.
  • Heparin (Unfractionated heparin-UFH): It is safe for the fetus as it does not cross the placenta but less effective than warfarin.
  • LMWH (low molecular weight heparin): Inadequate and ACOG does not recommend its use in pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves.

Period of gestation

Anticoagulant

Till 12 completed weeks

LMWH or UFH

13 to 36 weeks

Warfarin

36 weeks to 6 hours before delivery

LMWH or UFH

6 hours after vaginal and 24 hours after cesarian section

LMWH or UFH (ACOG recommendation)

If the patient delivers when the anticoagulant is still effective and bleeds excessively, then protamine sulfate is given intravenously.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a physiological uncoupler?
questions.solution:
Thermogenin is a physiological uncoupler.

Uncouplers act by increasing the permeability of the mitochondrial membrane to ions. They collapse the proton gradient established by allowing the H+ to pass across the membrane without going through the ATP synthase enzyme complex.

  •  Synthetic: 2, 4 dinitrophenol
  •  Natural:Thyroxine and thermogenin. Thermogenin is found naturally in the brown adipose tissue, whose function is heat generation, especially in a newborn

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: As per the WHO recommendation for AMTSL (active management of the third stage of labor), when should the oxytocin be administered?

choices.text: After 30 min of delivery of fetus
Within 1 min of delivery of fetus
Within 1 min of delivery of placenta
After 5 mins of delivery of placenta

questions.solution:
WHO guidelines for active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL) recommends oxytocin administration immediately (within 1 minute) after the delivery of the fetus.  Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV. It should be given after the delivery of the fetus and before the delivery of the placenta. 

AMTSL  guidelines recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonic (Oxytocin). Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV.
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in cesarean section and in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tonus assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women. Continuous monitoring of uterine tone is done every 15 minutes for 2 hours. If uterine atony is detected, a fundal massage is performed.

Uterine massage is not recommended routinely.

The goal of this is to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Hence, uterotonics are the most important factor to decrease PPH. Delayed cord clamping is a less important component in this direction and similarly, cord traction is not as critical. Uterine massage does not form the main component of AMTSL.

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical structures is used as a demarcation point to differentiate an upper GI bleed from a lower GI bleed?
questions.solution:
The ligament of Treitz is used as the demarcation point to differentiate between upper gastrointestinal bleeding and lower gastrointestinal bleeding. It is a part of the duodenojejunal junction. 

Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower GI bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

Melena is the passage of black, tarry stools. It is seen in upper GI bleeding. Hematochezia is the passage of fresh blood with stools. It is seen in lower GI bleeding.

questions.text: A patient with HIV has a CD4 count of 170/ μL. He complains of breathlessness for the past week. The patient's chest radiograph is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows symmetric interstitial infiltrates mainly in the perihilar region. This finding along with the CD4 count of 170 cells /μL makes pneumocystis pneumonia the most likely diagnosis.

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients. It usually occurs when the CD4 count falls below 200 cells/μL.

Patients usually present with fever and nonproductive cough with progressive shortness of breath. It can also affect other organs like lymph nodes, spleen, and liver. The classic radiographic appearance consists of diffuse bilateral symmetric interstitial infiltrates that are perihilar. CT will show diffuse ground-glass opacities.

Giemsa stain, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains demonstrate trophozoites. The cyst wall appears black with Gomori's methenamine silver stain. Shown below is an image of the Gomori’s methenamine silver staining showing crescent-shaped cysts resembling the crushed ping-pong balls of P. jirovecii.

Other options

Option A- Mycobacterium avium complex infection is generally seen when the CD4 count falls less than 50 cells/μL. CT scan of the infected lung will show peribronchial inflammation, which gives rise to a tree in a bud appearance (small round structures attached to linear structures). In severe cases, there might be bronchiectasis and cavity formation.

Below image- Tree in bud appearance which is indicated by an arrowhead.

Option B- Histoplasmosis occurs when the CD4 count falls below 150 cells/μL and high risk populations in endemic areas or those with occupational exposure. Chest radiograph shows the signs of pneumonitis with prominent hilar or mediastinal adenopathy.

Option D- Pneumococcal pneumonia commonly appears as lobar or segmental consolidation. In some, it can involve more than one lobe. It can have pleural effusion and empyema in severe cases.

Below image- Consolidation in a streptococcal pneumonia

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasms found in patients with HIV infection

Infections

  • Protozoal and Helminthic Infections
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal Infections
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial Infections
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral Infections
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

 

One-liners about HIV

  • Sexual contact is the least efficacious yet most common mode of spread of HIV infection
  • ELISA is used for the detection of antibodies against viral proteins. This is the most sensitive and the best screening test for the diagnosis of AIDS.
  • Western blot is the most specific or the confirmatory test for HIV.
  • Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection in patients with AIDS.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) chorioretinitis exclusively in patients with CD4+ T cell counts less than 50 per microliter.
  • Toxoplasma gondii causes encephalitis and is responsible for 50% of all mass lesions in the central nervous system.
  • John Cunningham virus (JC virus) is a human papovavirus that causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
  • Persistent diarrhea in AIDS is caused by Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli, or microsporidia.
  • AIDS-dementia complex is the most common neurological manifestation of HIV infection.
  • Inflammatory myopathy is the commonest skeletal muscle disorder in HIV.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with infertility and menstrual abnormalities. Hysterosalpingogram was done to study the patency of fallopian tubes and the following finding is seen. What is the most probable causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given hysterosalpingography image shows the typical "tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube which is highly suggestive of tuberculous salpingitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

All the other options - N. gonorrhoea, C. trachomatis, and Mycoplasma hominis are causative agents for pelvic inflammatory disease.

Other hysterosalpingography features of genital tuberculosis are given below:

Image below shows "Pipe stem" or "Lead pipe" appearance. There is absence of normal tortuosity and a curved or straight pipe like appearance show fibrotic stage of tuberculous salpingitis. 

Image below shows multiple constrictions along the fallopian tube giving rise to a "beaded" appearance.

Image below shows sacculation of both tubes in distal portion with an associated hydrosalpinx giving a Golf club-like appearance.

Image below shows multiple small diverticular like appearance surrounding the ampulla produced by caseous ulceration giving the tubal outline a Rosette-like appearance (" Tufted tube" )

Image below shows " Tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a painless palpable lump in her left breast. She had sustained a traumatic blow to her left breast 1 month back. Mammography showed a radiolucent cystic lesion with rimmed calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The typical history of a breast lump following trauma and mammography findings of a radiolucent cystic lesion with rimmed calcification suggests a diagnosis of fat necrosis.

About half the affected women with fat necrosis of the breast have a history of breast trauma or previous surgery. It can present as a painless palpable mass, skin thickening or retraction, or mammographic densities or calcifications.

Histologically, necrotic adipose tissue with foamy macrophages, multinucleated giant cells, and chronic inflammatory cells are seen often with hemosiderin deposits, fibrosis, and calcification.

The following image shows an area of fat necrosis within breast tissue.

Note: Calcifications are seen on mammography in the following conditions -

  • Apo­crine cysts
  • Hyalinized fibroadenomas
  • Sclerosing adenosis
  • Duct ectasia 
  • Breast carcinoma- shows irregular densities and small, numerous, clustered calcifications (microcalcifications).

questions.text: A college-going student presents to you with rapidly increasing power in his glasses due to progressive myopia. On asking the patient to look down you notice the following sign. The ophthalmic examination in this condition usually reveals all the following additional signs except
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing Munson's sign are suggestive of keratoconus. In keratoconus, Vogt's striae are seen (not Haab's striae).

Haab’s striae are tears and breaks in Descemet's membrane, as seen in congenital glaucoma. 

The signs seen in keratoconus are:

Keratoconus is a progressive disorder and occurs due to central/paracentral thinning of the corneal stroma. This results in apical protrusion of the cornea and irregular astigmatism. Patients complain of defective vision due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism despite full correction with glasses.

The signs seen in keratoconus include:

  • Munson's sign is the localized bulging of the lower eyelid when the patient is looking downwards.
  • Using distant direct ophthalmoscopy a well-delineated oil droplet reflex can be elicited. It is an annular black shadow that separates the central and peripheral areas of the cornea. 
  • Fleischer's rings are epithelial iron deposits that are best seen with a cobalt blue filter during slit-lamp examination. 
  • Vogt striae are vertical deep stromal lines seen using a slit-lamp.
  • The scissoring/yawning reflex can be elicited using a retinoscopy. It occurs when two bands of a light beam reflexed from the retina move like the blades of a pair of scissors.

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

Related Pearl: Vogt's striae

The above image shows “Vogt’s Striae” which are characteristically seen in Keratoconus.

  • Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.
  • It may be asymmetric depending on the degree of keratoconus in each eye.
  • It is considered that there is a positive correlation between the orientation of the lines with the steepest axis of the cornea and the mechanism is thought to be related to mechanical stress forces on collagen lamellae radiating from the cone apex.
  • The striae can temporarily disappear with external pressure to the globe.

questions.text: What is the best way to diagnose patients with suspected bronchial asthma?

choices.text: Chest radiograph showing findings characteristic of asthma

questions.solution:
The best way to diagnose bronchial asthma is by the demonstration of reversible obstruction of the airways. 

Earlier a 200 ml and 12% increase in the FEV1 following the administration of an inhaled beta 2 agonist was said to demonstrate reversibility and significant bronchodilator response. According to the latest guidelines the following formula is used:

Bronchodilator response = ([Postbronchodilator value – Prebronchodilator value] x 100)/Predicted value. The 'value' in the equation is FEV1. An increase of >10% is considered significant.

Other options:

Option A: In the absence of comorbidities, chest radiographs are always normal in patients with asthma and there are no characteristic findings

Option B: Skin tests for specific allergens cannot be used to confirm a diagnosis of asthma but they can be used to confirm suspected triggers for asthma.

Option C: Although eosinophilia may be seen in patients with asthma, it cannot be used to diagnose asthma.

Related Pearl: Treatment of Asthma based on severity of symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following milestones is expected to be seen in a child at 5 years of age?

choices.text: Riding a tricycle and making a tower of 9 blocks
Establishment of handedness and parallel play

questions.solution:
At the age of 5 years, a child is expected to dress and undress themselves.

Developmental milestones at the age of 5 years include:

  • Motor - skips
  • Adaptive - Draws a triangle
  • Language - Asks meaning of words
  • Social - Dresses and undresses

Undressing is easier and hence learned before dressing.

  • 2 years - Helps to undress
  • 3 years - Helps in dressing (if helped with buttons)
  • 5 years - Dress and undress fully (without any help)

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental Milestones
At 1 year
  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months
At 2 years
  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs

  • Motor: Rides tricycle

At 4 years
  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories

At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips

questions.text: Identify the phase of menstruation given below:
questions.solution:
The image depicts the proliferative phase of endometrium.

During menstruation, the endometrium goes through three phases, namely proliferative, secretory, and menstrual phases.

 Features in proliferative phase/ follicular phase:

  • It begins when the regeneration of menstruating endometrium is complete and lasts until the 14th day of the menstrual cycle.
  • The glands of the functional layer are simple tubules with regular epithelium.
  • The basal layer of the endometrium and functional layer become more defined.
  • Arteries become more coiled and spiraled and extend through the endometrium.

Features in secretory phase/ luteal phase:

  • The secretory phase of the endometrium begins on the 15th day of the menstrual cycle and persists until the onset of menstruation.
  • The epithelium shows subnuclear vacuolation (presumptive evidence of progesterone activity).
  • Characteristic corkscrew-shaped glands and edematous stroma.

The image below shows the secretory endometrium

Menstrual phase: Glands shrink with prominent vessels and hemorrhagic spots.

questions.text: In a bimodal series, if the mean is 4 and median is 7, what is the mode?
questions.solution:
• The relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as Mode = 3 median – 2 mean.
  • In this scenario, mode = (3x7) – (2x4) = 21 – 8 = 13.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (b) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (c) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (a) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: A 20 yr old male was brought to casualty in unconscious state after a head injury. On examination, CSF rhinorrhea and Battle sign are noted. Which of the following most likely occured to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a battle sign, indicates a skull base fracture associated with bruising over mastoid process. Battle sign and CSF rhinorrhea are features of a middle cranial fossa fracture.

Middle cranial fossa fracture is associated with:

  • CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea
  • Hemotympanum
  • Ossicular disruption
  • Battle sign: Bruising behind the ear
  • 7th and 8th cranial nerve palsies

CSF rhinorrhea or otorrhea: Double target sign, a double-ring pattern described with CSF-containing bloody fluid from the ear or nose, when dripped onto paper or linen.

Double target sign is seen patients with CSF rhinorrhea. The nasal discharge in a patient with CSF rhinorrhea after head trauma is mixed with blood. When this discharge is collected on a filter paper, it shows a double target sign with a central red spot and a peripheral lighter halo as seen in the image below. 

The image below shows the 'battle' sign.

Anterior cranial fossa fracture is associated with:

  • Subconjunctival hematoma
  • CSF rhinorrhea
  • Carotico-cavernous fistula
  • Periorbital hematoma or “Raccoon eyes”

Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes): Pooling of blood surrounding the eyes, associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa (given below). 

Other options:

Option A: Duret hemorrhages are delayed, secondary brainstem hemorrhages. They occur in craniocerebral trauma victims with rapidly evolving descending transtentorial herniation. They are typically located in the ventral and paramedian aspects of the upper brainstem.

Option B: Kernohan phenomenon is a radiological finding resulting from extensive midline shift due to mass effect, resulting in indentation in the contralateral cerebral crus by the tentorium cerebelli. 

Option D: An epidural hematoma forms between the skull and the dura mater, which also occurs after a head injury, but presents with a lucid interval. 

Related Pearl: Signs of base of skull fracture

Signs of Base of Skull Fracture

  • Bilateral periorbital haematoma (raccoon eyes)
  • Battle’s sign (bruising over mastoid)
  • CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea
  • Haemotympanum or bleeding from ear

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman came with complaints of a gritty sensation in her eyes. On examination, Rose Bengal staining is positive. She is diagnosed with keratoconjunctivitis sicca. Which of the following layer of the tear film is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Keratoconjunctivitis sicca is due to the deficiency of the aqueous layer of the tear film.

Causes of keratoconjunctivitis sicca:

  • Sjogren's syndrome (primary keratoconjunctivitis sicca)
  • Non-Sjogren's keratoconjunctivitis sicca
    • Primary age-related hyposecretion (most common)
    • Lacrimal gland deficiencies- congenital, infiltration by tumors or sarcoidosis, surgical removal
    • Lacrimal gland duct obstruction- old trachoma, burns,  SJS
    • Reflex hyposecretion (neurogenic causes)- Parkinson disease, 7th nerve palsy, reflex sensory block

Related Pearl: Layers of the Tear Film

Lipid layer

  • Outermost layer
  • Secreted by the meibomian, Zeis glands
  • Prevents evaporation of tears

Aqueous layer

  • Middle layer
  • Secreted by the lacrimal and accessory lacrimal glands
  • Provides lubrication

Mucin layer  

  • Innermost layer
  • Secreted by the goblet cells of the conjunctiva
  • Help in spreading the tear film over the ocular surface

The maximum density of the goblet cells is seen on the nasal bulbar conjunctiva.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with limping gait and left hip pain. A plain radiograph of his hip shows the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of limping gait and left hip pain with radiographic findings of the radiolucency and distorted articular surface is suggestive of avascular necrosis. 

Avascular necrosis or osteonecrosis is a painful bone condition as a result of diminished blood supply mainly due to trauma or non-traumatic etiologies. 

The typical features are pain with movements in or near the joint, click in the joint, joint stiffness, limping gait, and deformity. Restriction of movements is also a feature of this condition. The radiograph shows reactive new bone formation, increased radiolucency in the subchondral bone, and a distorted articular surface. 

Management in the early stages can involve osteotomy while in late stages pain control, splinting, arthrodesis, and total or partial replacement are preferred.  

Other options: 

Option A: Tuberculosis of the hip is characterized by painful and restricted movements of the hip. The radiographic findings are not appreciable in the early stages. But late stages show periarticular osteoporosis, hazy, and irregular joint margins with a reduction in the joint space, and wandering acetabulum. 

Option B: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is usually seen in females in the 4th to 5th decade. Patients present with symmetrical polyarthritis of the proximal finger joints, tenosynovitis, early morning stiffness and pain. RA of the hip can be bilateral. Radiographic findings such as joint space narrowing due to hyaline cartilage destruction, cyst formation, and acetabular protrusion type deformity can be seen.

Option C: Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease of the spine and sacroiliac joint. It typically occurs in the age group 15-25 years with a male preponderance. Features include backache, stiffness, sciatica, and fixed flexion contracture. Radiographic findings show erosion of sacroiliac joints, squaring, and bridging of the vertebral body leading to a bamboo spine appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an orphan drug?
questions.solution:
Acetaminophen is not an orphan drug. It is an essential drug.

Orphan drugs are drugs for rare diseases.

Orphan drugs are for the treatment or prevention of rare diseases with little commercial value for pharmaceutical companies. Therefore, special incentives are given by the government for the pharmaceutical companies for the development and marketing of orphan drugs.

Few examples of orphan drugs:

  • Miltefosine
  • Sodium nitrite
  • Succimer
  • Rifabutin
  • Liposomal amphotericin B
  • Fomepizole

questions.text: What is the usual method of sterilization of this medium used for the primary isolation of mycobacterium species?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Lowenstein-Jensen medium. The medium is sterilized by inspissation.

Inspissation is used for the sterilization of heat labile culture media containing eggs or serum. This method of sterilization involves heating at 80–85 °C for 30 minutes on 3 consecutive days. Another medium for which this method is used is loeffler's serum.

Lowenstein–Jensen medium is commonly used, egg-based, selective culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Loeffler's serum slope is an enriched medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Other Options:

Option B: Pasteurization - Milk is heated at either 63°C for 30 minutes (the holder method) or at 72°C for 15–20 seconds (the flash process), followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower. 

Option C: Autoclaving is a method of sterilization by moist heat.

Option D: Hot air oven is a method of sterilization by dry heat.

Moist heat causes coagulation and denaturation of proteins, while dry heat causes oxidation and charring of proteins. Hence not preferred for egg-containing culture media like the Lowenstein-Jensen medium.

questions.text: A neonate was noted to have cyanosis of the oral mucosa. Chest x-ray revealed a snowman appearance of the cardiac silhouette. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Snowman's appearance on the chest X-ray image is classically seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC).

Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection/return is a cyanotic congenital heart disease in which the pulmonary veins fail to make their normal connection with the left atrium. This results in anomalous drainage into the systemic circulation.

There are four types of TAPVC based on the level of connections relative to the heart. The four types are:

  • Supracardiac
  • Cardiac
  • Infracardiac
  • Mixed

The supracardiac variant can classically depict a snowman appearance/figure of 8/cottage loaf heart on the frontal chest radiograph.

The dilated vertical vein on the left, the brachiocephalic vein on the top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium. The image given below shows a snowman or figure-8 configuration. Cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary vascularity are evident.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or Figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: The anomaly shown in the image below, falls under which category of the AFS (American Fertility Society) classification of Mullerian duct anomalies?
questions.solution:
The image shows a hysterosalpingogram of a unicornuate uterus, which falls under Class II of Mullerian duct anomalies

In the unicornuate uterus, the formation of the uterus and fallopian tube occurs entirely from one Mullerian duct due to the developmental arrest of other Mullerian ducts. On Hysterosalpingography, the endometrial cavity usually appears fusiform shape tapering at the apex and draining into a single fallopian tube. The uterus generally appears shifted off the midline.

The AFS (American Fertility Society) classification of Mullerian duct anomalies is as follows:

  • Class I—Mullerian agenesis or hypoplasia.
  • Class II—Unicornuate uterus, with absent or defective development of one Mullerian duct.
  • Class III—Uterus didelphys
  • Class IV—Bicornuate uterus 
  • Class V—Septate uterus
  • Class VI—Arcuate uterus

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct

Surrogacy for treatment of infertility 

Vaginal hypoplasia is surgically corrected at the time of marriage

 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any   Uterine rupture, abortions, risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct Metroplasty (Resection of membrane and fundal recombination) Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation 
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part fused where as upper part unfused Metroplasty in selected cases  Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 

Diminished fertility, Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation

 
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (cockscomb cervix)   Ectopic pregnancy,  cervical incompetance,  clear cell adenocarcinoma of vagina and cervix 

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: A professional boxer is diagnosed with diabetes mellitus. He is concerned about weight changes as a side effect of anti-diabetic drugs and explains that he has to maintain his current weight category. Which of the following will you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Saxagliptin, a dipeptidyl peptidase - 4 inhibitor (DPP-4 inhibitor), can be prescribed for this patient as it has a weight-neutral effect.

DPP-4 is an enzyme that breaks down vasoactive peptides such as glucagon-like peptide -1 and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide. These peptides exert their main effect by stimulating glucose-dependent insulin release from pancreatic islets. DPP - 4 inhibitors such as saxagliptin prevent the breakdown of these peptides and prolong their action on pancreatic cells. 

Examples of DPP-4 inhibitors are sitagliptin, saxagliptin, linagliptin, and vildagliptin.

The following table contains a list of oral hypoglycemic agents and their effect on weight.

EFFECT DRUGS
Weight gain Sulfonylureas (gliclazide), Insulin, Thiazolidinediones (pioglitazone)
Weight loss GLP-1 analogues (liraglutide), Pramlintide, SGLT-2 inhibitors, Metformin*
Weight neutral Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors, DPP-4 inhibitors

 

*Note: Metformin classification is a bit difficult. It can cause mild weight loss in some patients but few authorities do consider metformin as weight neutral.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with fever, arthralgia, fatigue for the past six months, and new-onset hematuria. The patient has a rash on her face as shown in the image below. Urine examination reveals RBC casts and proteinuria. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of lupus nephritis.

Lupus nephritis is a common complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It results from immune complex deposition containing DNA and anti-DNA. 

Clinical features include proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension. The disease is divided into 6 classes based on severity. Patients with class V disease are at an increased risk of thrombotic complications. Lupus nephritis can result in end-stage disease warranting dialysis or transplantation.

SLE is an autoimmune condition more commonly seen in women. Antinuclear antibodies, anti-dsDNA, and anti-Sm are the autoantibodies implicated. Symptoms include maculopapular butterfly rash, photosensitivity, oral or nasal ulcers, fever, and intermittent polyarthritis. Pleuritis and pericarditis can also be associated. Systemic glucocorticoids, cyclophosphamide, or mycophenolate mofetil are used for management. Due to the possible teratogenic effects of these drugs, hydroxychloroquine is the mainstay in pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A - Acute interstitial nephritis is a type of acute kidney injury. It is marked by oliguria and raised creatinine. Various causes of interstitial injury include the use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), pyelonephritis, leukemia, and sepsis. White blood cell (WBC) casts and granular casts may be seen.

Option B - Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis usually affects male children between the age of 2-14. Skin or pharyngeal infection with M types of the organism is implicated. Symptoms include hematuria, pyuria, and hypertension. Flank pain and headache are also associated symptoms. Red blood cell (RBC) casts are seen in the urine.

Option D - IgA nephropathy arises due to mesangial IgA deposition. It is characterized by recurrent macroscopic hematuria after an upper respiratory infection associated with proteinuria. Mesangial proliferation is a distinctive feature. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and steroids can be used for management.

Related Pearl: Classification of Lupus Nephritis (International Society of Nephrology and Renal Pathology Society)

 

Class 

Findings

Immune complex deposition in the mesangium without structural changes by light microscopy.

Mesangial proliferative lupus nephritis (class II)

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is this instrument contraindicated?
questions.solution:
The image shows Piper's forceps, identified by its distinct perineal curve. It is contraindicated in obstructed labour.

Piper forceps is a specialized forceps, used to assist the delivery of the after-coming head of the breech (Option A). It can also be used in cases of occipito-posterior position and caesarian delivery (Options B and C). It has a cephalic curve, reverse pelvic curve, and long parallel shanks that permit the baby’s body to rest against it during head delivery.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text: Identify this complication of burns.
questions.solution:
The image shows a 'Marjolin ulcer'.

Marjolin’s ulcer is a term used to describe a rare type of SCC (squamous cell carcinoma) which arises in sites of chronic wounds or scars.

The malignant transformation is slow, with an average latency time of approx 30 years.

The tumor may initially present as an ulceration that fails to heal; nodules may develop as the lesion progresses. Other clinical signs include rolled or everted wound margins, excessive granulation tissue, a rapid increase in size, and bleeding on touch.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of fetal biophysical profile?
questions.solution:
The contraction stress test is not a component of the biophysical profile.

Components of Biophysical profile (BPP)/Manning score:

(Mnemonic:BATMaN)

  • B - Breathing movements of the fetus
  • A - Amniotic fluid volume
  • T - Tone of the fetus
  • M - Movements of the fetus
  • N - Non-stress test (NST)

The modified biophysical score has only 2 components i.e NST and amniotic fluid index only. It is considered abnormal (nonreassuring) when the NST is non-reactive and/or the AFI is <5.

*Note: The contraction stress test (oxytocin challenge test) is an invasive method to assess fetal well-being during pregnancy. When there is an alteration in FHR in response to uterine contractions, it suggests fetal hypoxia.

questions.text: A patient on long-term anticoagulation therapy with warfarin, would need an increase in dosage when coadministered with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
A patient on long-term anticoagulation therapy with warfarin would need an increased in dosage when coadministered with rifampicin. This is because rifampicin is a potent microsomal enzyme inducer and can decrease the effect of warfarin.

Warfarin is cleared hepatically primarily via the CYP2C9 enzyme.

Rifampicin induces CYP3A and CYP2D6 enzymes.

    • Phenobarbitone (CYP2B1)

    • Phenytoin
    • Glucocorticoids
  • CYP2E1
    • Isoniazid
    • Chronic alcoholism

Note: Isoniazid is an inducer for CYP2E1 but an inhibitor for CYP3A4

questions.text: Which of the following structures are not removed in a modified radical hysterectomy?
questions.solution:
In modified radical hysterectomy/Type II hysterectomy, the uterine vessels are not removed. They are ligated at the level of the ureter. 

Structures removed in Type II hysterectomy:

  • Uterus
  • Cervix
  • Proximal 1-2cm (upper 1/3rd) of the vagina
  • Parametrial and paracervical tissue medial to the ureter
  • Pelvic nodes

Hysterectomy types include:

  • Type I - Simple hysterectomy/ extrafascial
  • Type II - Modified radical hysterectomy/ Wertheim hysterectomy
  • Type III - Radical hysterectomy/ Meigs-Wertheim hysterectomy
  • Type IV - Extended radical Hysterectomy
  • Type V - Exenteration

    Main differences between a modified radical hysterectomy (type II) and a radical hysterectomy (type III):

      Modified radical hysterectomy Radical hysterectomy
    Uterine artery Ligated at the level that it crosses the ureters Ligated at the origin from the internal iliac artery
    Cardinal ligaments Medial half of cardinal ligaments resected Cardinal ligaments divided at the sidewall
    Uterosacral ligament  Divided midway between uterus and sacrum Divided at sacrum
     Vagina 1-2cm of the proximal vagina (upper 1/3rd of the vagina) removed >2cm of the upper vagina (upper 2/3rd of the vagina) removed

questions.text: A young man comes to the urology department with a chronic history of deformity of the penis, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection.  On examination, there were palpable penile plaques and penile ultrasound showed a thickened area of tissue around tunica albuginea. He has been using the device shown below but is now seeking a permanent solution. What surgical procedure you would recommend for him?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is suffering from Peyronie’s disease. The image shows the traction device/ extender used to treat excessive penile curvature. The most common surgical procedure used in Peyronie’s disease is Nesbit's procedure.

Peyronie's disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection. It causes the penis to bend, usually towards the side of the plaque. It can be associated with Dupuytren's contracture as a part of the Galezia triad (Dupuytren's contracture, retroperitoneal fibrosis, Peyronie's disease).

Some cases may resolve spontaneously. If not, conservative measures such as oral tamoxifen, vitamin E, terfenadine, intralesional verapamil, etc. can be attempted. Intralesional collagenase has also been used. Penile extenders/ traction devices such as the devices shown in the above image have also been used. However, if none of these methods are effective, surgical management can be tried using Nesbit's procedure.

Nesbit's procedure is indicated when all other interventions have failed and the patient is experiencing difficulties in their sexual and personal life due to this condition. The procedure is started by creating an artificial erection by injecting normal saline. Following this, an elliptical excision is done on the convex side of the penis (opposite to the thickened plaque). The width of the excised tissue depends on the degree of penile deformity. The side with the plaque is left as it is.

Options (A) and (B): Lord’s operation and Jaboulay’s procedure are surgery performed for hydrocoele.

Option (D): Anderson-Hynes operation is a pyeloplasty procedure performed for hydronephrosis.

questions.text: A  female patient presents with severe abdominal pain and vomiting which was provisionally diagnosed as intestinal obstruction. An emergency laparotomy was done and the following specimen was removed. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the image of a trichobezoar, suggests a diagnosis of trichophagia.

Trichophagia is the compulsive eating of hair associated with trichotillomania. Trichotillomania is a form of obsessive-compulsive disorder that is associated with hair pulling. In trichophagia, people also ingest the hair that they pull. 

Complications of trichotillomania include:

  • trichobezoars
  • malnutrition
  • intestinal obstruction

Trichobezoar is a foreign body found in the gastrointestinal tract as a result of accumulated ingested hair.

The modalities currently used in the management of trichotillomania are cognitive behavioral therapy and habit reversal training.

questions.text: Electron microscopic picture of which of the following conditions is shown below?
questions.solution:
The given electron microscopy image shows tennis racket-shaped Birbeck granules. These granules are characteristic of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

Langerhans cell histiocytosis occurs due to the proliferation of a special type of immature dendritic cells, called Langerhans cells. Their normal function is to present antigens. The most common mutation is BRAF V600E gain-of-function mutation.

It is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions and can also infiltrate nearly every organ, like the skin (of the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system. 

Histopathologically, Langerhans cells have a single large nucleus with a characteristic folded or grooved nucleus giving a coffee-bean appearance. Birbeck granules are seen in the cytoplasm on electron microscopy. The tumour cells specifically express HLA-DR, S-100, and CD1a and langerin (CD207) markers.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with jerky movements of her extremities for the past 1 week. Her hands show a typical movement as shown in the image below. She also complains of pain in multiple joints. Physical examination is remarkable for jaundice. Which of the following is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with jaundice along with the clip showing a wing beating tremor is suggestive of Wilson's disease with decompensation. The gold standard for diagnosis is liver biopsy.

Wilsons disease is an autosomal-recessive disease, caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase. The characteristics features of wilsons disease include Hepatitis, cirrhosis, behavioral disturbances, wing beating tremor, sunflower cataract and KF rings.

The image below is that of a patient with a KF ring and a sunflower cataract:

Diagnosis:

  • Presence of KF rings
  • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
  • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy - Gold standard
  • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

Trientine and Zinc is the first choice of a drug regimen to be used for treating mild hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease.

Other options: 

Option b : Serum ferritin is not used to diagnose wilson disease but rather serum ceruloplasmin is used.

Option c : 24 hour urinary copper excretion is used for diagnosis of wilsons disease but it is not a gold standard investigation.

Option d : Genetic testing is an important part of diagnosis of wilson disease but is not an gold standard investigation. Detection of biallelic pathogenic variants in ATP7B is identified by molecular testing.

questions.text: Decrease in pH shifts the oxygen dissociation curve to_____

choices.text: On either side depending on other factors

questions.solution:
The pH decreasing from the normal value shifts the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve, to the right.

Oxygen-Hb dissociation curve (OHDC)

  • This is a plot of the partial pressure of O2 and the % saturation of Hb with O2.
  • It is normally sigmoid-shaped.
  • If OHDC is shifted to the right, it means that the affinity of Hb for O2 has become less (which favors O2 delivery) i.e. higher the P50 - Right shift Releases oxygen

Shift to the right is caused by: (Conditions with an increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat 
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis
  • Growth hormone, thyroid hormone, androgen - by increasing 2,3 DPG
  • Sickle cell anemia - reduced affinity for O2

Conditions that cause a left shift in the oxygen hemoglobin curve are:

  • Increased oxygen
  • Decreased carbon dioxide
  • Increased pH
  • Decreased temperature
  • Decreased 2,3-Biphosphoglycerate.
  • Fetal hemoglobin

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient in the post-operative ward becomes confused and drowsy and has one episode of vomiting post-thyroidectomy. On examination, she has a temperature of 100 degrees F along with tremors of the hand. Laboratory reports reveal elevated thyroid hormone levels. The best drug for the immediate management of this condition is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with features of fever, central nervous system depression, vomiting, and elevated thyroid hormones following surgery is suggestive of thyroid storm. Propylthiouracil, which inhibits thyroid synthesis and also inhibits peripheral conversion of T4 to T3, is the best drug for the immediate management of this case.

Thyroid storm/ Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is a rare but severe life-threatening complication of hyperthyroidism induced by the release of excessive thyroid hormones.

Causes:

  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Infection
  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy.
  • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
  • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Amiodarone administration
  • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
  • Following RAI (radioactive iodine) therapy

Features:

  • They present 12–24 hours after surgery with hyperpyrexia and severe dehydration
  • Cardiovascular: Circulatory collapse, hypotension, palpitations, tachycardia, cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac failure
  • GI symptoms: vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice.
  • Neurological symptoms: restlessness, irritability, delirium, tremor, convulsions, and coma 

Treatment:

  • Supportive measures – rehydration by proper fluid therapy, tepid sponging, cooling blankets
  • Thionamides like Propylthiouracil (PTU) or methimazole or carbimazole are used. They inhibit thyroid hormone synthesis. Propylthiouracil also inhibits the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. Hence, PTU is the preferred drug in thyroid storm. However, the risk for severe liver injury and acute liver failure associated with PTU therapy makes either carbimazole or methimazole the first choice thionamides in patients with deranged liver function tests.
  • Lugol’s iodide is given one hour after intake of thionamides. They inhibit thyroid hormone synthesis by Wolff- Chaikoff effect. Large doses of iodide inhibit the organic binding of the iodide and hence decrease thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • Propranolol is used to reduce tachycardia and other adrenergic manifestations. It also reduces the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.
  • Glucocorticoids – reduce the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 and controls the shock. 
  • Digoxin, cardiac monitoring is crucial.

*Note: As per the references, there are certain discrepancies over the drug of choice being an anti-thyroid drug (PTU) or a beta-blocker(Propranolol). However, as per the recent updates, PROPRANOLOL is primarily indicated in HYPERTHYROIDISM (not in thyroid crisis) because it has limited effect and slow onset for reducing serum T3 conversion. Additionally, in cases where deiodinase inhibition is significant (in cases of severe hyperthyroidism) like in THYROID CRISIS/ THYROTOXICOSIS an anti-thyroid drug is considered as the therapeutic drug (DOC), thus the answer to this MCQ is PTU and NOT PROPRANOLOL.

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Infection
  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy.
  • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
  • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Amiodarone administration or exposure to iodinated contrast agents
  • Following RAI therapy.

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Central nervous system agitation or depression
  • Cardiovascular and GI dysfunction, including hepatic failure
