questions.text: The empty delta sign is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The empty delta sign is a CT sign of cerebral venous thrombosis.

The 'empty delta' sign is a CT sign of dural venous sinus thrombosis of the superior sagittal sinus, where the thrombus becomes less dense and the contrast outlines a triangular filling defect (clot) within the sinus lumen. It is only described with contrast-enhanced CT-scan (CECT) or MRI with contrast (not with non-contrast CT(NCCT) or non-contrast MRI).

On doing an NCCT scan, an acutely thrombosed sinus appears hyperdense and expanded. This is called the 'delta sign'.

questions.text: A person working in an industry for a long time developed progressive breathlessness. The histopathological image of his lung biopsy is given below. Which industry was he most likely working in?
questions.solution:
From the clinical history of progressive breathlessness and the histopathological image showing asbestos bodies, ferruginous bodies, and fibrosis, the patient is most likely working in the asbestos industry.

Asbestosis occurs due to the inhalation of crystalline hydrated silicates (asbestos). It is characterized by diffuse parenchymal interstitial fibrosis. It usually begins in the lower lobes of the lungs and may present with dyspnoea and cough, usually after 20-30 years of exposure. Other asbestos-related diseases include pleural plaques, recurrent pleural effusions, lung carcinoma, and mesothelioma.

Asbestos bodies are a hallmark finding. They appear as golden brown, fusiform, or beaded rods. These are formed when the asbestos fibers are phagocytosed by the macrophages and are coated by iron-containing proteinaceous material derived from phagocyte ferritin. Similar iron-protein complexes coat other inorganic particulates other than asbestos which are termed as ferruginous bodies.

The image below shows asbestos bodies.

Other options:

Option A: Silicosis is due to the inhalation of crystalline silicon dioxide (silica) as seen in individuals employed in sandblasting or rock mining. Microscopy reveals coalescent nodules of whorled collagen fibers surrounded by a peripheral zone of silica-laden macrophages (shown below).

 

Option C: Anthracosis/coal workers' pneumoconiosis is a pulmonary condition seen in coal miners. Microscopic features consist of coal-laden macrophages, black pigment, and dense collagenous interstitial fibrosis. 

The image below shows anthracosis - black pigment engulfed within macrophages as well as in the form of deposits.

 

Option D: Cotton dust causes byssinosis and can induce occupational asthma.

questions.text: Failure to attend a summons from the court would be punishable under:
questions.solution:
Non-attendance a summons from the court is punishable with imprisonment of 6 months as per section 174 of IPC.

The punishment for IPC 174 is Simple Imprisonment for 1 Month or Fine or Both. It is a non-cognizable and bailable offense.

Section 175 of IPC: Omission to produce document(s) to public servant by person legally bound to produce it. Punishable with six months imprisonment.

Section 176 of IPC: Omission to give notice or information to public servant by a person legally bound to give it (imprisonment up to one month).

Section 177 of IPC: Furnishing false information is punishable with imprisonment of up to six months.

 

*Note: Section 172 of IPC: Absconding to avoid service of summons or other proceedings

questions.text: A newborn presents with hypoplasia of the mandibles and zygomatic bones, malformed external ears, and slanted palpebral fissures. An abnormality in the development of which pharyngeal arch is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Treacher Collins syndrome that results from abnormal development of the 1st pharyngeal arch (mandibular arch). 

First arch syndromes are congenital defects caused due to the failure of the neural crest cells to migrate into the 1st pharyngeal arch. They are:

Treacher Collins syndrome (mandibulofacial dysostosis) - Autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by:

  • Craniofacial bone defects - Involves mandible, maxilla, and zygomatic arches, causing micrognathia.
  • Ear defects - Involves the external ear, atresia of auditory canals, and abnormalities of the middle ear ossicles leading to bilateral conductive hearing loss
  • Eye defects - Down-slanting palpebral fissures and lower eyelid colobomas

Pierre Robin sequence (or Robin sequence) - Caused due to genetic defects or due to environmental factors. It can also be seen in oligohydramnios when the chin gets compressed against the chest in utero. 

  • It is characterized by a triad of micrognathia, glossoptosis (posteriorly placed tongue), and cleft palate.
  • The primary defect is poor growth of the mandible (micrognathia). As a consequence of this, the tongue is posteriorly placed (glossoptosis), Additionally, the tongue remains in between the palatal shelves and they fail to fuse (cleft palate)

questions.text: An HIV-positive female patient presents with acute rhinitis. On examination, a greyish membrane is seen in the nasal mucosa.  Exploration of the maxillary sinus reveals a fungus ball containing semisolid blackish material. Histopathological examination revealed dichotomous branching. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of aspergillosis. 

Aspergillus shows narrow, septate hyphae with typical dichotomous branching at acute angles (45°) on microscopy.

Clinical features of aspergillosis include acute/ subacute rhinitis or sinusitis. As given in the question stem, on examination black or greyish membrane would be seen in the nasal mucosa, and exploration of maxillary sinus would show a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material. The organisms can be seen on special staining for fungus.

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients. This can be due to prolonged treatment with steroids or retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs

The usual causative organisms are Aspergillus niger, Aspergillus fumigatus or Aspergillus flavus, which invade nasal tissues in any immunocompetent host.

Surgical debridement of the involved tissues and antifungal drugs, e.g. Amphotericin B. Repeated irrigation of the involved area with application of 1% solution of gentian violet is also useful.

Other options:

Option A: Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza.  It commonly occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus and immunocompromised individuals. Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis. The presenting features are facial pain, numbness, loosening of teeth, conjunctival swelling, congestion, and blurry vision. When the disease spreads to the orbit, proptosis can be present. It can later spread to the frontal lobe of the brain and cavernous sinus. The local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge is typically seen in invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discoloration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

Option C: Foreign body nose presents with foul-smelling unilateral discharge.

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. It presents as nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: The blood-testis barrier is formed by______

choices.text: Tight junctions between adjacent leydig cells
Tight junctions between adjacent sertoli cells

questions.solution:
The blood-testis barrier is formed by the tight junctions between adjacent Sertoli cells.

This Sertoli-Sertoli cell tight junctions divide the seminiferous epithelium into 2 compartments:

  • Basal compartment - contains the spermatogonia and early-stage primary spermatocytes.
  • Adluminal compartment - contains later-stage primary spermatocytes and all subsequent stages of sperm cells.

It imparts a selective permeability, allowing few substances such as testosterone to cross and preventing noxious substances that might damage the developing sperm. It also protects sperm from antibodies by creating a specialized, immunologically safe microenvironment for developing sperm.

 BELOW DIAGRAM - 

1- basal lamina, 2- spermatogonia, 3- 1st order spermatocyte, 4- 2nd order spermatocyte, 5- spermatid, 6 mature spermatids, 7 Sertoli cell, 8 tight junctions(Blood- Testis Barrier)

questions.text: An elderly man is diagnosed with a slow-growing tumor in the deep perineal pouch. Which of the following structures would most likely be affected?
questions.solution:
A tumor in the deep perineal space is most likely to affect the bulbourethral glands as they are present in the deep perineal pouch.

Contents of deep perineal pouch:

  • Membranous urethra
  • Muscles: Sphincter urethrae and deep transverse perineal muscles
  • Nerves: Dorsal nerve of penis and muscular branches of the perineal nerve
  • Vessels: Artery of penis
  • Glands: Bulbourethral glands in males

Contents of superficial perineal pouch: 

  • Corpora cavernosa and corpus spongiosum
  • Three muscles – the ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus, and superficial transverse perineal
  • The Bartholin’s glands (greater vestibular glands) in females and the duct of bulbourethral glands in males.
  • Arteries: Branches of the perineal artery (posterior scrotal and transverse perineal arteries) and branches of artery of the penis (artery to the bulb, urethral artery, deep artery of the penis, and dorsal artery of the penis)
  • Nerves: Long perineal nerve, branches of the perineal nerve (posterior scrotal, nerve to bulb and muscular branches)
  • Clitoris in female
  • Urethra in male

questions.text: A 32 year old male with a history of chronic smoking presents with the following picture.  He gives a history of pain in his fingers for a few months. Investigations showed blood glucose and lipid profile within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette and image suggest Buerger's disease or thromboangitis obliterans (TAO). 

A young male smoker, presenting with chronic pain, with no history of diabetes and hyperlipidemia and gangrenous ulcers as shown in the image are points in favor of Buerger's disease.

Buerger's disease is a nonatherosclerotic segmental inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder involving small and medium-sized arteries of the upper and lower limb.

It is predominantly seen in young male smokers. Patients mainly present with claudication pain of extremities and later with ischemic rest pain and ulcers. Atherogenic conditions like diabetes and dyslipidemia should be excluded.

The following criteria must be met for the diagnosis of TAO:

  • Age younger than 45 years
  • History of tobacco use
  • Distal extremity ischemia like claudication pain or ulcer
  • Autoimmune diseases, hypercoagulable state, dyslipidemia, and diabetes mellitus must be excluded
  • Consistent arteriographic findings in the limbs
  • A proximal source of atheroemboli must be excluded

Angiography shows segmental occlusions as skip lesions of the small and medium-sized vessels with the formation of extensive collaterals around the occlusions. These are called corkscrew collaterals. These represent dilated vasa vasorum of the occluded vessels. 

They may also present with pain, paraesthesia, and color changes of the digits of the hand and feet in response to cold and anxiety. This is called as Raynaud phenomenon. 

The image below shows the Raynaud phenomenon in the digits of the hand.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with miosis, ptosis, and anhydrosis on the left side along with dysphagia, and dysarthria, and frequently falls towards the left side while walking. On examination, he was found to have a loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the body and the left side of the face. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient having left-sided Horner's syndrome, dysphagia, dysarthria, ataxia towards left and right-sided loss of pain and temperature is left-sided Wallenberg’s syndrome.

Wallenberg’s syndrome, otherwise known as the lateral medullary syndrome, is a type of ischemic stroke of the brainstem. The symptoms and the corresponding tracts affected are shown below: 

Tract affected Symptoms
Descending tract and nucleus of CN V  Ipsilateral impaired sensation over half of the face
IX and X CN Ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord(dysarthria), diminished gag reflex causing dysphagia
The nucleus of tractus solitarius Ipsilateral loss of taste
Vestibular nucleus   Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
Spinocerebellar tract Ipsilateral ataxia
Descending sympathetic tract Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (characterized by miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis (decreased sweating)
Lateral spinothalamic tract  Impaired pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body

It can be caused by occlusion of vessels like the vertebral artery, posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), Superior, middle, or inferior lateral medullary arteries. The most commonly involved are the vertebral artery and PICA.

Other options:

Dejerine syndrome is otherwise known as medial medullary syndrome. It occurs due to occlusion of the vertebral artery or its branch. There is paralysis of the ipsilateral tongue (face is spared) and contralateral limbs, as well as impaired tactile and proprioceptive sense of the contralateral half of the body.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic presented with severe pain in ear and otorrhoea not responding to antibiotics. Facial nerve palsy is noted. On examination, granulation tissue is seen in the external auditory canal. What is the most common organism responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Elderly diabetic with severe otalgia, otorrhoea, granulation tissue in the external auditory canal and facial nerve palsy indicates malignant otitis externa. The most common causative agent remains Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa is associated with Pseudomonas infection in elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs. It is termed malignant, though being an infection due to the high mortality rate and poor response to treatment.

Patients present with excruciating pain, profuse discharge & granulations on the floor of EAC. Necrosis of bone aids in the spread of infection. Facial paralysis is common.  Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies.

Gallium-67 is more useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection, but the test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease. 

Treatment includes:

  • Diabetic control.
  • Ear toileting
  • Antibiotic treatment against the causative organism (P. aeruginosa) for 6–8 weeks or more.
Antibiotics found effective are:
  • Gentamicin combined with ticarcillin (intravenous).
  • Third-generation cephalosporins combined with an aminoglycoside (intravenous).
  • Quinolones combined with rifampin (oral). 
If the patient is not responsive, culture and sensitivity of ear discharge should be done. Prolonged antibiotic treatment has replaced radical surgery and resections done earlier for this condition.

questions.text: Which is the new online software launched under the national tuberculosis elimination program (NTEP) by the government to monitor TB patients?
questions.solution:
NIKSHAY is a web-based solution for monitoring TB patients. (The word is a combination of two Hindi words NI and KSHAY, meaning eradication of TB).

Nikshay is a web-based solution for monitoring TB patients to monitor the Revised National Tuberculosis Programme (RNTCP). This system stores information about the patient, medical history, diagnosis, co-morbidities and lab reports. 

The system has been developed jointly by the Central TB Division of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare and National Informatics Centre (NIC) and it was launched by the Government of India in June 2012. This is used by health functionaries at various levels across the country in association with Central TB Division (CTD), Ministry of Health & Family Welfare.

NIKSHAY covers various aspects of controlling TB using technological innovations.

Apart from web-based technology, SMS services have been used effectively for communication with patients and monitoring the program on a day-to-day basis.

Other options:

Option B: Nikusth is the new online software for monitoring leprosy patients.

Option C: Nischay is a pregnancy test kit.

Option D: Axshya is a project that works to improve access to quality TB care and control through a partnership between the government and civil society.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument
questions.solution:
The instrument shown is a harmonic scalpel. It is an instrument that uses ultrasonic energy to cut tissues while simultaneously coagulating them.

The scalpel vibrates in the 20000–50000 Hz range and cuts through tissues, achieving hemostasis by sealing vessels and tissues by means of protein denaturation using vibration rather than heat.

Cutting is a mode of diathermy/electrosurgery. The cut current is a low-voltage, continuous waveform. Cutting occurs when sufficient heat is applied to the tissue to cause cell water to explode into steam.

Coagulation is the sealing of blood vessels. In coagulation, a heating effect leads to cell death by dehydration and protein denaturation.

A blend is a combination of cutting and coagulation.

Other options:

Option B: LigaSure vessel sealing system (shown below) is a bipolar apparatus for sealing vascular tissue. It applies a high coaptive pressure during the generation of tissue temperature under 1000°C, hydrogen cross-links are first ruptured and then renatured, resulting in a vascular seal that has high tensile strength.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient developed fever, malaise, and anorexia a month after undergoing liver transplantation. On evaluation, he has leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and deranged liver function tests. Which of the following organisms is most likely to have caused this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of post-solid organ transplant infection most likely due to cytomegalovirus(CMV). It is the most common cause of post-solid organ transplants in India. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), herpes, and varicella are also known to cause infection post-solid organ transplantation but to a lesser extent.

CMV disease in recipients can present with fever, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, malaise, and arthralgia. They usually present within 1-4 months after transplant. The diagnosis of CMV infection is established by nucleic acid testing (NAT) using the polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

Management includes the use of anti-viral drugs like ganciclovir, valganciclovir, foscarnet, cidofovir and intravenous immunoglobulins.

questions.text: The maternal mortality rate is expressed as "number of maternal deaths in a given period per ____ during the same time period".
questions.solution:
The maternal mortality rate is expressed as the "number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 women in reproductive age during the same time period".

Note: The maternal mortality ratio is expressed as the "number of maternal deaths during a given period per 100,000 live births during the same time period".

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy was brought to the psychiatrist by his parents. The parents reported that the child frequently lies at home and in school, misbehaves with the teacher, often bullies the younger kids, and has been caught stealing money on multiple occasions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this boy is conduct disorder.

Conduct disorder is diagnosed when at least 3 characteristic behaviors have been present within the previous 12 months, with at least 1 present in the past 6 months.

The onset of Conduct Disorder:

  • Childhood-onset type: Individuals show at least one symptom characteristic of conduct disorder before the age of 10 years.
  • Adolescent-onset type: Individuals show no symptom characteristic of conduct disorder before the age of 10 years.
  • Unspecified onset: Criteria for a diagnosis of conduct disorder are met, but there is not enough information available to determine whether the onset of the first symptom was before or after the age of 10 years.
DSM-5 criteria for Conduct Disorder  
Aggression towards people and animals

Initiating physical fights, bullying, threatening, or intimidating others

Using a weapon to cause serious harm to others

Being physically cruel to people

Being physically cruel to animals

Stealing while confronting a victim

Forcing someone into sexual activity
Destruction of property

Setting fires

Intentionally destroying the property of others
Serious violation of rules

Running away overnight at least twice or once without returning for a lengthy period.

Being truant from school often starting before age 13.

Frequently staying out at night despite parental prohibitions starting before age 13
Deceitfulness or theft

Frequently lying to obtain goods or favors

Breaking into a car or building

Stealing items of nontrivial value without confronting a victim

Other options:

: Oppositional defiant disorder(ODD):

  • Persistent pattern, lasting at least 6 months, of negativistic, hostile, and defiant attitude/behavior towards adults, including arguments, temper outbursts, vindictiveness, and deliberate annoyance.
  • Seen in children less than 10 years of age.
  • The symptoms must be present for 6 months, during which 4 or more of the following have to be present:
    • Argues with others
    • Loses temper
    • Blames others
    • Easily annoyed
    • Refuses and defies listening to adults

NOTE: Unlike conduct disorder, children with ODD do not indulge in destructive and physically harmful activities.

Option C: If conduct disorder persists beyond 18 years of age the child is diagnosed with an antisocial personality disorder.

Option D: In disruptive mood dysregulation disorder the child presents with severe, recurrent temper outbursts out of proportion to the situation. The child is constantly angry and irritable between outbreaks. Onset is before 10 years of age.

questions.text: All are features of paralytic ileus except______
questions.solution:
Paralytic ileus is an adynamic obstruction in which there is a failure of transmission of peristaltic waves secondary to neuromuscular failure (i.e., in the myenteric [Auerbach’s] and submucous [Meissner’s] plexuses). Since there are no rigorous contractions, there is no colicky pain.

Clinical features :

The resultant stasis leads to the following:

  • Accumulation of fluid and gas in the bowel
  • With associated distension: marked and tympanitic
  • Vomiting (effortless)
  • Absence of bowel sounds
  • Absolute constipation.
  • Paralytic ileus takes on clinical significance if any of the following are observed at 72 hours after laparotomy:
    • No return of bowel sounds on auscultation
    • No passage of flatus
  • Colicky pain is not a feature.
  • Radiologically, the abdomen shows gas-filled loops of the intestine with multiple fluid levels (if an erect film is felt necessary).

Treatment:

  • Paralytic ileus is managed with the use of nasogastric suction and restriction of oral intake until bowel sounds and the passage of flatus return.
  • Electrolyte balance must be maintained.

questions.text: A child presents with the complaint of perianal itching which occurs predominantly at night and disturbs sleep. The eggs of the causative organism have been shown in the following image. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing plano-convex eggs containing a tadpole-shaped embryo is suggestive of Enterobius vermicularis or pinworm infection.

Infection with Enterobius vermicularis presents with perianal or perineal pruritus and restless sleep (due to nocturnal pruritus).

Plano-convex eggs containing a tadpole-shaped embryo, are deposited by the gravid female worm on perianal skin which causes pruritis.

Since pinworms are not released in feces, the diagnosis cannot be made by conventional fecal ova and parasite tests. NIH swab method and Scotch tape method are used for the collection of specimens. 

The image given below shows the NIH swab.

Treatment: 

  • Albendazole 400 mg PO with a repeat dose 2 weeks
  • Frequent changing of underclothes, bedclothes, and bedsheets decreases environmental egg contamination and may decrease the risk for autoinfection.
  • Good hand hygiene is the most effective method of prevention.
The image given below shows the life cycle of Enterobius vermicularis.

questions.text:
A young male patient presents with breathlessness. Further questioning reveals that he had a panic attack an hour ago and has been breathless since. An arterial blood gas analysis (ABG) sample was taken and the values are given below. What is the interpretation?

pH: 7.50

HCO3: 22mEq/L

pCO2: 31 mm Hg.

pO2: 75 mm Hg.
questions.solution:
The correct interpretation of the acid-base abnormality in this patient who has been hyperventilating since morning would be respiratory alkalosis. 

In the given question,

pH is increased (normal pH - 7.35 to 7.45 )

pCO2 is decreased (normal pCO2 - 35 to 45 mm Hg)

HCO3- is normal (normal HCO3-  22 mEq/L to 28 mEq/L)

During panic attacks, there is alveolar hyperventilation. This leads to decreased PaCO2 and increased pH. If hypocapnia persists for more than 2-6 hours, then there would be a further decrease in renal filtered HCO3- reabsorption, and a decrease in renal ammonium and titrable acid excretion. 

Respiratory alkalosis leads to decreased blood flow, further resulting in dizziness, mental confusion, and seizures. This may occur in the absence of hypoxemia. Respiratory alkalosis may be seen in critically ill patients and before the onset of rapid respiratory failure. 

Other options:

Option B. In respiratory acidosis, the pH is decreased while pCO2 is increased. 

Option C. In metabolic acidosis, pH and HCO3- are decreased. 

Option D. The given values are not that of a normal ABG. Normal ABG values are as follows: 

pH - 7.35 - 7.45

PaO2 - 75 - 100 mmHg

PaCO2 - 35 - 45 mmHg

HCO3- - 22-26 mEq/L

questions.text: A truck driver came with complaints of a painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. He is suspected to have a hard chancre. Motility of the most likely causative organism can be detected by which of the following microscopes?
questions.solution:
Hard chancre / syphilitic chancre is caused by Treponema pallidum. The motility of the organism can be demonstrated by dark ground/ field microscopy. 

Dark ground microscopy can be used to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present to visualize Treponema pallidum. Dark-field microscopy images have a dark background with a refractile organism. The dark ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies. It is generally less sensitive.

The image given below shows Treponema pallidum demonstrated by dark ground microscopy.

Various types of Spirochetes and their appearances under a dark ground microscope:

  • Treponemes generally are short and slender with regular and sharp spirals.
  • Leptospira have a large number of closely wound spirals and characteristic hooked ends.
  • Borrelia is large with irregular and wide open coils.

 

Other options:

Option B: Electron microscopy is not commonly used for diagnostics in laboratories. It generally helps in appreciating viral structures. 

Option C: Light microscopes are commonly used in the labs to visualize the stained smears of various bacteria, and fungi in 100x magnification. They are also used during the examination of stool specimens for identifying ova, eggs, or larvae.

Option D: A fluorescent microscope uses fluorescent dyes like auramine-rhodamine to appreciate Mycobacterial species and malarial parasites.

questions.text: A young patient presented with neck swelling which moves with deglutition as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, thyroglossal cyst is the only neck swelling which moves with deglutition. This is because the thyroid gland is fixed to the hyoid. 

The hyoid bone would not be formed during the time of descent of thyroid gland. Hence, thyroglossal duct passes in front, through or behind the eventual position of hyoid body.

Other neck swellings that move with deglutition are:

  • Thyroid swellings
  • Subhyoid bursitis 
  • Dermoid cysts attached to the hyoid bone

However, only the thyroglossal cyst moves with tongue protrusion. This is because the duct extends from the foramen caecum of tongue to the isthmus of the gland. 

Sistrunk’s operation is performed to excise the cyst and prevent a recurrence. It involves excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, involving removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum along with the core of tissue on either side.

questions.text: Which of the following primitive reflexes would persist throughout life?
questions.solution:
The parachute reflex persists throughout life.

The parachute reflex is a primitive reflex. It is elicited by holding the infant's trunk and then suddenly lowering them as if they were falling. This will cause the infant's arms to extend in order to break the fall. Thus, it is a prerequisite for walking. The onset of this reflex is at 7-8 months of age, it fully develops by 10-11 months and persists for life. 

Primitive reflexes appear and disappear at specific times during a child's development. Any persistence or absence of these reflexes is significant for central nervous system dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding early dumping syndrome?

choices.text: Intractable dumping can be managed with Octreotide
It is relieved by lying down.

questions.solution:
Hypoglycemia​ does not occur in early dumping syndrome. It is seen in late dumping syndrome secondary to raised insulin levels.

Dumping syndromes are disorders characterized by rapid gastric emptying. Though early and late dumping syndromes are due to different etiologies, they are considered together because of this common feature.

Early dumping syndrome is due to the high osmotic load that reaches the small bowel, leading to the sequestration of fluid from circulation into the gastrointestinal tract (GIT). It occurs as a sequela of gastrectomy or vagotomy and drainage. The principal treatment is dietary manipulation. Patients who suffer from intractable dumping syndrome are managed with somatostatin analogs such as Octreotide.

Late dumping syndrome is due to the high carbohydrate load in the small intestine, which causes an increase in insulin levels and secondary hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 5-month-old girl child was brought to the clinic with a failure to thrive. On examination,  generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly were present. Microscopy of a muscle biopsy shows vacuolations. The chest radiograph of the infant is shown below.  Which enzyme is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario given and the radiograph showing cardiomegaly are suggestive of Pompe's disease. This disease results from a deficiency in the enzyme acid maltase.

Pompe's disease (type 2 glycogen storage disease) is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiency. It causes lysosomal glycogen accumulation in cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells.

The clinical symptoms of Pompe disease include hypotonia leading to floppy infant, skeletal muscle weakness, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, macroglossia, and chest X-ray image showing cardiomegaly. 

Laboratory findings will show elevated levels of serum creatine kinase (CK), aspartate transaminase (AST), alanine transaminase (ALT), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). 

Muscle biopsy shows the presence of vacuoles that stain positively for glycogen as shown below.

Treatment includes enzyme replacement therapy with recombinant enzyme a-glucosidase alfa (Myozyme).

questions.text: A 25 year old man presents to the clinic with hair loss. He gives a history of being on a highly restrictive diet (one that does not meet his daily protein requirements) and sudden weight loss for the last 4 months. What is the clinical diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
This male most probably has telogen efflivium. This male had sudden weight loss with protein deficit, which could have acted as a trigger for this condition.

Telogen effluvium describes an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to premature termination of the anagen phase of the hair cycle following a period of stress.

Acute telogen effluvium is an acute-onset scalp hair loss that occurs 2–3 months after a triggering event such as high fever, surgical trauma, sudden weight loss/starvation or haemorrhage.

Chronic diffuse telogen hair loss refers to telogen hair shedding persisting for longer than 6 months. Causes of chronic diffuse telogen hair loss are thyroid disorders, profound iron deficiency anaemia, acroder­matitis enteropathica, and malnutrition. Both hyper- and hypo­thyroidism (including drug-induced hypothyroidism) may cause a diffuse telogen hair loss.

Telogen gravidarum refers to telogen hair loss seen 2–3 months after childbirth.

Option A: Alopecia areata is a common, chronic, inflammatory disease that causes non‐scarring hair loss. Alopecia areata is associated with several autoimmune diseases including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo and psoriasis.

Option B: Androgenetic alopecia is a permanent hair loss from the scalp, causing baldness, and have a common genetic cause. Hair loss typically occurs on the top and front of the head. It occurs progressively, unlike seen here. 

Option D: Anagen effluvium is a type of alopecia, which is the sudden loss of anagen (actively growing) hair, usually occuring post chemotherapy.

questions.text: Read the pedigree chart and identify the pattern of transmission.
questions.solution:
The pattern of inheritance shown in the image is X linked recessive pattern of inheritance.

Clues for diagnosis of the pattern of inheritance as X-linked recessive:

  • Males are affected and females are carriers.
  • No male-to-male transmission. Females transmit the disease.
  • Females transmit the mutated genes to 50% of the males.
  • Affected males have carrier daughters and unaffected sons.

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

 

Autosomal Dominant Disorders:

  • With every autosomal dominant disorder, some patients do not have affected parents. Such patients owe their disorder to new mutations involving either the egg or the sperm from which they were derived.
  • Clinical features can be modified by variations in penetrance and expressivity.
  • In many conditions, the age at onset is delayed, and symptoms and signs may not appear until adulthood (as in Huntington disease).

X-linked Recessive Conditions:

  • All sex-linked disorders are X-linked, and almost all are recessive.
  • Several genes are located in the “male-specific region of Y;” all these are related to spermatogenesis.
  • Males with mutations affecting the Y-linked genes are usually infertile, and hence, there is no Y-linked inheritance.
  • An affected male does not transmit the disorder to his sons, but all daughters are carriers.
  • Sons of heterozygous women have, of course, a one-in-two chance of receiving the mutant gene.
  • Heterozygous females express the disorder partially because of random inactivation of one X chromosome.

questions.text:
A biochemistry resident plots a graph while studying the effect of an inhibitor on an enzymatic reaction. Which of the following statements is false, with respect to the following graph that he has plotted?

Km: The substrate concentration at which velocity is half the maximum.

Vmax: The maximum velocity of a reaction.

v0: Reaction velocity

[S]: Substrate concentration

choices.text: Reaction is with a non-competitive inhibitor
Inhibitor binds to the enzyme in location other than the active site
Vmax decreases and Km is unchanged
Can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration

questions.solution:
The given graph represents a reaction with a non-competitive inhibitor and it cannot be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate.

The above graph is called the 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot. 1/v0 is plotted versus 1/[S] and a straight line is obtained. This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors.

In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases (or 1/Vmax increases) but Km is unchanged. Hence the graphs of inhibited and uninhibited reactions have the same x-intercepts (converge at -1/Km) but different y-intercepts.

In contrast to competitive inhibitors, noncompetitive inhibitors bind to enzymes in locations away from the active site. For this reason, the degree of inhibition is based solely upon the concentration of the inhibitor, and increasing the substrate concentrations does not compete with or change the inhibition. Therefore, unlike the increase in Km seen with competitive inhibition, in noncompetitive inhibition, Vmax decreases while Km usually remains the same. While competitive inhibitors can be overcome at a sufficiently high substrate concentration (i.e, reversible), non-competitive inhibition is irreversible and cannot be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

questions.text: During your rotation in the postnatal ward, a concerned mother asks you the period by which her newborn infant should have passed urine. The baby was delivered at term gestation and her pregnancy was uneventful. You reassure her by saying that her child should urinate at least once within a period of ______
questions.solution:
The child should urinate at least once within a period of 24 hours after birth.

It is estimated that almost all healthy premature, term, and post-term infants pass urine within the first 24 hours after birth. Failure to pass urine within this period warrants further evaluation.

Anuria is defined as an absence of urine output 48 hours after birth and is a feature of underlying renal failure or acute kidney injury.

The following conditions predispose to neonatal renal failure:

  • Low birth weight infants
  • Infants post congenital heart surgery
  • Infants on extracorporeal membrane oxygenation

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Fuller’s tracheostomy tube.

It consists of an outer tube and an inner tube, the latter being slightly longer. Outer tube is made of two blades, which when pressed together, can be easily introduced into the tracheostomy opening. Inner tube has a hole in the centre so that patient can still have a chance to breathe from the larynx even when tube is blocked at its outer end.

Other options:

Option A: Cuffed tracheostomy tube:

Option B: Laryngeal mask airway

Option D: Jackson’s tracheostomy tube:

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: An insured 35-year-old woman, who is working in a newspaper establishment, is undergoing a tubectomy procedure. According to the Employees State Insurance Act, she would receive the cash benefit under ____.
questions.solution:
Insured persons in the reproductive age group undergoing sterilization procedures such as tubectomy and vasectomy are offered cash benefit under the ESI Act as enhanced sickness benefit. 

The enhanced sickness benefit equal to full wage is payable to insured persons undergoing sterilization. 7 days for male workers, post-vasectomy, and 14 days for female workers, post-tubectomy.

Other options: 

Option B: Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.

Option C: Maternity Benefit – the benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman

Option D: Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: An elderly man was caught peeping into a bathroom window and watching a girl disrobe. During his psychiatric evaluation, he confessed that he attains sexual gratification when he watches people naked or while they are engaged in any sexual activity without their knowledge. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
Attaining sexual gratification after observing someone naked or engaged in sexual activity is called voyeurism. 

Voyeurism is also called scopophilia. It is more common in men. The voyeuristic act may be accompanied by masturbation. 

Paraphilias (perversions) are sexual stimuli or acts that are considered deviations from normal sexual behaviors. These are necessary for some people to experience arousal and orgasm. Individuals with paraphilias do not experience sexual pleasure through stimuli that are considered normal.

Other options:

Option A: In transvestism there is a sexual urge to dress in opposite-gender clothing as a means of arousal. It is diagnosed when these fantasies have been acted upon for at least six months. 

Option B: Coprophilia is attaining sexual pleasure by defecating on the partner or by being defecated on. An urge to eat feces (coprophagia) may also be seen. 

Option D: Frotteurism is characterized by the rubbing of genitals against the buttocks or any other parts of the body of a woman who is fully clothed. This is done to achieve an orgasm and usually occurs in crowded places.

*Note: Exhibitionism is characterized by a recurrent urge to expose the genitals to strangers. The anticipation of the exposure results in sexual excitement and orgasm.

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13
years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a nonconsenting person

questions.text:
An obese and diabetic man presented with the lesions as shown below over his abdomen. On examination, he had diastolic hypertension. 24-hour urinary-free cortisol was increased. ACTH levels were high. What is the likely diagnosis?

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an obese, diabetic man with the image showing purple striae, diastolic hypertension, increased 24-hour urinary cortisol levels, and high levels of ACTH. So the likely diagnosis is Cushing's syndrome. 

Cushing's syndrome is a group of clinical features that occur due to chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids of any etiology. Cushing's disease is specifically Cushing's syndrome that occurs due to pituitary corticotrope adenoma. 

Typical features include

System Clinical features
Body fat
  • Central or truncal obesity (most common)
  • Buffalo hump (fat deposition behind the neck)
  • Moon facies  
Skin
  • Purple striae (over abdomen & flanks)
  • Acne and Hirsutism 
  • Easy bruising 
  • Facial plethora
  • Hyperpigmentation 
Musculoskeletal
  • Proximal myopathy
  • Osteoporosis
Metabolic
  • Poorly controlled hyperglycemia
  • Dyslipidemia
Reproductive
  • Low libido
  • Amenorrhea
Renal
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
CVS
  • Atherosclerosis 
  • Diastolic hypertension 
  • Edema 
Hematologic
  • Hypercoagulable state 
  • Neutrophilia
  • Eosinopenia
CNS
  • Depression, anxiety
  • Psychosis 
  • Irritability

 

Management of Cushing's syndrome includes

  • Surgical removal of the tumor followed by hydrocortisone replacement with gradual tapering is preferred.
  • Medical management includes metyrapone and ketoconazole. 

Other options:

Option A: Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency in which the adrenal is unable to secrete adequate amounts of cortisol (glucocorticoid), and aldosterone (mineralocorticoid). The features are fatigue, weight loss, anorexia, low blood pressure, postural hypotension, hypoglycemia, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, salt craving, hyponatremia and hyperkalemia.

Option B: Adrenal crisis or acute adrenal insufficiency is an emergency usually occurring in patients with primary adrenal insufficiency. It is triggered by conditions like intercurrent illness and stress. The features include hypovolemic shock, acute abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, decreased responsiveness, stupor and coma.

Option C: Conn's syndrome or primary aldosteronism occurs due to aldosterone secreting adrenal adenoma leading to mineralocorticoid excess. It is characterized by hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, muscle weakness, proximal myopathy and muscle cramps.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Iatrogenic (Most common cause)

  • Exogenous administration of glucocorticoids

Endogenous Causes

  • ACTH Dependent – (90 % of endogenous causes)
  • Cushing’s disease – ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma
  • Ectopic ACTH syndrome – Due to ACTH secretion by
  • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
  • Small-cell lung cancer
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • ACTH Independent – (10% )
  • Adrenocortical adenoma
  • Adrenocortical carcinoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: The finding shown in the image below is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The image shows a chocolate cyst, which is seen in ovarian endometriosis.

The cysts form secondary to endometriotic implants in the ovarian stroma that bleed periodically and undergo shedding.

Spontaneous cyst rupture, with the release of thick, tarry brownish fluid, can lead to acute peritonitis, and this may be mistaken for a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, appendicitis, diverticulitis, or torsion of a tumor.

Endometriosis is a condition that is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue in ectopic sites such as:

  • Ovary (chocolate cysts)- left/right lower quadrant pain
  • Pouch of Douglas - pain during defecation
  • Uterosacral ligaments - chronic pelvic pain & infertility
  • Appendix - right lower quadrant pain.
  • Lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) scar endometriosis
  • Umbilicus
  • Lung - cyclical hemoptysis.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A postmenopausal woman presents with episodes of a sudden sensation of intense heat involving the face and upper chest which rapidly spreads across the entire body. The episodes last about 2-4 minutes and are associated with profuse sweating, palpitations, and anxiety. What is the most effective treatment for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of vasomotor symptoms (hot flushes) in a postmenopausal woman. Estrogen therapy is found to be the most effective to treat it.

Hot flushes are episodes of vasodilation affecting the face and the neck. The episode lasts for 2–5 min each. These are followed by severe sweating, palpitations, anxiety, and anginal pains may be felt. Multiple episodes occur during the day, but are more severe at night and can disturb sleep. Sometimes they can be preceded by headaches.

Hormone therapy in postmenopausal women is only indicated for the treatment of:

  • vasomotor symptoms
  • osteoporosis (prevention and treatment)
  • vaginal atrophy
  • urethral syndrome
  • dyspareunia

Estrogen can be given as oral estrogen formulations, transdermal patches, topical gel, or intravaginal formulations. For Dyspareunia, urethral syndrome, and senile vaginitis local estrogen cream is preferred over oral therapy. Short-term therapy is recommended for vasomotor symptoms whereas osteoporosis requires long-term therapy. Estrogen should be given in the smallest effective dose for the shortest duration possible. 

 Other treatments: 

Hormonal Non-Hormonal Non-prescriptive

Estrogen therapy (Most effective)

Progestin

Combination preparations

Tibolone

Clonidine 

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (like Fluoxetine)

selective norepinephrine- reuptake inhibitor(like desvenlafaxine)

Gabapentin

Vitamin E

Soya 

Isoflavones

Contraindications of HRT:

  • Undiagnosed abnormal genital bleeding
  • Known, suspected, or history of breast cancer
  • Known or suspected estrogen-dependent neoplasia
  • Active or prior venous thromboembolism
  • Active or recent (e.g., within the past year) arterial thromboembolic disease
  • Liver dysfunction or gall bladder disease
  • Known hypersensitivity to the ingredients of the estrogen preparation
  • Known or suspected pregnancy
  • Uterine fibroids as these may enlarge in size.

For women with a uterus, it is recommended to add micronized progesterone to prevent endometrial hyperplasia which can occur after 6 months of estrogen therapy. For women without uterus just estrogen therapy is sufficient.

questions.text: Which of the following provides long-lasting results in a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG)?
questions.solution:
The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) provides long-lasting results in a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG). The most important criterion in conduit selection is graft patency. The conduit with the highest patency rate is the left internal mammary artery or internal thoracic artery.

Left internal mammary artery > Radial artery > long saphenous vein represents the correct order of graft patency in a patient undergoing a CABG procedure.

Venous grafts:

  • The long saphenous vein is the most common vein used as a conduit as it is straightforward to harvest, provides good length, and is easy to handle.
  • The ten-year patency rate for long saphenous vein grafts is reported to be 50–60 percent.

Arterial grafts:

  • The Left internal mammary artery (LIMA) or internal thoracic artery has become the conduit of choice for the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. The radial artery can be used as a second or alternative arterial bypass graft. Other arterial bypass grafts include the gastroepiploic artery and the inferior epigastric artery.
  • Long patency rates of >98 percent have been reported.

questions.text: Which of the following indicators is used to calculate both Human Development Index (HDI) and Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI), according to WHO?
questions.solution:
Literacy is used in the measurement of both HDI and PQLI.

The components of the Human Development Index (HDI) include life expectancy at birth, literacy, and standard of living.

Human Development Index (HDI) is a measure of a country's average achievements in three dimensions of human development:

  • A long and healthy life, as measured by life expectancy at birth
  • Knowledge (literacy), as measured by mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling, and
  • A decent standard of living, as measured by GNI (gross national income) per capita

HDI values range from 0 to 1, with 1 as the maximum value.

Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy, and infant mortality rate are components of the Physical quality of life index (PQLI).

Related Pearl: HDI vs. PQLI

 

Human Development Index

[HDI]

Physical Quality of Life Index [PQLI]

Components

1.   Longevity (Life expectancy at birth)

2.  A decent standard of living (Real GNI per capita in PPP US$)

3.      Knowledge (Mean years of schooling; Expected years of schooling)

 

1.      Life expectancy at 1 year of age

 

2.      Infant Mortality rate

 

3.      Literacy rate

Range

0 to +1

0 to 100

 India currently ranks 132 (HDI is 0.633) on the 2021-2022 Human developmental Index.

questions.text: What parameter does the yellow color tracing on the monitor shown below represent?
questions.solution:
The yellow color tracing shown in the monitor is capnography.

Waveform capnography is a continuous non-invasive measurement and graphical display of the EtCO2. 

It is a direct measure of lung ventilation and an indirect measure of circulation and metabolism. 

The normal capnograph displays the exhaled CO2 in both the inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components:
  • Phase I: exhalation of dead space gas (i.e., partial pressure of CO2, pCO2 ∼0).
  • Phase II: A sharp rise in pCO2 to a plateau indicates the sampling of transitional gas between the airways and alveoli. 
  • Phase III: The plateau region of the capnograph, corresponds to the pCO2 in the alveolar compartment. 
  • Following phase III, a sharp inspiratory downstroke occurs, which is referred to as the beginning of phase 0 or phase IV.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: An 8-month-old child with acute diarrhea is being treated with oral rehydration solution (ORS).  Which of the following is correct regarding zinc supplementation in this child?
questions.solution:
An 8-month-old child being treated for acute diarrhea should be supplemented with oral zinc at 20 mg/day for 10-14 days.

Zinc administration for diarrhea management can significantly reduce mortality and hospital admission. In addition, it improves diarrhea recovery rates and reduces the inappropriate use of antimicrobials.

Zinc supplementation is usually done for 10 to 14 days. The dosage is age-dependent as follows:

Age <6 months: 10 mg/day

Age >6 months:  20 mg/day

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: A 7-day-old neonate is brought with failure to pass meconium since birth. The baby's abdomen is markedly distended and he aspirates on feeding. Rectal suction biopsy shows a lot of hypertrophied nerve bundles with increased acetylcholinesterase staining and aganglionosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of failure to pass meconium and a markedly distended abdomen along with a biopsy showing aganglionosis suggests a likely diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease/congenital aganglionic megacolon.

Hirschsprung disease is a developmental disorder of the enteric nervous system. Normally, the enteric neuronal plexus develops by neural crest cells migrating to the colon wall. When there is a mutation in tyrosine kinase receptor RET, it results in premature arrest of this regular migration from the cecum to the rectum. This results in the lack of Auerbach and Meissner submucosal plexus in the distal intestinal segment (aganglionosis) causing hypertonicity of the bowel wall. Thus, there is a functional obstruction in the distal segment that also results in massive dilatation of the proximal segment (megacolon). 

      Based on the segments affected, they are classified into -

  • Short-segment Hirschsprung disease - Disease limited to the rectosigmoid segment
  • Long-segment Hirschsprung disease - Disease having proximal extension beyond the rectosigmoid segment

The onset of constipation can be seen at birth. Patients present with intermittent attacks of fever and pain due to intestinal obstruction from the retained feces. Complications include enterocolitis and bowel perforation. 

A rectal suction biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis and shows increased acetylcholinesterase staining and aganglionosis. Other investigations include anorectal manometry and barium contrast enema. 

Surgical intervention is the only definitive treatment available.

Other options:

Option B: Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis generally presents as new-onset regurgitation and projectile non-bilious vomiting after feeding. A firm abdominal mass and abnormal left-to-right hyperperistalsis can be seen. Diagnosis is made by ultrasonography. 

Option C: Wilkie syndrome, otherwise known as superior mesenteric artery syndrome, occurs due to the compression of the third duodenal segment against the aorta by this artery. Diagnosis is by radiological demonstration of duodenal cutoff along with proximal duodenal dilatation. 

Option D: Functional constipation, otherwise known as fecal withholding, is the intentional or subconscious withholding of stool. It usually starts after the neonatal period. Here daytime encopresis (passage of stools at inappropriate places after 4 years of age) is common.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

questions.text: A 34-year-old male was diagnosed with a urogenital tumor. History revealed that the patient had cryptorchidism in his childhood. Which of the following tumors is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The commonest cancer in patients who had cryptorchidism is seminoma.

The cancer risk for adults after cryptorchidism in childhood is 5–10 times greater than normal. The most common cancer is seminoma.

Seminoma:

  • It is the most common type of GCT (~50% of GCTs). The peak incidence is seen in the fourth decade.
  • It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma, or the pineal gland tumor termed germinoma.
  • Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and podoplanin and negative for cytokeratin.

The gross specimen shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis.

The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance). The sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate.

Other options:
Option B: Leydig cell tumors are sex-cord stromal cell tumors of the testis. They predominantly secrete androgens and in some cases estrogen and corticosteroids as well. The most common presenting features in prepubertal children are painless testicular swelling and precocious puberty. 
Option C: Sertoli cell tumors are sex-cord stromal cell tumors of the testis. They are usually hormonally inactive and present only as a painless testicular mass. It is associated with Carneys complex, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, and familial adenomatosis polyposis syndrome.
Option D: Teratoma can be seen in infants and children after yolk sac tumors. It consists of derivatives of all three germ layers. It includes islands of bronchial epithelium, neural tissue, muscle, islands of cartilage, clusters of squamous epithelium, etc. 

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a gradual loss of visual acuity in the left eye. Her MRI head is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and MRI showing tram track sign is suggestive of optic nerve meningioma.

Primary optic nerve meningioma arises from the arachnoid sheath of the optic nerve. CT or MRI shows tram track sign. It is defined as the relative hypoattenuation of the optic nerve on CT or reduced signal on post-gadolinium MRI due to peripheral enhancement of the tumor around the nerve.

 

*Note - Tram track sign refers to the appearance of parallel line lesions and is seen in the following conditions:

  • Tram track sign in the brain is suggestive of Sturge-Weber syndrome
  • Tram track sign in the orbit is suggestive of optic nerve meningioma
  • Tram track sign on microscopy in nephrology is suggestive of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Tram track sign in pulmonology is seen in bronchiectasis

questions.text: A physiologist studies about the sensor which detects elevated sodium and decreases the glomerular filtration rate. In the given image of the juxtaglomerular apparatus, which of the following structures acts as this sensor?
questions.solution:
The structure marked '1' is the macula densa cells in the distal convoluted tubule and they are involved in detecting elevated sodium levels and thereby decreasing the glomerular filtration rate

The given image constitutes the juxtaglomerular apparatus and has the following parts:

  • Macula densa: Specialized cells at the start of Distal Convoluted Tubule form the macula densa. They detect sodium and chloride concentrations of the fluid in the tubule (Chemoreceptor). In response to elevated sodium and chloride, the macula densa cells trigger the contraction of the afferent arteriole, reducing the flow of blood to the glomerulus and the glomerular filtration rate. This happens as follows: When there is increased sodium, there is increased sodium-potassium ATPase activity which leads to increased ATP hydrolysis causing more adenosine formation. The adenosine receptors on the macula densa cells stimulate it to release more calcium, so that there is vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole, thereby decreasing the GFR.
  • Granular cells/JG cells: Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole, they secrete renin. Fall in pressure in afferent arteriole stimulates renin release (mechanoreceptor), which, in turn, increases blood pressure. They are denoted by '2' in the given image.
  • Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole. They are marked as '3' in the given image.
    The structure marked as '4' in the given image is the proximal tubular cell. It is involved in the process of glomerulotubular balance. 

When an increase in the GFR occurs, there is a consequential increase in the reabsorption of the solutes and water in the proximal convoluted tubule. This process is called the glomerulotubular balance and it keeps the percentage of the reabsorbed solutes at constant levels.

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing data on some volunteers in a gym. Which of the following statements is true in these volunteers regarding their respiratory adjustment?

choices.text: Activity of joint proprioceptors is important factor in increasing ventilation
Arterio-venous difference in oxygen concentration remains constant

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding respiratory adjustment is that signals from joint proprioceptors play a role in stimulating the respiratory drive during exercise.

Regulation of respiration in exercise

  • During strenuous exercise, O2 consumption and CO2 for­mation can increase as much as 20-fold. Yet in the healthy athlete, the arterial PO2, PCO2, and pH remain almost exactly normal. This is because alveolar ventilation increases along with the increased level of oxygen metabolism.
  • Part of this stimulation of alveolar ventilation results from direct stimulation of the respiratory centre by nervous signals. An additional part is believed to result from sensory signals transmitted into the respiratory centre from the contracting muscles and joint proprioceptors.
  • During strenuous exercise, the utilization of O2 in the entire body can increase by 75%-85%. So, more oxygen is extracted from the arterioles leaving less O2 in the venules. This leads to an increased arterio-venous difference in oxygen concentration.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cell-cycle specific agent?
questions.solution:
Vinblastine is a cell cycle-specific agent and a vinca alkaloid. It arrests mitosis and acts specifically on M-phase.

Vinca alkaloids are a group of drugs obtains from the periwinkle plant. These drugs exert their action by disrupting microtubular function which in turn leads to the arrest of the cell cycle at metaphase.

Vinca alkaloids such as vinblastine are an essential component of chemotherapy regimens for testicular carcinoma, Hodgkin's, and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Examples of vinca alkaloids are vinblastine, vinorelbine, vincristine, and vindesine.

Cyclophosphamide, melphalan, and ifosfamide are nitrogen mustards and are cell-cycle non-specific agents.

Cell-cycle specific agents:

  • Antimetabolites: S phase
  • Camptothecin analogs: S Phase
  • Taxanes, Vinca alkaloids: M phase
  • Epipodophyllotoxin: G1-S phase
  • Bleomycin: G2-M phase

Cell cycle non-specific agents:

  • Alkylating agents
  • Platinum analogs
  • Anthracyclines
  • Mitomycin, dactinomycin

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the procedure shown in the image?

choices.text: The concept of the procedure was introduced by Goldmann.
It is used to treat after cataract
It is based on the Imbert-Fick law
It is used to investigate glaucoma

questions.solution:
The instrument shown is an applanation tonometer, which is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP). 

Tonometers are used to measure intraocular pressure. There are two types of tonometers. They are indentation and applanation tonometers. Increased intraocular pressure is seen in cases of glaucoma.

Applanation tonometry is more accurate. The concept behind the procedure was introduced by Goldmann. The applanation tonometer measures the amount of force needed to applanate (flatten) a known corneal area based on the Imbert-Fick law. Imbert-Fick law states that the pressure inside a sphere(P) is equal to the force (W) required to flatten its surface divided by the area of flattening (A).

P = W/A

Goldmann tonometer, tono-pen, Perkin's applanation tonometry, and pneumatic tonometer are all based on the principle of applanation tonometry. 

Indentation tonometry is based on the principle that a plunger will indent more on a soft eye than a hard eye. Schiotz tonometer is the most widely used tonometer as it is cheap and hand-held. However, it can give false readings if used in an eye with abnormal scleral rigidity.

*Note - After cataract, otherwise known as posterior capsular opacification, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. Treatment includes posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser.

questions.text: A young male patient developed abdominal pain for which he was being evaluated. You notice the following finding in his CECT.  What is the likely condition indicated by the arrow in the image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a horseshoe kidney. It is prone to obstruction, reflux, and stone formation (the likely cause of pain in this case)

Horseshoe kidney is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidneys with male preponderance

Horseshoe kidney is caused due to the fusion of the lower poles of the kidney. The lower border of the kidneys usually lies in front of the L3 vertebra due to the arrest of ascent.

The common associations of horseshoe kidney are:

  • Vesicoureteral Reflux
  • Wilms Tumor
  • Multicystic Dysplastic Kidney
  • Turner’s Syndrome

questions.text:
You see the senior resident ordering the following medications for a patient with end-stage kidney disease. What is the electrolyte abnormality that he is trying to correct?
  1. Intravenous calcium gluconate 
  2. Regular insulin with dextrose 
  3. Salbutamol nebulization
questions.solution:
The most likely electrolyte abnormality that is being corrected using the above is hyperkalemia.

Hyperkalemia is defined as a serum potassium level of more than 5.5 mEq/L. It can cause drastic conduction changes. It can be diagnosed by a sequence of changes affecting the ST-T segments and QRS complex. ST-T segment changes reflect a change in repolarization, while QRS complex changes reflect a change in depolarization.

The ECG changes that can be seen in hyperkalemia depend on the extent of hyperkalemia. 

S. No. Serum potassium level ECG change
1 5.5–6.5 mEq/L Tall, peaked T waves with 'tented' or 'pinched' shape
2 6.5–7.5 mEq/L Loss of P waves
3 7.0–8.0 mEq/L Widened QRS complex
4 > 8.0 mEq/L Sine wave

Drugs that cause hyperkalemia include the following:

  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers, e.g. losartan 
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor blockers like spirinolactone, eplerenone, and drospirenone
  • Epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) blockers like amiloride, triamterene, trimethoprim, pentamidine, and nafamostat

The most common cause of hyperkalemia is kidney failure. 

Treatment of hyperkalemia involves the following:

  1. Administer intravenous calcium gluconate, which raises the threshold and reduces excitability. It is cardioprotective.
  2. Administer regular insulin with dextrose. The insulin will reduce the serum potassium concentration by causing an intracellular shift. The dextrose will counteract the hypoglycemic effects of insulin.
  3. Provide salbutamol nebulization, which will also shift potassium inside the cell.
  4. Remove potassium with calcium-based resins, diuretics, or hemodialysis.

questions.solution:

The National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) has started the Suraksha clinic to deal with sexually transmitted infections (STI) and reproductive tract infections (RTI). Pre-packed STI/RTI color-coded kits are supplied through STI/RTI clinics free of cost.
