questions.text: A 55 year old postmenopausal woman came with complaints of irregular bleeding, breast tenderness, and abdominal pain. Abdomino-pelvic ultrasound revealed an adnexal mass. A biopsy from the mass revealed the following picture. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with biopsy showing gland-like structures, called Call–Exner bodies are suggestive of granulosa cell tumor.

Granulosa cell tumors are ovarian sex-cord stromal tumors made up of cells closely resembling the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle. The majority of the time it is seen in post-menopausal women. 

These tumors are usually unilateral. In adult women, they may be associated with proliferative breast disease, postmenopausal irregular bleeding, breast tenderness, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma. The presence of this tumor in prepubertal girls may lead to precocious puberty. Occasionally, granulosa cell tumors produce androgens, masculinizing the patient

The cut section is soft and has a yellowish reticular or trabecular appearance with interstitial hemorrhage. On microscopy, Call- Exner bodies are seen which are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material that resemble immature follicles.

Other options:

Option B: A yolk sac tumor/endodermal sinus tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic.

Option C: Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. It is characterized by mucin-producing signet ring cells. 

Option D: Seminoma is the most common type of germ-cell tumor. The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and a central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus giving a fried-egg.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman came with complaints of abdominal pain, shortness of breath, and vomiting for a few hours. She is on ovulation induction therapy for infertility.  Her sonogram of both ovaries is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the sonogram showing enlarged ovaries meeting in the midline having large cysts are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. 

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is an iatrogenic complication seen during the luteal phase or early pregnancy. It is seen in patients taking ovulation induction therapies for infertility more common in FSH/LH therapy than clomiphene or pulsatile GnRH therapies. 

The pathogenesis in OHSS is the increased vascular permeability leading to a fluid shift from intravascular to extravascular space.

They often present with shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and gastrointestinal disturbances like nausea, vomiting, and oliguria. Abdominal pain occurs due to ovarian enlargement and accumulation of peritoneal fluid. Increased vascular permeability and loss of fluid, protein, and electrolytes into the peritoneal cavity cause ascites and result in hemoconcentration. Hemoconcentration causes hyperviscosity and leads to hypercoagulability. Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, leukocytosis, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion can be associated with OHSS. 

This condition can be prevented by

  • Withholding hCG in a cycle if there are more than 20 follicles on ultrasound and E2 level rises to 3000 pg/ mL.
  • Albumin 5% infusion in 500 mL lactated Ringer’s solution during and after oocyte retrieval
  • Dopamine agonist cabergoline 0.5 mg daily for 8 days starting on day 1 of hCG.

OHSS is primarily managed with general supportive care. Paracentesis is performed to ameliorate abdominal discomfort and relieve respiratory discomfort.

Other options:

Option B- Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is the most common endocrine disorder of the reproductive age group. Patients with PCOS present with menstrual irregularities, hirsutism, acne, infertility, etc.

The ultrasound examination image shown below is of PCOS showing enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts. 


Option C- Hyperreactio luteinalis is a condition in which one or both ovaries develop multiple large theca lutein cysts. They are commonly seen in gestational trophoblastic disease, multiple gestational pregnancies, and other high HCG states. Most of them resolve spontaneously after delivery. Surgical management is only required if it is complicated by torsion or hemorrhage. 

The below image shows bilaterally enlarged ovaries with multiple theca luteal cysts as in hyperreactio luteinalis.


Option D- Hematometra is a condition in which menstrual outflow obstruction traps the blood and distends the uterus.  A large uterus can compress the urinary bladder, and rectum causing urinary retention and constipation. blood may get infected and lead to pyometra causing fever and leukocytosis.

The below ultrasonographic image shows a smooth, symmetric hypoechoic enlargement of the uterine cavity suggestive of hematometra.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes with complaints of floaters and photopsia for the past 3 months. The consultant uses the following instrument to evaluate the patient. What method is being used?
questions.solution:
The method being used is indirect ophthalmoscopy. It is a type of ophthalmoscopy and is used for fundus examination. 

Fundus examination can be done using ophthalmoscopy or a slit-lamp biomicroscopy. Ophthalmoscopy is the method of assessing the interior of the eye by using an ophthalmoscope. There are 3 types of ophthalmoscopy, mainly indirect ophthalmoscopy, direct ophthalmoscopy, and distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

An indirect ophthalmoscope produces a real, inverted, and magnified image. It is essential for assessing retinal detachment and other peripheral retinal lesions. 

Advantages of  an indirect ophthalmoscope over a direct ophthalmoscope are:

Magnification  X~2.5   X 15
Area of the field in focus  Much larger (8 disc diameter) Small (2 disc diameter)

Depth perception Possible Not possible

Other options:

Option A: Slit-lamp biomicroscopy is used to scan the eye anteroposteriorly and horizontally. 

Option C: Direct ophthalmoscope is most commonly used in routine fundus examination. Its features can be seen in the table above.

Option D: Distant direct ophthalmoscopy is used to help recognize a detached retina, diagnose opacities in the refractive media, etc. It can be performed using a self-illuminated ophthalmoscope or a simple plain mirror with a hole at its center.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic patient presented with complaints of fever, cough, and hemoptysis for a few weeks. On staining his sputum, gram-negative bacilli with the typical safety pin appearance were identified. Culture on Ashdown medium showed wrinkled, purple colonies. Which of the following could be the possible causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Whitmore's disease or melioidosis caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei.

Infection with B. pseudomallei is acquired by contamination of abrasion wounds with soil and water containing the bacilli. Patients with underlying diseases like diabetes mellitus have an increased risk of acquiring the infection.

Melioidosis can be of two types:

  • Acute - It causes acute pneumonia with upper lobe infiltrates or severe necrotizing disease. It can also mimic tuberculosis with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. It may lead to septicemia. Acute cases have a high case fatality rate. 
  • Chronic - It can lead to the development of multiple caseous or suppurative foci, with skin and subcutaneous abscesses. These can lead to lymphangitis and lymphadenopathy. It may involve bones and other internal organs.

On microscopy, gram-negative bacilli with a typical bipolar safety-pin appearance (as shown below) is seen.

The image below shows dry purple wrinkled colonies of B. pseudomallei cultured in Ashdown medium. 

Treatment is divided into two stages: an intensive phase of 2 weeks of therapy with ceftazidime (drug of choice) or a carbapenem, followed by 12 weeks of oral cotrimoxazole to eradicate the organism and prevent relapse.

Option B: Burkholderia mallei causes glanders disease. It is a gram-negative, irregularly staining bacillus with a beaded appearance. It is usually an equine infection. Human infection is possible and is usually occupational, found among veterinarians and persons working with/caring for horses.

Option C: Burkholderia cepacia is an opportunist pathogen, usually seen in cases of cystic fibrosis or chronic granulomatous disease. It causes a rapidly fatal syndrome of respiratory distress and septicemia (cepacia syndrome) in cystic fibrosis patients.

Option D: Paraburkholderia species do not cause human infection. They are beneficial to plants.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought with a history of impaired vision. On examination, she has light hair, light skin color, and pale blue iris. The child has a normal IQ.  You suspect a disorder due to a deficiency of an enzyme tyrosinase. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features along with the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosinase point to the diagnosis of albinism.

The first step in melanin synthesis involves the oxidation of L-tyrosine to DOPA by the enzyme tyrosinase. Tyrosinase again acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which undergoes a series of reactions to form melanin. Mutations in the tyrosinase gene lead to a complete inability to produce melanin.

Albinism is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes. This manifests as white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-gray in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity. The IQ of the child will be normal.

Given below is an image of a young child with albinism showing white hair, skin, and pale iris:

Other options:

Option B: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency leads to phenylketonuria. This defect results in the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. Infants appear normal at birth. They gradually develop hyperactivity, agitation, low IQ, and hypopigmentation (due to tyrosine deficiency), Phenylacetate gives rise to the characteristic mousy odor in the body sweat, and urine.

Option C: The metabolic defect in alkaptonuria is a defective homogentisate oxidase. Patients typically will have dark urine or urine that turns dark on standing, ochronosis(bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue), arthritis, the pigment in the sclera, and ear cartilage.

Option D: Tyrosinemia type 2 (oculocutaneous type) is caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine transaminase. Clinical findings include palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions with photophobia, and learning disability.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a warty cutaneous growth on his foot. Histopathology is as shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is likely a case of chromoblastomycosis with sclerotic bodies seen on histopathology examination.

It is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genera Fonsecaea. It enters the skin by traumatic inoculation. Hence, seen in woodcutters and farmers.

Patients present with verrucous and warty cauliflower-like cutaneous nodules on the feet and lower legs. The disease generally remains localized with slow peripheral extension. Lymphatic spread can occur.

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells called medlar/copper penny bodies.Other options:

Mycetoma is caused by various types of Fungi (Eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (Actinomycetes). It presents with a painless nodule but with time, papules and pustules may form which break down to form draining sinuses, with the discharge of granules.

The image below shows mycetoma of foot:

Sporotrichosis: Nodules generally develop along the draining lymphatics.

Phaeohyphomycosis: It is a chronic fungal infection involving the skin and subcutaneous tissue. The lesions may be plaques that are verrucous, hypertkeratotic or ulcerated. The fungi implicated are usually of the class Phialophora or Cladophora or other dematiaceous fungi.

questions.text: A middle-aged man comes with complaints of sudden-onset chest pain radiating to the left arm and profuse sweating. An ECG taken showed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Which of the following is true regarding blood lactate dehydrogenase levels in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sudden onset chest pain with profuse sweating and ECG with ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF is suggestive of myocardial Infarction. Serum LDH 1 > LDH 2 levels are seen in this condition. 

Under normal conditions, LDH 2 is predominantly present in the blood and LDH 1 is predominantly present in the heart. So, normally LDH 2 > LDH 1 in blood. When cardiac tissue is damaged LDH 1 is released into the bloodstream. This results in a flipped lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) ratio where LDH 1 > LDH 2.

LDH is a tetrameric enzyme with 4 subunits. It has four subunits with two isoforms: H isoform (heart) and M isoform (muscle)

questions.text: A mother brings her 9-year-old child with complaints of polyuria. On examination, he has growth failure and bitemporal hemianopia. Laboratory evaluation reveals low urine osmolality and high plasma osmolality. Findings on the MRI brain are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the MRI showing intracranial mass with foci of calcification at sella turcica and the laboratory findings suggestive of diabetes insipidus point to a diagnosis of craniopharyngioma.

Craniopharyngiomas are tumors that arise from the remnants of Rathke’s pouch. It is an intracranial space-occupying lesion. It has bimodal age of presentation. Children usually present with frequent headaches, short stature, bitemporal hemianopsia (due to optic chiasm compression), and polyuria.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol-rich, thick brownish-yellow fluid and are compared to machine oil. They also show radiologically demonstrable calcification.

Diabetes insipidus in these patients can be diagnosed with features such as polyuria, low urine osmolality, and high plasma osmolality. Treatment of central diabetes insipidus caused by craniopharyngioma includes supplementation with vasopressin analogs such as desmopressin (DDAVP) and resection of the tumor.

Other options:

Option B: Germinomas of the pituitary stalk also cause central diabetes insipidus. However, they are often missed in routine neuroimaging. 

Option C: Pituitary microadenomas usually present incidentally or with endocrine effects. They are <10mm in size and the tumor is confined to the sella. Visual field deficits are usually caused by pituitary macroadenomas. 

Option D: Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare cause of central diabetes insipidus. Symptoms include dermatological manifestations such as red, scaly papules, pain, and swelling in the limbs, characteristic bony lesions, and disseminated lymph node enlargement.

questions.text: A woman presents with cyclical hematuria 8 months after an emergency cesarean section was done for non-progress of labor. There is no urinary incontinence. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of vesicouterine fistula.

Vesicouterine fistula occurs during cesarean section or uterine rupture or placenta accreta. Patients complain of cyclical hematuria due to the trickling of menstrual blood into the bladder through this anomalous condition. But the urinary continence of the patient remains normal. This is also known as Youssef syndrome. 

Other causes of cyclical hematuria can be intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) perforation into the bladder or bladder endometriosis. True pathology can be confirmed by cystoscopy.

Treatment:

  • Prolonged bladder catheterization can close the fistula. 
  • Abdominal repair using omental or gracilis graft is done if the prolonged catheterization fails.

Methylene blue swab test:

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. A diluted solution of methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a transurethral catheter. After 15 to 30 minutes, the swabs are removed serially and inspected for dye.

Interpretation:

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in the ureterovaginal fistula
  • The middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula
  • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in the urethrovaginal fistula

The given image shows the 3-swab test.

Other options:

Option A: In a vesicovaginal fistula, the main complaint will be constant dribbling of urine (true incontinence). It usually follows difficult childbirth. A positive methylene blue test confirms the diagnosis. 

Option C: Ureterovaginal fistulae result from direct injury to the ureter during gynecologic surgery (Eg: Wertheim's procedure for Ca cervix). Urine dribbles from both vagina and urethra post-surgery. The three-swab test will not stain with methylene blue, but with urine.

Option D: In urethrovaginal fistulae, the patient is continent and dry, but may dribble urine during micturition. This usually follows surgery for a paravaginal cyst or urethral diverticulum, or after a penetrating injury from a fall or criminal abortion. The fistulous opening is visible on speculum examination.

questions.text: A middle-aged obese, non-diabetic, non-hypertensive female patient has been diagnosed with non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). Which of the following drugs can be used as the first-line treatment in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, Alpha-tocopherol or vitamin E is the first-line treatment considered for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) for non-diabetic patients.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is associated with diabetes and obesity. The fatty change may also be caused due to the effect of toxins (including certain medications), protein malnutrition, dyslipidemia, and anoxia. Bleomycin, Methotrexate, Doxycycline, and l-Asparaginase are other drugs that can cause hepatic steatosis.

Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is characterized by hepatic steatosis which is complicated by histologically evident hepatocyte death and inflammation. Currently, a liver biopsy is the best investigation to establish the diagnosis.

The current approach to NAFLD management focuses on treatment to avoid or decrease the risk factors for NASH (like obesity, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, and dyslipidemia).

Alpha-tocopherol or vitamin E is the first-line treatment considered for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). Various clinical trials demonstrate that vitamin E is well-tolerated, and shows modest improvements in AST levels, radiographic features of hepatic steatosis, and/or histologic features of NASH.

  • Vitamin E should only be considered as the first-line pharmacotherapy for non-diabetic NASH patients.
  • Dose: 800 IU/day.

In patients with diabetes who also have NAS1H/NAFLD, the clinician needs. to consider the presence of NASH while selectingoral anti-hypoglycemic agent. GLP—1 agonists and thiazolidinediones, such as pioglitazone, have been shown to improve fibrosis, inflammation, and steatosis.

 Other options : 

Option A: Ursodeoxycholic acid (a bile acid that improves certain cholestatic liver diseases) and omega-3 fatty acids show no histologic benefit in the management of NASH.

Option C: Metformin is not currently recommended as a treatment for NASH (in patients without diabetes) as there is no conclusive evidence of improved hepatic outcomes. 

Option D: N-acetylcysteine(NAC) is a specific antidote for paracetamol poisoning. It has maximum efficacy when given within 8 hours and can be given either via the oral or intravenous route.

questions.text: Identify the Mallampatti class of this patient.
questions.solution:
The image shows Mallampatti class II airway.

The modified Mallampatti classification is used in the assessment of airway. It is a predictor of the difficulty of intubation or difficult airway.

The assessment is performed with the patient sitting up straight, mouth open and tongue maximally protruded, without saying "ahh."

Modified Mallampati classification:

  • Class 0: Ability to see any part of the epiglottis. 
  • Class I: Soft palate, fauces, uvula visible.
  • Class II: Soft palate and fauces seen, tip of uvula not visible.
  • Class III: Soft palate, base of uvula visible.
  • Class IV: Soft palate not visible at all. Only hard palate visible.

Classes 3 and 4 are difficult intubation situations.

*Note:
Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents to the refraction room. You read his previous prescription which mentions blurred vision and eye strain due to astigmatism. What is the type of astigmatism, if the horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian?
questions.solution:
The horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian in Against-the-rule astigmatism.

Other options:

With the rule, astigmatism: The vertical meridian is rendered more curved due to the pressure of the eyelids. It is normally seen in the eyes.

Oblique astigmatism: Here, the two principal meridians are not the horizontal and vertical meridians although they are at right angles to each other.

Bi-oblique astigmatism: Here, the two principal meridians are not at right angles to each other; for example, one may be at 40 degrees and the other, at 100 degrees.

questions.text: The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare is planning strategies to completely prevent the emission of nitrogen dioxide and carbon monoxide.  Which level of prevention does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Strategies to completely prevent the emission of nitrogen dioxide and sulfur dioxide fall under the primordial level of prevention. 

The primordial level of prevention involves the prevention of the emergence or development of risk factors in countries or population groups in which they have not yet appeared.

Primordial prevention consists of risk factor reduction targeted towards an entire population through a focus on social and environmental conditions. Measures taken for this level of prevention are typically promoted through laws and national policies. The main intervention in primordial prevention is individual and mass education.

Examples of the concerns addressed at this level include adult health problems, like obesity and hypertension, that have an early onset due to lifestyle factors, like smoking, poor eating patterns, and lack of physical exercise; preventive measures are directed at discouraging these practices from early childhood.

Other options:

Option A: Secondary prevention includes early disease detection and targets healthy-looking individuals with subclinical forms of the disease. Secondary prevention is defined by intervention that halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications.

Screening tests and early diagnosis are the specific interventional strategies used in the secondary level of prevention, and they help arrest the disease process. It is an imperfect tool in the control of the transmission of disease. It is often more expensive and less effective than primary prevention. A Papanicolaou (Pap) smear is an example of secondary prevention aimed to diagnose cervical cancer in its subclinical state before progression.

Option C: Tertiary prevention includes all rehabilitation measures available to reduce or limit impairments and disabilities and to minimize suffering caused by any stage of the disease. This also promotes the patient's adjustment to irremediable conditions. Tertiary prevention extends the concepts of prevention by rehabilitation.

Examples include occupational and physical therapy in burns patients and cardiac rehabilitation in post-myocardial infarction patients.

Option D: Primary prevention is defined as an action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. Primary prevention is obtained by measures promoting general health and well-being and the quality of life of people by specific protective measures. This helps in the modification of risk factors of a  disease. They include two strategies:

  • Population (mass) strategy where the target group is the whole population
  • A high-risk strategy where the target group is limited to the people who are most at risk of developing a particular disease

Examples are sanitation, immunization, and the protection of food.

questions.text: The given image is a dissected specimen of the posterior surface of the knee. What is the nature of the gait associated with damage to the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the common peroneal nerve. Damage to it would result in a high stepping gait.

The common peroneal nerve descends down obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa, until the fibular head. It lies medial to the biceps femoris. The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to the peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis, which are the evertors of the foot, and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot, except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment, which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between the great and second toes.

Common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the level of the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. The clinical features of common peroneal nerve injury include the following:

  • Foot drop (image below shows a foot drop in the right calf) leading to high stepping gait.
  • Weakness or paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion
  • A diminished sensation on the dorsum of the foot including the first dorsal web space
  • Plantar flexion, inversion, and ankle reflex are preserved

Other options:

  • Cautious gait is seen in persons with spinal TB; they will walk carefully with short steps to avoid pain resulting from movement.
  • Wide-stepping gait is a broad-based unstable gait and is indicative of cerebellar dysfunction.
  • Waddling gait is seen in developmental dysplasia of the hip and in proximal muscle weakness.

questions.text: A woman presents at 33-weeks of gestation and the umbilical artery Doppler imaging shows the following finding. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Terminate the pregnancy at 34 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
The umbilical artery Doppler depicts the reversal of end-diastolic flow (waves appearing below the baseline) which is seen in intrauterine growth restriction. So the next step of management is the termination of pregnancy irrespective of gestational age

Abnormal flow patterns in the umbilical artery:

Reduced End diastolic flow: Uteroplacental insufficiency (S/D ratio increases)

Absent End diastolic flow: Fetal compromise - terminate the pregnancy by cesarean section if >34 weeks.

Reverse end diastolic flow: Impending doom of death - terminate pregnancy irrespective of gestational age.

questions.text: Which of the following disease is associated with a positive Coombs test?
questions.solution:
A positive Coomb's test is seen in patients with cold agglutinin disease.

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), hereditary spherocytosis, and megaloblastic anemia are not Coomb's positive conditions. The following are Coombs-positive hemolytic anemias:

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA)
    • Warm AIHA
    • Cold agglutinin disease
  • Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH)
  • Drug-induced hemolytic anemia

Cold agglutinins are IgM autoantibodies against red blood cell antigens that are activated at an optimum temperature of 3- 4° celsius. Cold agglutinin disease is a form of auto-immune hemolytic anemia involving cold agglutinins.

Condition Agglutination with
anti- IgG anti- C3
Warm AIHA + +
Drug-induced + +
PCH - +
Cold agglutinin disease (IgM) - +
PNH - -

 

*Note: In PCH, the direct Coomb's test will be positive for complement only. This condition is characterized by the presence of the Donath-Landsteiner antibody. It is a unique antibody with anti-P specificity at 4°C. Hence, it binds to the RBC at 4°C. However, it causes complement-mediated lysis at 37°C.

questions.text: A primigravid woman at 34 weeks of gestation was taken for emergency cesarean section after presenting with premature rupture of membranes and severe abdominal pain. Laparotomy revealed patches of dark port wine color over the uterus. In which of the following conditions can this complication be expected?
questions.solution:
The laparotomy finding is suggestive of uteroplacental apoplexy/Couvelaire uterus, and this complication can be expected in abruptio placenta.

Abruptio placenta is the partial/total placental separation from its implantation site before delivery. The bleeding may be:

  • Revealed (blood dissects downwards between membranes and uterine wall to escape through the cervix) or
  • Concealed (blood accumulates between detached placenta and uterus)

Risk factors for abruptio placenta include prior abruption history, preterm premature rupture of membranes, and pregnancy-associated hypertension. Patients often present with sudden onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions.

Uteroplacental apoplexy/Couvelaire uterus is a complication seen in severe types of concealed abruptio placentae. There is massive intravasation of blood into the uterine musculature, potentially extending up to the serous coat. It is only diagnosed on laparotomy, where a port-wine-colored uterus (diffuse or patchy) is seen. Though the uterus may lose its contractility, increasing the risk of bleeding, it rarely causes uterine atony. Hence, Couvelaire uterus does not require hysterectomy until uterine atony occurs.

Other complications of abruptio placenta include: 

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Hypovolemic shock due to torrential bleeding
  • Acute kidney injury

Abruptio placenta is mostly managed by immediate delivery and management of complications such as shock with adequate blood products.

Other options: 

Option A: Placenta previa occurs when the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment over or very near to the cervical os. Vaginal bleeding is usually painless in this condition.

Option B: Preeclampsia is a multisystem disorder that occurs after 20 weeks due to the new onset of hypertension and proteinuria. Patients complain of headaches, epigastric pain, decreased urine output, and blurring of vision.

Option D: Uterine inversion is a complication that occurs in the third stage of labor. The uterus is partially/completely turned inside out due to various factors, such as fundally implanted placenta, uterine atony, placenta accrete syndrome, and cord traction before the placenta is separated. It produces acute lower abdominal pain with a bearing down sensation and leads to massive bleeding.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with a history of a gunshot wound sustained while on a hunting trip. X-ray findings are as given below. Which of the following weapons is most likely to produce this type of injury?
questions.solution:
The radiograph is suggestive of a close-range shotgun blast injury to the knee. Birdshot pellets are visible within and around the shattered patella, distal femur, and proximal tibia.

The ammunition for the shotgun is a cartridge made of a cardboard or plastic cylinder fitted into a metal base. The base carries a percussion detonator that is struck by the spring-loaded firing pin when the trigger is pulled.  The primer is located in the percussion cup and contains the detonator.  The cartridge contains a charge of propellant (gunpowder), above which are ‘wads’ or pistons of felt, and cardboard or plastic discs, or both. Above these is the charge of shot (pellets), which varies greatly in number and size, finally covered by a card or plastic disc.

 

The image given below shows the entry wound in the case of a shotgun. There is a central round hole, with multiple pellet holes scattered around the central hole. This wound is most likely to have been caused by a shotgun from a range of 1-5 m.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady is diagnosed with Hashimoto thyroiditis. She has antibodies against the thyroid peroxidase enzyme. Which of the following function is not affected by this enzyme?
questions.solution:
Iodide trapping (iodide uptake) is not catalyzed by thyroid peroxidase. It occurs with the help of an iodide pump.

Thyroid peroxidase catalyses oxidation, organification(iodination) and coupling.

Steps in synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone: 

  • Iodide uptake: The basolateral sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) actively takes up I-(iodide) from the circulation into the follicular cells. It is then transported into the colloid through a pendrin (chloride-iodide) transporter 
  • Thyroglobulin synthesis: Thyroglobulin (Tg), is a large glycoprotein rich in tyrosine residues. It is synthesized by follicular cells.
  • Iodination of thyroglobulin: The process of incorporating iodine into the tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin, leading to the formation of iodothyronine. This is regulated by the thyroid peroxidase (TPO) enzyme. TPO has three functions: 
    • Oxidation: TPO oxidizes I- to I2 (iodine)  in the presence of H2O2
    • Organification: TPO links tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin with iodine (I2) to form monoiodotyrosine (MIT), diiodotyrosine (DIT)
    • Coupling reactions: TPO combines iodinated tyrosine residues to make MIT + DIT = T3 (triiodothyronine), DIT + DIT = T4 (tetraiodothyronine)
  • Storage: Thyroid hormones are bound to thyroglobulin and stored in the follicular lumen as colloids. The colloid has hormone reserves for 2-3 months
  • Release: Iodinated thyroglobulin is taken up by the thyroid follicles via endocytosis and fuses with lysosomes. It is cleaved by lysosomal proteolytic enzymes into MIT, DIT, T3, and T4. T4 (80%) and T3 (20%) are released into the blood
  • Peripheral T3 conversion: T4 undergoes deiodination in extrathyroidal tissue to form T3, which is the active form of the hormone

questions.text: An 8 year old girl was brought to the hospital after her parents noticed blood in her stools. Physical examination showed the below finding. Small bowel radiography and histopathology showed multiple, small- to medium-sized hamartomatous polyps. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of blood in stools, mucocutaneous pigmentation, and hamartomatous small to medium-sized polyps are suggestive of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation.

The hyperpigmentation typically appears as dark blue to brown macules on the lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, palmar surfaces of the hands, genitalia, and perianal region. During later life, there is a risk for gastric and small intestinal cancers, and subsequently for colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers.

Germline mutations in the gene STK11 are present in approximately half of the individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Histopathology shows the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by the normal-appearing intestinal epithelium (as shown below).

Other options:

Option A: Juvenile polyps are the focal malformations of the epithelium or the lamina propria. They occur in children less than 5 years of age. Microscopy of the polyp reveals dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris. 

Option B: Turcot syndrome is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis and constitutes colorectal polyps and brain tumors like medulloblastomas and glioblastomas.

Option D: Lynch syndrome, also called hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC) syndrome, is associated with cecum and colon carcinomas. It is a DNA mismatch repair defect. They are also at an increased risk of developing cancers of the endometrium, stomach, ovary, ureters, brain, small bowel, hepatobiliary tract, pancreas, and skin.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought by his parents with complaints of diarrhea and dermatitis. The child had neutral aminoaciduria and a positive Obermeyer test result. Which of the following is the precursor of the vitamin that is deficient in the patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of pellagra secondary to Hartnup disease. The vitamin deficiency in this condition is niacin. The precursor of niacin is tryptophan.

Hartnup's disease which is due to impaired renal and intestinal absorption of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids. It is characterized by a varied clinical presentation including ataxia (lack of muscle control), delayed mental development, diarrhea, and dermatitis i.e, pellagra-like symptoms (as tryptophan is a precursor of niacin)

Diagnosis is based on aminoaciduria and increased excretion of indole compounds detected by the Obermeyer test.

Niacin/vitamin B3 is a constituent of NAD and NADP. Niacin deficiency causes pellagra (3Ds):

  1. Diarrhea
  2. Dermatitis (Casal necklace)
  3. Dementia

Patients can also present with bright red glossitis, stomatitis, depression, seizures, insomnia, and delirium.

The image below shows the Casal necklace—a ring-like rash seen around the neck caused by the deficiency of niacin.

questions.text: Diagnose the respiratory condition based on the CT given below?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this patient is bronchiectasis. The CT scan shows the signet ring sign which is specific for bronchiectasis.

Bronchiectasis refers to the irreversible dilatation of one or more bronchi, which occurs due to recurrent cycles of infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Development of the disease requires an infectious insult in combination with impaired bacterial clearance (eg, impaired immune defenses, structural airway defect).

The clinical scenario observed in bronchiectasis is: 

  • Repeated chest infections 
  • Presence of large amounts of yellow sputum 
  • Non-smoker 

Bronchiectasis is commonly associated with

  • Kartagener syndrome
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.

Radiological findings - Chest X-ray shows tram track appearance due to the dilated airways. 

CT findings include:

  • Tram track appearance
  • Signet ring sign
  • Lack of bronchial tapering
  • Tree-in-bud pattern - It occurs due to the thickening of the dilated airways along with the inspissated secretions.
  • Cysts originating from the bronchial wall (pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis)

Note: High-Resolution CT (HRCT) is the best method for the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. 

Other options:

Option A: Pulmonary tuberculosis is an infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Patients often present with chronic cough and hemoptysis. Low-grade fever, anorexia, and weight loss are the commonly associated symptoms. CT findings of pulmonary tuberculosis are Ghon focus, Ranke complex, nodal calcifications, cavities, and hilar/paratracheal lymphadenopathy.

Option B: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease[COPD], is inflammation-induced destruction of lung parenchyma resulting from cigarette smoke or other pollutants. Patients typically will be smokers with exertional dyspnea, and cough with productive sputum. Lung hyperinflation (emphysema) and airflow obstruction are characteristic of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. 

Option C: Bronchial asthma is an airway hyperresponsiveness disease characterized by reversible airway narrowing and obstruction by mucus plugging. Patients typically present with symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and cough usually on exposure to triggering agents. CT findings in bronchial asthma are bronchial wall thickening, mucus plugging, decreased lung attenuation, and gas trapping.

questions.text: A neonate presented with mild intermittent upper abdominal pain. On examination, the infant has a scaphoid abdomen and breath sounds are decreased on both sides. X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of respiratory distress, intermittent abdominal pain, scaphoid abdomen, absent breath sounds in both sides of the chest, and an X-ray image showing bowel loops in the thoracic cavity is diagnostic of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), the most common variant being Bochdalek hernia.

If the defect is posterolateral it is called Bochdalek hernia and if it's anteromedial it is called Morgagni hernia. 

Clinical features :

  • Respiratory distress is a cardinal sign in infants with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
  • Early respiratory distress, within 6 hr after birth, is thought to be a poor prognostic sign.
  • Children with CDH may also have a scaphoid abdomen and increased chest wall diameter.
  • Bowel sounds may also be heard in the chest, with a bilateral decrease in breath sounds.
  • The point of maximal cardiac impulse may be displaced away from the side of a hernia if a mediastinal shift has occurred.
  • Retroperitoneal fat, left kidney, spleen or only the omentum commonly herniates through the defect. If the defect is large, most abdominal contents including the stomach may herniate.

Diagnosis:

  • Chest radiography and passage of a nasal gastric tube confirm the diagnosis.
  • CDH can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography (between 16 and 24 weeks of gestation)
  • High-speed fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can further define the lesion.

Treatment:

Variable period of time (24-72 hours) to allow for stabilization before surgical repair. Immediate respiratory support should be provided, including rapid endotracheal intubation and sedation. 

Bag and Mask Ventilation is contraindicated in newborns with congenital diaphragmatic hernia because it causes distension of the stomach which in turn may limit the expansion of the already hypoplastic lung.

Other options:

Option B: Chest radiograph revealing bowel loops in the thorax is not seen in pneumonia.

Option C: Morgagni hernia: Here the defect is at the anteromedial location. It is rarer than Bochdalek hernia and accounts for only 2-5% of CDH. About 90% of the cases occur on the right side.

It is less symptomatic and the diagnosis is usually delayed until childhood. The patient presents with respiratory or upper GI symptoms. Respiratory symptoms like distress, tachypnea, and recurrent pulmonary infections are common in children. Other symptoms are abdominal pain, dyspnea, flatulence, and indigestion.

Radiographic findings

  • Radiolucent paracardiac shadow may be seen retrosternally on lateral chest x-ray if there is bowel herniation.
  • Rounded opacity in the right cardiophrenic angle may be seen if there is herniation of omentum or solid organs.(Shown below)

 

Option D: Eventration of the diaphragm: It refers to the abnormal contour of the dome of the diaphragm without any disruption to the diaphragmatic continuity. It usually involves a segment of the hemidiaphragm. It can cause respiratory distress in newborns and is usually asymptomatic in adults.

Radiographic findings: The affected portion of the hemidiaphragm is elevated and is seen as a smooth hump, while the normal contour is seen in the remaining part. 'Double diaphragmatic contour' may be seen in frontal view and is confirmed with a lateral X-ray.

questions.text: Identify the clinical sign being elicited in the image shown below.
questions.solution:
The clinical sign being elicited is Fluid thrill.

The fluid thrill is elicited to clinically diagnose ascites.

It is not a reliable sign and is only felt when there is a large amount of fluid under tension.

Method: The patient is placed supine and his abdomen is exposed after consent. Place one hand of the examiner flat over the lumbar region while an assistant's hand is kept firmly on the midline of the abdomen with the side of his hand kept longitudinally. This is done to dampen any impulse that can be transmitted via the fat of the abdominal wall. Now the examiner flicks or taps the opposite side of the abdomen where his palm is not resting and a fluid thrill or wave is felt on the resting hand.

Note:

The cardinal clinical sign for ascites is shifting dullness.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a deformed eye (given below). He was treated for a corneal ulcer 2 weeks back which took a long time to heal despite treatment with antibiotics. Which of the following layers is involved in the disease seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of anterior staphyloma and it commonly involves the uveal tissue with the cornea.

Staphyloma (a bunch of grapes) is a clinical condition characterized by ectasia of the outer coats (cornea, or sclera or both) of the eye, with the involvement of the uveal tissue. The basic underlying pathology is the weakening of the eyewall, which can be caused by many inflammatory or degenerative diseases involving these structures.

Types of staphyloma

  • Anterior staphyloma: an ectasia of the pseudocornea, which results from the total sloughing of the cornea. It is lined internally by the iris and externally, by the newly formed epithelium.
  • Intercalary staphyloma: This is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris.
  • Ciliary staphyloma: Ectasia of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone that includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus.
  • Equatorial staphyloma: This occurs at the equatorial region up to 14 mm behind the limbus of the eye.
  • Posterior staphyloma: This affects the posterior pole of the eye.

Note: 

  •  The most common cause for anterior staphyloma is sloughing corneal ulcer.
  •  The most common cause for posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.

Image showing the types of staphyloma.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with complaints of daydreaming in the class as reported by his teacher. Examination revealed that the child had episodes of sudden brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control, which was induced by hyperventilation.  Such episodes lasted for a few seconds, and there was no post-ictal confusion. The child is most likely suffering from
questions.solution:
Sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and no post-ictal confusion is seen in Absence seizures. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds.

The seizures may occur about 100 times a day, and the child is unaware. The seizures are so subtle, that may go unrecognized by parents. Most common complaints include "daydreaming" and a decline in school performance recognized by a teacher. The seizures can be provoked by hyperventilation.

EEG shows generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. Hyperventilation provokes these EEG discharges and seizures.

Other options:

Option A: Syncope is defined as transient, self-limited loss of consciousness due to a sudden decrease in cerebral blood flow. There is a loss of postural control, and patients may faint.

Option B: Myoclonic seizures have preserved consciousness. They involve a sudden brief jerking movement involving the entire body or a part of it.

Option C: Atonic seizures are characterized by a sudden loss of postural control.

questions.text: A carpenter presented to the outpatient department with a swelling over his palm as shown in the image below He gives a history of being injured by a nail on the same region during work.  Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an implantation dermoid which is caused due to traumatic injury.

Implantation dermoid is an acquired condition that occurs as the result of implantation of epidermal fragments into the dermis by a penetrating injury. The epidermis continues to grow and forms a cyst lined with stratified squamous epithelium and filled with keratin.

Can occur with any skin puncture, laceration, or skin incision which has the potential to implant epidermal elements into the dermis and subcutaneous tissue, where continued production of keratin and other epidermal products produces a thick-walled cyst.

Mostly seen in farmers, factory workers, carpenters, and tailors who are subject to repeated minor traumas to the hand. Risk factors of palmoplantar epidermoid cysts-HPV infection, ultraviolet exposure, and eccrine duct obstruction.

Presents as asymptomatic, slowly enlarging, painless, superficial localized swellings over the volar aspect of the hand, especially the distal portion of the digits.

Investigations-X-rays, Ultrasonography, FNAC(CT and MRI may be helpful in delineating the anatomy of the soft tissue tumors, although unnecessary to guide the treatment). Histologically, the inclusion epidermoid cysts are lined with stratified squamous epithelium with granular cell layer and are filled with eosinophilic lamellated keratinous material.

Most of the hand dermoid cysts are benign and asymptomatic, and hence surgical intervention is not needed. The surgical treatment is needed for symptomatic cysts causing interference with hand function in which complete excision is done with regional anesthesia under a pneumatic tourniquet.  

Other options:

Option A: Ameloblastoma is a rare, benign tumor that develops most often in the jaw, near the molars. Causes may include injury to the mouth or jaw, infections of the teeth or gums, or inflammation of these same areas.

Option B: Ganglion cysts are fluid filled lumps that most commonly develop along the tendons or joints of the wrists or hands, or ankle or feet. They are round, small and usually painless. Although rare, they can be painful if they press a nerve. In a few cases, the cysts can interfere with joint movements.

Option C: Lipomas are the most common soft tissue tumor in adults. They present as a well-encapsulated mass of mature adipocytes. It usually arises in the subcutis of the proximal extremities and trunk at around 40-60 years of age.

questions.text: A 5-day-old infant is seen with a rash on his nose, cheek and forehead, as shown in the image below. On examination, they are noted to be pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Milia is the most probable diagnosis. This condition presents with small cysts formed around the pilosebaceous follicles usually seen over the nose, cheek, and forehead. They are pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts. 

Infantile milia may occasionally be associated with oral lesions on the gingivae or palate. Milia are more common in white children, but less frequent in children born prematurely or of low gestational weight. They resolve spontaneously without scarring.

 Other options:

Option A: Erythema toxicum presents with papular lesions on an erythematous base with eosinophil laden sterile lesions, distributed over the trunk and face predominantly. It is a normal finding in many newborns. They are seen 1–3 days after birth and may persist for 1 week and resolve spontaneously and do not require any treatment.

Option B: Pustular melanosis is a benign transient condition that lasts for 2-3 days in newborns. It is seen predominantly in black neonates. The lesions are vesiculopustular eruption and have neutrophils.

Option C: Mongolian spots are blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A 38 year old woman with a chronic history of cough and shortness of breath is found to have bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on a chest X-ray. She also complains of dry eyes and nodules under the skin over her arms. Lymph node biopsy shows non-caseating granulomas. Which of the following findings can be seen in the biopsy of her lesions?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and non-caseating granulomas on lymph node biopsy is suggestive of sarcoidosis. In this condition, Schaumann bodies can be seen on biopsy.

Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease that most commonly presents as bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Lesions of the eyes and skin are also very common in these patients. It is seen more in middle-aged women than in men.

Sarcoidosis results from an increase in CD4+ T-cells (increased CD4+:CD8+ ratio). As a result, cytokines like IL-2, TNF, IL-8, and IFN-gamma will increase. These cytokines are the cause of granuloma formation in this disorder.

It presents with granulomas in multiple organs. They are classically described as non-caseating granulomas composed of epithelioid macrophages with giant cells. There is no central necrosis as there would be in tubercular granulomas. Laminated calcium and protein-containing bodies called Schaumann bodies and star-shaped inclusions called asteroid bodies are also found in the giant cells of most of these granulomas. These are not pathognomonic to sarcoidosis and can also be found in other granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis.

The image below shows stellate inclusions known as asteroid bodies.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in a patient with serotonin syndrome?
questions.solution:
Patients on monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOI) + selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) can develop serotonin syndrome, which is characterized by fever, clonus, hyperreflexia, and tremors.

Serotonin syndrome can occur with any drug that increases 5-HT levels (e.g., MAOIs, SSRIs, SNRIs, TCAs, tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA, and dextromethorphan). Coadministration of these drugs results in increased serotonin and norepinephrine levels, which are responsible for the autonomic symptoms seen in serotonin syndrome.

It is characterized by 3 A’s:

  • Neuromuscular hyperActivity- clonus, hyperreflexia, hypertonia, tremor, and seizure
  • Autonomic stimulation - hyperthermia, diaphoresis, diarrhea 
  • Agitation

Treatment: Cyproheptadine (5-HT2 receptor antagonist).

questions.text: A middle-aged female comes to the clinic for follow-up three weeks after left parotidectomy. She complains of flushing, sweating, and burning sensation on the left side of her face every time she sits down to have a meal. The postganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibers of which of the following nerves is the likely culprit for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
The symptom complex in this patient along with a history of recent parotid surgery is indicative of Frey's syndrome in which the auriculotemporal nerve marked as "D" is involved.

Frey’s syndrome/Gustatory sweating (auriculotemporal syndrome)

  • Commonly develops after parotid surgery or other trauma that results in the opening of the parotid capsule.
  • It results from damage to the autonomic innervation of the salivary gland. There is a regeneration of the parasympathetic nerve fibres that stimulate the sweat glands of the overlying skin in response to salivary stimulation or mastication. 
  • It is thought to reflect abnormal innervation of sweat glands on the face by regrowing parasympathetic secretomotor axons that would previously have innervated the parotid gland
  • Clinical features:
    • Sweating, warmth, and erythema over the region of surgical excision of the parotid gland. This is due to the autonomic stimulation of salivation by the smell/taste of food.
  • Diagnosis:
    • The starch iodine will aid in diagnosis. The affected area painted with iodine will turn blue on exposure to sweat.
  • Management:
    • Antiperspirants with aluminium chloride
    • Subcutaneous infiltration of purified botulinum toxin into the affected area
    • Denervation by a tympanic neurectomy or auriculotemporal nerve avulsion has been advocated but is often not curative

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with hemoptysis, red-colored urine, and frequent sinusitis. Her blood reports revealed anemia, leucocytosis, and elevated ESR. Serology is positive for antiproteinase-3 ANCA. Her chest X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray showing cavitating lesions in the right lung, along with positivity for antiproteinase-3 ANCA ( i.e, c-ANCA) suggests that the most likely diagnosis is granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) a.k.a Wegener's granulomatosis.

Wegener's granulomatosis is a type of vasculitis characterized by necrotizing granulomas in the upper, and lower respiratory tract, and small and medium vessels.

Clinically, they present with fever, purulent rhinorrhoea, nasal ulcers, sinus pain, polyarthralgia, cough, hemoptysis, breathlessness, hematuria, and proteinuria. Occasionally, cutaneous purpura and mononeuritis complex may be present. Necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis can be seen in the condition.

Lab investigations will show anemia, leucocytosis, elevated ESR, and high titers of cytoplasmic ANCA (c-ANCA) targetted against anti-proteinase-3 (anti-PR-3). The specificity of a positive PR-3 ANCA for Wegener's is very high, especially in the presence of active glomerulonephritis. Chest radiograph will show multiple, bilateral cavitating nodules and pulmonary infiltrates. 

The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis on biopsy.

questions.text: A middle aged female patient is diagnosed with insulinoma. Which of the following is not a component of the classical Whipple's triad seen in this condition?

choices.text: Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose

questions.solution:
Increased levels of 72-hour-fasting insulin is not a part of the classic Whipple's triad.

Whipple’s triad describes the clinical symptoms of insulinoma:

  1. Symptoms of hypoglycemia after fasting or exercise
  2. Plasma glucose levels of <2.8 mmol/L or 50 mg/dL
  3. Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose

Insulinoma is a neuroendocrine tumor in which patients present with hypoglycemia due to inappropriately high insulin secretion.

The investigation of choice for insulinoma is the determination of 72-hour fasting glucose and serum insulin levels.

Insulinomas having a diameter of <2 cm without signs of vascular invasion or metastases are considered benign. Tumor enucleation is the technique of choice for benign insulinomas.

Distal pancreatectomy is advised for the following:

  • Tumors deep in the pancreatic body or tail
  • Tumors of size >2 cm
  • Tumors located within 2 mm of the main pancreatic duct

Medical management to treat hyperinsulinism includes frequent intake of carbohydrate-rich meals and octreotide or diazoxide.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented to the clinic with a history suggestive of a transient ischemic attack 5 hours ago. Which of the following can be used to determine the risk for future stroke?
questions.solution:
The risk of stroke following transient ischemic attacks (TIA) is determined by the ABCD2 score.

TIA is a temporary, focal neurological deficit of sudden onset (stroke-like symptoms) lasting for less than 24 hours.

This occurs due to focal ischemia of the brain, retina, or cochlea. There is a high risk of developing an ischemic stroke after a TIA, especially for the first 3 months following a TIA. 

The components of the ABCD2 are shown in the table below

Age ≥60 years 1 point
<60 years 0 points
Blood pressure elevation when first assessed after TIA Systolic ≥ 140 mm Hg or Diastolic ≥90 mm Hg 1 point
Systolic <140 mm Hg and diastolic < 90 mm Hg 0 points
Clinical features Unilateral weakness 2 points
Isolated speech disturbance 1 point
Other  0 points
Duration of TIA symptoms   ≥60 minutes 2 points
10 to 59 minutes 1 point
<10 minutes 0 points
 Diabetes Present 1 point
Absent  0 points

 Interpretation of ABCD2 score:

  • Score 6 to 7: High two-day stroke risk
  • Score 4 to 5: Moderate two-day stroke risk
  • Score 0 to 3: Low two-day stroke risk

Other options:

Options B and C: BISAP (bedside index of severity in a/c pancreatitis) and APACHE II are used for assessing the severity of Acute pancreatitis.

Option D: CHADS2 score determines the risk of stroke in Atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: A middle aged male patient presented with a painful hard lump with purulent discharge as seen in the image below. The patient also reports having a history of diabetes mellitus. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image above shows a picture of a carbuncle which is seen as an infection of hair follicles over a contiguous area and multiple pus-discharging sinuses.

A carbuncle is a deep infection of a contiguous group of follicles accompanied by inflammation of surrounding connective tissue. The causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus. It is commonly associated with diabetes mellitus. 

It presents as a painful hard lump that increases in size (about 3-10 cm). This is followed by suppuration, and pus is discharged from multiple follicular orifices.

Microbiological swabs are taken from the lesion for the culture of the organisms present. Treatment with penicillinase-resistant antibiotics such as flucloxacillin is recommended. 

Incision and drainage and saucerisation may be required to aid in the removal of pus and necrotic tissue.

Other options:

Option A: Folliculitis is infection and inflammation of the follicular ostium. It presents as small follicular papules or pinhead pustules which are rarely painful.

The image below shows a picture of folliculitis:

Option B: Cellulitis is an acute, subacute, or chronic inflammation of loose connective tissue. It presents as diffuse inflammation with erythema, pain, and tenderness.

The image below shows a picture of cellulitis:

Option D: Furuncle or boil is an abscess of the hair follicle (usually vellus type). It presents as a small inflammatory nodule that soon becomes pustular and necrotic.

The image below shows a furuncle:

questions.text: A surgeon performing a difficult neck dissection has accidentally injured the hypoglossal nerve. Which of the following triangles of the neck, is he probably dissecting?
questions.solution:
The surgeon has accidentally injured the hypoglossal nerve, which has its major course in the carotid triangle.

The hypoglossal nerve leaves the skull through the hypoglossal canal. It then descends to the carotid triangle. Here, in the carotid triangle, the nerve makes a loop lateral to the internal and external carotid arteries. The nerve then ascends to the digastric triangle, and reaches further up supplying the muscles of the tongue.

Contents of the carotid triangle include:

  • Common carotid artery, internal and external carotid artery
  • Branches of external carotid – superior thyroid, lingual, facial, ascending pharyngeal, and occipital artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve
  • Hypoglossal nerve
  • Spinal part of the accessory
  • Sympathetic chain
  • Ansa cervicalis

questions.text: A middle aged female patient comes to the OPD with a history of a lump in the left breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump is 9×10 cm with the following appearance and no axillary lymphadenopathy. The histopathology of the biopsy from the lump shows increased stromal cellularity and typical leaflike architecture. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image is suggestive of cystosarcoma phyllodes/Phyllodes tumor of the breast.

Phyllodes tumor, also known as cystosarcoma phyllodes, presents as a large tumor with an unevenly bosselated surface. This tumor does not infiltrate the skin though the overlying skin becomes thin and tense due to swelling. Nipple retraction is not seen in this condition.

The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of a phyllodes tumor. Axillary dissection is not done if malignant transformation occurs because the lymphatic spread is rare.

Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women. Phyllodes tumor is mostly benign even though it is also called cystosarcoma phyllodes or serocystic disease of Brodie. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. Histologically, there is a wide variation with some having low malignant potential and others having a higher mitotic index.

Treatment of phyllodes tumor:

  • Benign type- Enucleation or wide local excision
  • Massive tumors, recurrent tumors, and malignant type- Mastectomy

The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of a phyllodes tumor.

 

Other options:

Option B: Giant fibroadenomas are usually seen in the early reproductive years. These are benign solid encapsulated tumors. It is a slow-growing tumor and presents as a painless lump in the breast.

Option C and D: Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The pathologic hallmark of inflammatory cancer is the presence of tumor cells within dermal lymphatics. Axillary nodal metastases are common, and there is a significant risk for distant metastases.

Patients with inflammatory carcinoma usually have a history revealing the rapid onset of the disease with progression over weeks to 3 months.

The hallmark of inflammatory breast cancer is diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatic channels within the breast and overlying skin, often without an underlying tumor mass. Inflammatory breast cancer manifests clinically as erythema, edema, and warmth of the breast as a result of lymphatic obstruction.

questions.text: A man in a restaurant suddenly begins choking on his food. The following procedure was performed by another patron at the restaurant. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The image shows a person standing behind with arms placed around the choking person's lower chest, giving abdominal thrusts, which is suggestive of Heimlich's maneuver.

The Heimlich maneuver (also known as subdiaphragmatic abdominal thrusts or abdominal thrusts) is done for an adult or a child (1-8 years) with foreign body airway obstruction (FBAO). It is not recommended for FBAO relief in infants. 

The rescuer should stand or kneel behind the patient and wrap his arms around the patient’s waist. A fist is made with one hand and using the other hand, the fist is driven into the patient’s abdomen with a rapid, forceful inward and upward thrust to dislodge the foreign body. This is continued until the foreign body is expelled or if the patient becomes unresponsive. 

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR).

 Other options:

Option B: Back slaps or back blows can also be used to relieve FBAO. They are given between the shoulder blades using the heel of the rescuer’s hand, and up to 5 are given. If there is a failure of the back slaps to relieve the obstruction, up to 5 abdominal thrusts can be given. 

Infants (<1 year) should be treated with alternating 5 back blows and then 5 chest thrusts. The infant's torso is placed on the rescuer's nondominant arm. The procedure is depicted in the image below.

Option C: Chest thrusts can be used as an alternative to the Heimlich maneuver for pregnant women or markedly obese patients. The patient is supine, and the rescuer should kneel close to the victim’s side. Hands are placed in the same manner as is done to perform CPR chest compressions. Each thrust is given in such a way as to relieve the obstruction. 

Option D: The blind finger sweep can be done in unresponsive adults with complete foreign body airway obstruction. With the patient's face up, the mouth is opened by grasping both the tongue and lower jaw and lifting the mandible. The index finger is inserted along the inside of the cheek and using a hooking action, the foreign body is dislodged and removed. The blind finger sweep should be avoided in infants since it may push the object further inside the airway

questions.text: All the passengers coming to India were screened for COVID-19 at the airport. Which type of screening is done in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The type of screening done for the immigrants to a country is prospective screening. 

Prospective screening is done for disease control. People are examined for the benefit of others. It may lead to an early diagnosis and permit more effective treatment. It also reduces the spread of infectious diseases in the community, thereby reducing the mortality associated with the disease.

Other examples of prospective screening:

  • Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the home population.
  • Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever.

Other options:

Option A: Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are examined for their own benefit. Screening is initiated by medical and public health personnel and is not requested by a patient. It may lead to an early diagnosis of an unrecognized disease. Hence, appropriate treatment can be initiated immediately to arrest disease progression.

Examples of prescriptive screening:

  • Screening of infants for phenylketonuria
  • Screening of school children for visual and auditory defects.

Option B: Multiphasic screening is the combined application of two or more screening tests to a large number of people at one time. It is not cost-effective and has shown no benefit in reducing the morbidity and mortality of the population. Examples include a pregnant woman undergoing various screening tests (VDRL, HIV, HBV, etc) at a time.

Option D: Selective screening is done in high-risk groups. It is one of the most productive screening tests. Examples include MRI screening of the breast done annually in a 25-year-old woman with a first-degree relative having BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation.

questions.text: A 9 year old child was diagnosed with acute coalescent mastoiditis. Examination reveals collection of pus under the sheath of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. What is the most likely complication that occurred in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with acute coalescent mastoiditis, most likely has Bezold's abscess.

Bezold's abscess is one of the main complications of acute coalescent mastoiditis and is formed when pus breaks inferiorly, through the thin medial aspect of the tip of the mastoid and collects in the upper part of the neck, most commonly into the sheath of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

The abscess can also take any of the following locations: 

  • Deep to the sternocleidomastoid
  • Along the posterior belly of the digastric presenting as a swelling in the tip of the mastoid or the angle of the jaw
  • The upper part of the posterior triangle
  • Parapharyngeal space
  • Along with the carotid vessels.

Treatment:

  1. Cortical mastoidectomy for coalescent mastoiditis
  2. Drainage of the abscess in the neck with insertion of a drain through a separate incision
  3. IV antibiotics

Other options:

Option A: Zygomatic abscess forms due to infection of the zygomatic air cells. It is situated at the posterior root of the zygoma.  Patients present with swelling in front and above the pinna with associated edema over the upper eyelid. Here the pus collects either superficial or deep to the temporalis muscle.

Option C: Luc abscess is defined as a subperiosteal temporal abscess. It develops following the spread of infection from the middle ear along the external auditory meatus, directly, to the temporal region. Swelling is present in the deep part of the bony meatus. 

Option D: Citelli’s abscess is formed posterior to the mastoid, occupying a position more towards the occipital bone. It is also considered an abscess of the digastric triangle. In any case, a diagnosis of Bezold abscess is more appropriate for this patient owing to the location of the abscess.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common location of implantation in ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The most common location of implantation in ectopic pregnancy is the tubal ampulla.

Almost 95% of ectopic pregnancies implant within the fallopian tube. Within the fallopian tube, the ampulla is the most commonly affected location in 70% of the cases. The remaining implant in the isthmus (12%), fimbria (11%), and interstitial tube (2%). 

The other sites of implantations are the ovary (Option A), peritoneal cavity, cervix (Option B), or prior cesarean scar (Option C). 

Patients usually present with rupture of ectopic pregnancy with the triad of delayed menstrual cycle, abdominal pain, and vaginal bleeding. 

The examination may reveal abdominal tenderness, pain on cervical motion, a bulging posterior vaginal fornix, boggy mass next to the uterus. Vaginal bleeding or spotting may be present. Ruptured ectopic will lead to intraabdominal hemorrhage leading to reciprocal changes in vital signs. 

Investigations used to diagnose ectopic pregnancy include a positive beta-human chorionic gonadotropin to diagnose a pregnancy. Transvaginal ultrasound can be used to identify the gestational sac or determine if the case is a pregnancy of an unknown location. In an ectopic pregnancy, the endometrial stripe will appear as a trilaminar pattern and anechoic fluid collections may be present. 

Medical management of ectopic pregnancy involves the use of methotrexate. Surgical management depends on whether the patient is hemodynamically stable, and whether she desires future fertility (salpingectomy versus salpingostomy). For a ruptured ectopic only salpingectomy can be done.

  • Hemodynamically stable - laparoscopically done
  • Hemodynamically unstable - laparotomy is done

questions.text: What is the amount of land required to practice the trench method of sanitary landfill for a population of 10,000?
questions.solution:
The amount of land required to practice the trench method of sanitary landfill for a population of 10,000 is one acre.

It is estimated that one acre of land per year will be required for 10,000 population if compacted refuse is placed in the fill to a standard depth of 2 meters.

Controlled tipping or sanitary landfill is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal where suitable land is available. The material is placed in a trench or other prepared area, adequately compacted, and covered with earth at the end of the working day. There are three methods under controlled tipping: 

  • Trench method: Done in places where level ground is available
  • Ramp method: Well suited where the terrain is moderately sloping
  • Area method: Used for filling land depressions, disused quarries, and clay pits.

questions.text: A child, upon ingestion of shellfish, developed a tingling sensation in the mouth, swelling of the face, lips, and tongue, and also complained of abdominal pain and dizziness. What type of reaction is this?
questions.solution:
This is an example of an IgE-mediated, type I hypersensitivity reaction. 

The primary mediators are histamine and serotonin. The secondary mediators are prostaglandins and leukotrienes. The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mild rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis.
