questions.text: A 14-year-old male patient presents with pain around the knee joint. His radiographic image is given below. Which among the following is the management for the condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the x-ray image showing the sunburst appearance and Codman's triangle, in the proximal tibia are suggestive of osteosarcoma, and the management for this patient would be wide excision.

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone with bimodal age of distribution peaking in adolescence and during the 7th decade. The most common site involved is the distal femoral metaphysis which mainly presents with pain and swelling. Other sites commonly involved are the proximal tibia, proximal femur, and humerus.

X-rays are diagnostic showing Codman’s triangle (new bone formation in response to periosteal elevation) and a ‘sunburst’ appearance when the periosteum does not have enough time to lay down a new layer. 

Wide excision and reconstruction are preferred if the tumor is resectable and there are no skip lesions. It is done after starting neoadjuvant chemotherapy for 8-12 weeks. Chemotherapeutic agents used are doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate.

Other options:

Option A: Curettage is mainly used for the management of giant cell tumors. It is a benign, locally aggressive tumor presenting in the 2nd-4th decade with distal femoral metaphysis or epiphysis as the most common site. Radiographic findings include solitary lytic lesions and soap bubble appearance shown below.

Option B: Radiofrequency ablation is the preferred treatment for osteoid osteoma. It is a benign tumor formed of osteoid and woven bone. It is common in men and most commonly occurs in the diaphysis of the femur.

Option D: Intralesional steroids are used in the management of simple bone cysts that occur most commonly in males near the metaphyseal areas.

questions.text: While working as a resident in a hospital, you are asked by the consultant to prescribe a certain proton-pump inhibitor (PPI). It should be given only orally once daily before breakfast, even though it has a half-life of no more than 3 hours. What is the rationale behind this once-daily dosing?

choices.text: The drug can inhibit all gastric pumps.
The drug irreversibly inactivates the pump molecule.
The drug is gradually released irrespective of its formulation.
The drug suppresses basal but not stimulated acid production.

questions.solution:
The rationale behind the once-daily dosing is that the drug irreversibly inactivates the pump molecule.

Proton-pump inhibitors (PPIs) are prodrugs that are activated only after undergoing an acid-catalyzed cleavage in the canaliculi of the parietal cells of the stomach.

On administration, they are absorbed in the proximal small bowel and eventually, block the H+/K+ ATPase enzyme, the "proton pump" in the parietal cells of the stomach. The secretion of protons by an activated H+/K+- ATPase (proton pump) in the parietal cells into the gastric lumen is the final step involved in the production of gastric acid and inhibition of this enzyme prevents acid secretion into the stomach.

Once PPIs irreversibly inactivate the H+K+-ATPase pump, acid secretion resumes only after new pump molecules are synthesized and inserted into the luminal membrane. This leads to prolonged suppression of acid secretion for up to 24-48 hours, despite having a shorter plasma half-life of only 30 minutes to 3 hours.

In most individuals, once-daily dosing is enough to achieve effective acid inhibition. If necessary, a second dose can be given before an evening meal.

The number of H+K+-ATPase pump molecules increases after fasting and food decreases the oral bioavailability of the drug. Hence, PPIs are given around 30 minutes before the first meal of the day.

PPIs cannot inhibit all gastric acid pumps with oral dosing because not all pumps are active during the short half-life of the PPI in the blood. 

PPIs cause maximum suppression of gastric acid. They reduce the daily production of both basal and stimulated acid secretion by 85–90%. 

There are available in the form of delayed-release tablets, capsules, and oral suspension packets and for immediate acid suppression, there are intravenous formulations for PPIs like lansoprazole, pantoprazole, and esomeprazole. Therefore, the release of the drug depends upon the drug formulation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man files a case against a surgeon who left a cotton swab inside his abdomen after a hernia repair. Which of the following best describes this scenario of medical negligence?
questions.solution:
Res ipsa loquitur best describes this scenario under medical negligence.

Res ipsa loquitur means the facts of the case speak for themselves.

Normally, in cases of medical negligence, the burden of proof lies on the patient to prove the doctor guilty. However, the patient need not prove any negligence under Res ipsa loquitur.

The conditions to be fulfilled for Res Ipsa Loquitur are:

  • The injury or damage would not have occurred without negligence
  • The doctor is in exclusive control of the instrumentation or circumstances
  • The patient must not contribute to his own injury or damage

Several situations can be used as defenses by the doctor against medical negligence. This includes no duty owed to the plaintiff/ patient, the doctor's duty has been discharged according to prevailing standards, a scenario of misadventure that may be therapeutic, diagnostic, and experimental, or an error of judgment.

Other options:

Option A: Res judicata under section 300 Cr. P.C states that if a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same question.

Option C: Limitation or Res indicata indicates that a suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed. But, where a breach of duty to provide care as per a particular contract between a patient and a doctor is committed, legal action can be initiated up to three years from the date of alleged negligence.

Option D: Novus Actus Interveniens is a situation where the cause of disability or death passes from the doctor to a later negligent action of some other person. It means a person is responsible not only for his actions but also for the logical consequences of those actions. For a plea of Novus actus, an element of negligence is absolutely essential.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: Decussation of ascending spinal pathways occurs mainly within the______
questions.solution:
Decussation of ascending spinal pathways occurs mainly within the spinal cord and medulla oblongata. Most of the ascending pathways and tracts do decussate or cross; however, some remain uncrossed.

Dorsal column pathway crosses in the medulla oblongata.

The anterior and lateral spinothalamic tract crosses obliquely in the spinal segments.

second-order neurons from nucleus gracilis and nucleus cuneatus continue as internal arcuate fibers >

questions.text:
Match the following splints and the conditions where they are used.
  1. Cervical spine injury
  2. Brachial plexus injury
  3. Radial nerve palsy
  4. Ulnar nerve palsy
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a.

  1. Knuckle bender splint - Ulnar nerve palsy
  2. Cock-up splint  - Radial nerve palsy
  3. Aeroplane splint - Brachial plexus injury
  4. SOMI Brace - Cervical spine injury

Knuckle bender splint :

In cases of ulnar claw hand where ulnar nerve recovery is anticipated, the knuckle bender splint can be used to correct and prevent MCP (metacarpophalangeal) hyperextension.

Cock-up splint - 

it is used in the management of radial nerve palsy.

Aeroplane splint:

It is used in the management of brachial plexus injury and axillary nerve injury.

SOMI (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer) brace is used to treat cervical spine injury. 

It is a rigid cervical brace that positions the neck in alignment with the spine and immobilizes it. The SOMI brace may be used as a treatment for cervical spine injury or for cervical pain due to a chronic condition, such as rheumatoid arthritis. It may also be prescribed after cervical spine surgery as a recovery aid.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male is diagnosed with G6PD deficiency. Which of the following drugs is not contraindicated in his condition?
questions.solution:
Ceftriaxone is not contraindicated in G6PD deficient individuals as it does not possess oxidizing properties, hence there is no hemolysis.

Glucose-6 phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is the most common enzyme deficiency seen worldwide. Men are more commonly affected than women due to X-linked inheritance. G-6PD is an enzyme found in the cytoplasm of all cells in the human body. This enzyme plays a vital role in preventing cellular damage from reactive oxygen species.

Drugs having the potential to cause hemolysis in G6PD deficient individuals:

  • Anti-malarials - Primaquine, chloroquine, quinine, pyrimethamine, proguanil
  • Sulfonamides - Cotrimoxazole
  • Fluoroquinolones - Nalidixic acid
  • Nitro furan antibacterial - Furazolidone, nitrofurantoin
  • Anti-hypertensives - Methyldopa, hydralazine
  • Anti-convulsants - Phenytoin
  • Anti-arrhythmic - Procainamide

questions.text: A young girl is brought by their parents due to concern about her height. On evaluation, growth hormone levels are found to be high, and insulin-like growth factor levels are low. Which among the following is the likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
The presence of high GH levels and low insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels point towards Laron dwarfism. 

It is caused by end-organ resistance to growth hormone(GH insensitivity) due to a mutation in the GH receptor. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder with clinical features like those seen in pituitary dwarfism.

Here, growth hormone is produced but is unable to act on the target tissues. Thus, the resting and stimulated GH levels are high and IGF-1 levels are low.

Patients with Laron syndrome present with features such as:

  • Growth failure
  • Small head circumference
  • Characteristic facies with saddle nose and prominent forehead
  • Short limb length compared with trunk
  • Osteopenia
  • Obesity
  • In some cases mild to moderately impaired intellect may be seen

Other options

Option A: In Turner's syndrome, loss of the short arm of the X chromosome is implicated in dwarfism. The short stature occurs due to a state of GH resistance, relative deficiency, and decreased utilization.

Option B: Pituitary dwarfism is a condition with GH deficiency.

Option D: Maternal deprivation dwarfism is due to psychosocial causes such as emotional deprivation and neglect. There is an inadequate response to GH stimulation tests. The mechanism is not fully understood. No history suggestive of disturbed maternal or family relationships rules this out.

questions.text: A middle-aged male presents with dull aching epigastric pain. He gives a history of acute abdominal pain following an episode of binge drinking 5 weeks back which was managed conservatively. On examination, he appears icteric and a firm mass was palpable in the epigastrium. His CT scan is given below.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of acute pancreatitis, epigastric mass, and the CT image showing a cyst is suggestive of pancreatic pseudocyst. The capsule of the cyst is composed of collagen and granulation tissue, and it is not lined by epithelium. Hence, it is called a pseudocyst.

Pseudocysts are post-inflammatory cysts that arise following an attack of mild acute pancreatitis. Formation of a pseudocyst requires 4 weeks or more from the onset of acute pancreatitis. They are also the most common complication of chronic pancreatitis.

Pseudocysts are usually solitary and most commonly seen in the lesser omental sac. The most common artery involved is the splenic artery.

 Complications of pancreatic pseudocyst include:

  • Abscess
  • Systemic sepsis
  • GI bleeding
  • Fistula formation
  • Peritonitis
  • Obstructive jaundice
  • Bowel obstruction
  • Hemorrhage into the cyst
  • Hemoperitoneum

Pancreatic pseudo­cysts can be distinguished from cystic neoplasms by having high amylase levels and absence of mucin and low serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels.

Related Pearl: Causes of acute pancreatitis

Common causes

  • Gallstones - most common
  • Alcohol
  • Post-ERCP (Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography)
  • Blunt trauma, abdomen
  • Post-operative (cardiothoracic, upper gastrointestinal, biliary)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction

Uncommon causes

  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Deficiency of apolipoprotein CII
  • Pancreas divisum
  • Periampullary diverticulum
  • Vasculitis
  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)
  • Connective tissue disorders
  • Ischemic–hypoperfusion states
  • Hereditary pancreatitis
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Renal failure

Drugs

  • L-Asparaginase
  • Steroids
  • Sulfonamides
  • Tetracycline
  • Valproate
  • Azathioprine
  • Anti-retroviral drugs
  • Estrogens
  • Thiazide diuretics

Rare causes

  • Autoimmune
  • Infections (mumps, coxsackie B, cytomegalovirus, parasite)
  • Malnutrition
  • Scorpion bite

Related Pearl: Clinical features of acute pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: discoloration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Laboratory findings in acute pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity.
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later.
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT).
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida delivers a preterm baby at 33 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2 kg. She is advised to hold her child as shown below.  Which of the following statements about this method is false?

choices.text: Safety and thermal protection provided by this method is comparable to incubators
Should be performed only by the mother

questions.solution:
Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) can be carried out by the mother or any other caregiver.

KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns. It has 4 components—

  • Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother’s chest.
  • Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care.
  • Support for mother and family for child care.

Evidence shows that-

  • It is at least equivalent to incubators, in terms of safety and thermal protection (measured by mortality)
  • Reduces severe morbidity by way of facilitating breastfeeding
  • Humanization of neonatal care
  • Promoted bonding between mother and child

Eligibiilty criteria for KMC:

It is indicated for all hemodynamically stable low birthweight babies. Short sessions of KMC can be initiated in babies on medical treatment like IV fluids or oxygen therapy. Initiation of KMC can vary with the birth weight of the baby.

  • Birthweight <1200 g - It may take days to weeks for initiation of KMC
  • Birthweight 1200-1800 g - Only a few days may be taken before KMC initiation
  • Birthweight >1800 g - KMC can be initiated immediately after birth

All mothers without any serious illness can provide KMC

Positioning for KMC: The baby is placed between the mother's breast in an upright position. The hips are abducted and flexed in the frog position and the arms are also flexed. The abdomen of the baby should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. In this position, the mother's breathing would stimulate the baby and prevent the development of apnea.

The duration of KMC should be gradually increased from short sessions of more than one hour to 24 hours a day.

KMC is not necessary once the baby attains 2500 g of weight or 37 weeks of gestation.

Note: 

Incubatory care, feeding via nasal catheter, and prevention of infection are part of intensive care for low birthweight babies.

questions.text: A young boy presented with a cystic swelling on the left side of the floor of the mouth as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image of a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth are suggestive of a ranula.

Ranula is a mucus extravasation cyst arising from the sublingual gland. It produces a characteristic translucent swelling that gives the appearance of a frog’s belly. A ranula usually resolves spontaneously.  

A plunging ranula is a mucus retention cyst. It has mucus collecting below the gland and perforating through the mylohyoid muscle.

Other options:

Options A: Ectopic thyroid tissue is a developmental defect of the thyroid gland and is frequently found along the course of the thyroglossal duct. Lingual thyroid is the most common presentation of ectopic thyroid (shown below).

Option B: Cystic hygroma is usually seen in neonates and early childhood. They are cystic swellings filled with lymph fluid and are characteristically brilliantly translucent. They occur in the neck and can involve the parotid, submandibular, tongue, etc. The swelling is soft and partially compressible. Definitive treatment is the excision of the swelling. 

Option C: Ludwig's angina is a brawny swelling of the submandibular region that is caused by streptococcal infection. The infection tracks down to the mylohyoid muscle causing inflammation that displaces the tongue leading to dysphagia and painful airway obstruction. Management is by antibiotic therapy and decompression of the floor of the mouth by incising mylohyoid muscle.

questions.text: While prescribing levonorgestrel as post-coital emergency contraception, you would advise for ______.

choices.text: 5 mg single dose within 24 hours of unprotected intercourse
0.75 mg single dose within 24 hours of unprotected intercourse
3 mg single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse
1.5 mg single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse

questions.solution:
Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse can be used for emergency contraception. Alternatively, it can also be administered in two doses of 0.75 mg. 1st dose is taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse and the 2nd dose 12 hours apart. 

Emergency contraception refers to backup methods for contraceptive emergencies which women can use within the first few days after unprotected intercourse to prevent an unwanted pregnancy. Administration of postcoital contraceptive agents that interfere with postovulatory events that can lead to pregnancy. 

The various emergency contraceptive methods along with their mechanism of action have been described below:

  • IUCD (intrauterine contraceptive device) prevents the implantation of a fertilized ovum. It does so by acting as a foreign body within the uterine cavity. This leads to increased contractility, and tubal peristalsis, and promotes leukocytic infiltration in the endometrium. 
  • Ulipristal is given as a 30 mg tablet and should be taken within 5 days. It is a synthetic progesterone hormone receptor modulator. The drug attaches to the progesterone receptor, delays ovulation, and suppresses endometrium, thereby preventing implantation.
  • Ethinyl estradiol 50 μg + norgestrel 0.25 mg is administered as two tablets within 72 hours of coitus followed by the 2 tablets after 12 hours. The hormone may delay ovulation if taken soon after intercourse. 
  • Centchroman is administered as two tablets of 60 mg taken twice over a duration of 24 hours and within 24 hours of intercourse. It acts by preventing the implantation of the blastocyst in the endometrium. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A man underwent vasectomy recently.  The surgeon advises the patient to abstain from sexual activity for a certain period after the procedure before confirming the success of the vasectomy. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding the duration of abstinence post-vasectomy?

choices.text: 3 months and after semen analysis is done
1 month and after semen analysis is done

questions.solution:
A patient who has undergone a vasectomy should abstain from sexual activity for 3 months and undergo a semen analysis afterwards.

Vasectomy is a permanent sterilization procedure done in males, where a segment of the vas deferens is resected and ligated bilaterally.

This procedure is done under local anesthesia. A small incision is made in the scrotum. The vas deferens are divided on both sides, disrupting the passage of sperms. The no-scalpel technique has been now adopted. One single incision is made with special forceps and a skin stitch is not required. Clips and plugs can be applied over the vas instead of cutting. The failure rate of vasectomy is 0.15%.

It is a relatively simple procedure with low rates of complications. A patient who had a vasectomy is not sterile immediately after the procedure as semen is stored in distal channels of the vas deferens for varying periods.

Hence, for this reason, it is estimated that at least 20 ejaculations or 3 months are required to empty the stored semen. During this time, additional contraceptive measures should be used.

questions.text: A young male patient presented with pain and stiffness in the neck following an accident. On examination, the right shoulder is drooping and he has difficulty shrugging his shoulder. Which of the following muscles is likely to be paralyzed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is indicative of paralysis of the trapezius muscle.

The trapezius is innervated by the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI). It causes: 

  • Retraction of scapula
  • Shrugging of the shoulder
  • Overhead abduction (along with serratus anterior)

Paralysis of the trapezius causes drooping of the shoulder and slight winging of the scapula (the superior angle of the scapula becomes more prominent).

Nerves causing winging of the scapula:

Nerves Muscles Type of winging
Spinal accessory nerve

Trapezius

 The superior angle of the scapula becomes more prominent (lateral winging)
Long thoracic nerve

Serratus anterior

 The scapula is pulled upwards and towards the spine by the unopposed action of the trapezius (medial winging)
Dorsal scapular nerve Rhomboid major, and rhomboid minor Similar to serratus anterior but mild winging

questions.text: A young male who is a professional trumpet blower presents with swelling on the left side of his neck. Examination reveals a gurgling sound on compression of the swelling. X-ray of the neck is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image along with the examination finding of Bryce sign (on compressing the swelling, there is a gurgling sound) is suggestive of laryngocoele.

Laryngocoele:

  • Air filled cavity within the larynx developing in the saccule.
  • Patient presents with a neck swelling that is soft and compressible.
  • Bryce sign.

Other options:

Option A: Zenker diverticulum or pharyngeal pouch is a pulsion-pseudodiverticulum and results from herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian triangle (or dehiscence of Killian). Killian's triangle is an area of muscular weakness between the transverse fibres of the cricopharyngeus and the oblique fibres of the thyropharyngeus.

Option C: A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal fistula communication between the Esophagus and Trachea. Type C lesion is associated with proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF, the proximal blind pouch ends approximately at the distance of one or two vertebral bodies from the distal TEF.

Option D: Tonsillar cyst is due to blockage of a tonsillar crypt and appears as a yellowish swelling over the tonsil. Very often it is symptomless. It can be easily drained.

questions.text: An elderly patient with ventricular tachycardia has been started on amiodarone. Which of the following is the most important adverse event associated with this drug's use?
questions.solution:
The most important adverse event associated with the use of amiodarone is pulmonary fibrosis. 

Amiodarone is a class three anti-arrhythmic that is primarily used in the treatment of supraventricular arrhythmias, ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.

Pulmonary fibrosis is usually seen in patients who take prolonged courses of amiodarone and in high doses.

Pulmonary fibrosis can be potentially life-threatening and requires immediate discontinuation of the amiodarone and initiation of high-dose corticosteroids.

Other adverse events associated with amiodarone use are nausea, photosensitivity, corneal microdeposits and thyroid dysfunction.

Other options:

Option B: Central nervous system toxicity. There are no significant central nervous system-related adverse events. In a minority of patients, peripheral neuropathy presenting as shoulder and pelvic muscle weakness is seen.

Option C: Renal dysfunction is not seen with Amiodarone since it is hepatically cleared.

Option D: Ototoxicity is associated with prolonged aminoglycoside use and is not a feature of amiodarone toxicity.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes for an evaluation of blood pressure. He had a history of occasional flank pain. His BP was found to be 160/90 mm Hg. Further evaluation with CT was done and the finding is shown below. What could be the possible diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The CT shows the presence of multiple cysts in the kidney. This CT finding along with the clinical features of the patient is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). 

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1(chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4). 

ADPDK is characterized by the progressive formation of epithelial-lined cysts in the bilateral kidneys that ultimately leads to the loss of normal functioning renal tissue. Many patients do not have any symptoms until they are 40-50 years of age. The clinical manifestations include flank pain, hematuria (from cyst rupture), and hypertension due to increased Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone System (RAAS) activation.

Extrarenal manifestations of the disease include benign hepatic cysts, intracranial aneurysms, mitral valve prolapse, and colonic diverticula.

Intravenous pyelography shows characteristic spider leg sign, as a result of stretched calyces due to multiple cysts. The nephrogram shows a swiss cheese appearance. On prenatal USG, the presence of either > 3 cysts in unilateral kidneys or > 2 cysts in each kidney is suggestive of PKD. 

Other options:

Option A and C: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) and acute pyelonephritis, show striated nephrogram on CT nephrography (as shown below).

Option D: Renal angiomyolipoma show well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue on CT imaging.

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure
  • The commonest cause of abdominal mass in children

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: Which of the following is a negative regulator of Glycogen phosphorylase?
questions.solution:
Glycogen phosphorylase is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycogenolysis and is decreased in the fed state. It catalyzes the cleavage of α1 → 4 linkages of glycogen to single units of glucose 1-phosphate. It uses pyridoxal phosphate (vitamin B6) as the coenzyme. During glycogenolysis, glucose 6-phosphate allosterically inhibits glycogen phosphorylase. Insulin entirely suppresses glycogenolysis in the skeletal muscle and liver.

Negative regulators of Glycogen phosphorylase include:

  • Glucose-6-phosphate
  • Insulin
  • ATP

Positive regulators of Glycogen phosphorylase include:

  • Epinephrine
  • Glucagon
  • AMP

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. His CT scan is shown below. Which among the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan shows splenic laceration. 

Splenic lacerations are linear low attenuation parenchymal defects and are almost always associated with haemoperitoneum.

The spleen is the visceral organ most commonly injured in blunt trauma abdomen. Severely ill patients may present with hypovolemic shock manifesting as tachycardia, hypotension, and pallor. A splenic rupture may not always be clinically apparent and spontaneous splenic rupture or pathological rupture can occur after minor trauma or insignificant events.

The investigation of choice in blunt trauma abdomen is CECT.

Splenic injury are currently classified into five grades based on the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) splenic injury scale (revised in 2018).

Management of splenic trauma:

  • Nonoperative management is preferred for stable grade I, II, or III splenic injuries.
  • Splenectomy is done for grade IV and V injuries.

questions.text: The image below shows the process of DNA replication. Identify the disease associated with the defect of the enzyme marked by the blue arrow.
questions.solution:
The enzyme marked in the blue arrow, involved in the unwinding of the DNA template at the replication fork is DNA helicase. The disease associated with its defect is Werner syndrome.

Werner syndrome is a premature aging disorder, caused by mutations in the WRN gene. The mutated gene encodes a DNA helicase. DNA helicase is involved in DNA replication and repair. It is responsible for the ATP-driven unwinding of DNA. A defect in this enzyme causes rapid accumulation of damaged chromosomes that may mimic the injury that normally accumulates during cellular aging. Affected persons show various manifestations of premature aging including atherosclerosis, senile cataract, skin atrophy, alopecia, osteoporosis, etc.

Werner syndrome should not be confused with Wermer syndrome, a.k.a. MEN-1 syndrome (multiple endocrine neoplasias- type 1), a heritable disorder characterized by abnormalities involving the parathyroid, pancreas, and pituitary gland.

questions.text: The middle radioulnar joint is an example of :
questions.solution:
The middle radioulnar joint is a type of fibrous joint called syndesmosis.

Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna, in the middle, are connected by two syndesmoses namely:

  • The oblique cord - extends from the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity to the radius, distal to the radial tuberosity.
  • Interosseous membrane - a broad, thin collagenous structure, which runs perpendicular to the oblique cord. It extends distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna.

Based on the structure, joints are classified into three types:

1. Fibrous
  • Sutures - Peculiar to the skull. (Eg:joints between skull bones)
  • Syndesmoses - There is a true fibrous connection between bones. ( Eg: distal tibiofibular joint, middle radioulnar join )
  • Gomphose - A peg sits inside a socket supported by fibrous connections. (Eg: joint between teeth and teeth sockets in mandibular/maxillary bone)

2. Cartilaginous

  • Synchondrosis - primary cartilaginous (Eg:costochondral joints)
  • Symphysis - secondary cartilaginous (Eg:manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints)

3. Synovial

  • Ball-and-socket or spheroidal joints
  • Sellar or saddle joints
  • Condylar or bicondylar joints
  • Ellipsoid joints
  • Hinge joints
  • Pivot or trochoid joints
  • Plane joints

questions.text: A 4-year child is brought to the pediatrician for the evaluation of the neck mass. On examination, a painless, soft, fluctuating mass is found on the posterior triangle of the neck as shown in the image below. The slip sign is negative and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A soft, painless, fluctuating mass found in the posterior part of the neck in a child, is most likely to be a cystic hygroma.

Cystic hygroma is a benign lymph-filled sac that results from obstruction of lymph vessels during development. It is commonly seen during early infancy or diagnosed during prenatal ultrasound. It is present in the lateral part of the neck. It is soft, fluctuating, and brilliantly translucent.

Clinical presentation depends on the anatomical site of the swelling and patients may present with symptoms such as pain, hoarseness, dysphagia, or shortness of breath.

Treatment:

  • Aspiration of the contents, followed by excision once the sac or capsule gets thickened by fibrous tissue.
  • Single cysts can be treated with sclerosing therapy. Commonly used sclerosants include OK–432 or Picibanil, which is a mixture of group A Streptococcus pyogenes strain, pure ethanol, interferon alpha-2a, and doxycycline.
  • Complete excision is done in case of multiple cysts.

Other options: 

Option B: A branchial cleft cyst also presents as soft fluctuant swelling in the lateral part of the neck. It is present in the anterior neck and at the junction of the upper third and middle third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

Option C: Lipomas present as a painless, slow-growing, soft and mobile mass of the subcutaneous tissue. They do not transilluminate. The swelling is non-fluctuant and when palpated, the edge slips under the finger. This is known as the slip sign.

Option D: Cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common cause of a neck mass in a child. It is due to infections of oral and nasal cavities, pharynx, larynx, ear, and scalp or face. It can be found laterally or in the midline. On palpation, they are firm, tender and can become fluctuant in case of an abscess.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was brought to the emergency room with complaints of continuous diarrhea with rice water stools. A microscopic examination of a stool sample is shown in the image below. All the following can be used as a transport medium for this causative organism except?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette consisting of rice water stools and the image showing the characteristic fish in stream appearance is suggestive of Vibrio cholerae for which Stuart media cannot be used as a transport medium. Stuart media is used as a transport medium for the Neisseria group of organisms.

Transport media for Vibrio cholerae include: 

  • Venkatraman Ramakrishnan (VR) medium
  • Cary Blair medium
  • Autoclaved seawater.  

Enrichment media for Vibrio cholerae include:

  • Alkaline peptone water at a pH of 8.6
  • Monsur's taurocholate tellurite peptone water at a pH of 9.2.

Both these enrichment media are good transport mediums as well.

questions.text: A young boy presents to the emergency department after being at a party. He says he tasted a small colorful graphic blotting paper while at the party. Within minutes, he had started to feel his heart race, had profuse sweating and tremors, and was rushed to the hospital. Later, he develops extreme paranoia and extreme panic and starts crying. Examination of the eyes shows mydriasis. Which of the following drugs did he most likely consume?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) abuse. The patient developed extreme panic and paranoia after tasting a small colourful blotting paper, which is suggestive of a bad trip. Other features that support this diagnosis are palpitation, profuse sweating, tremors, and pupillary dilation.

LSD is the most powerful hallucinogen known to man. Increased sympathetic activity like tachycardia, hypertension, pupillary dilation, tremor, and fever can be seen within minutes of oral intake. Apart from this, the users may have psychiatric symptoms like visual illusions, extreme changes in mood, paranoid delusions, etc. Patients may experience bad trips, where they have panic episodes. Prolonged experience without further exposure to drugs known as “flashbacks" can also result from LSD use. 

Stopping the drug abruptly after continued use does not produce withdrawal symptoms. Management of bad trips due to LSD abuse involves supportive treatment with anxiolytics.

Other named effects of drug use:

  • Amotivational syndrome - Chronic use of cannabis may lead to amotivational syndrome with lethargy and lack of interest in day-to-day activities.
  • Run amok - This is a psychic disturbance resulting from continued use or sudden consumption of Cannabis and is characterized by a peculiar homicidal mania.
  • Magnan syndrome - This is a type of tactile hallucination seen in chronic users of cocaine where they feel as if grains of sand are under the skin or insects are creeping on the skin (formication)

Option A: Cannabis intoxication causes feelings of detachment, euphoria, relaxation, decreased concentration, and attention span. Images appear vivid. There is increased thirst and appetite.

Option B: Amphetamine intoxication also gives rise to similar clinical features like tachycardia, hypertension, sweating, tremors, dilated pupils, and paranoia. However, the ingestion of blotting paper, makes LSD more likely as it is most often sold on blotter paper. 

Option C: Cocaine intoxication may also have similar features, like tachycardia, hypertension, sweating, dilated pupils, and altered behaviour. It also causes anaesthesia in the area that has been in direct contact with the drug. Magnan syndrome may also be seen.

questions.text: A patient presents with diffuse abdominal pain, and on examination, there is generalised tenderness along with board-like abdominal rigidity. An X-ray of the abdomen is provided. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the chest radiograph showing air under the diaphragm are suggestive of a hollow viscus perforation resulting in perforation peritonitis.

Perforation of a viscus is a life-threatening condition that occurs following the rupture of the alimentary tract. This leads to the leakage of the enteric contents, thereby leading to acute bacterial peritonitis. Peritonitis is the generalized or localized inflammation of the peritoneum either due to the free spillage of fluids into the peritoneal cavity or secondary bacterial infection.

Clinical features of hollow viscous perforation occur due to the developed peritonitis and the features include abdominal pain and distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, decreased or absent bowel sounds, and guarding on palpation. Fever may be present. Sometimes, features of septic shock can be seen at later stages.

Investigations include estimating the white blood cell count, urea, serum electrolytes, and an erect abdominal radiograph showing free gas under the diaphragm. A supine radiograph may show dilated gas-filled loops of the bowel, suggestive of paralytic ileus. The below image shows a hollow viscus perforation.

Management of a hollow viscous perforation is mainly resuscitation, analgesics, intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics, and emergency laparotomy. Peritonitis is managed by nutritional support, pain relief, correction of fluid loss and circulating volume, urinary catheterization with or without gastrointestinal compression, antibiotics, analgesics, and specific surgical treatment of the cause.

Other Options: 

Option A: Clinical presentation of acute pancreatitis is characterized by epigastric pain radiating to the back which is relieved by bending forward, nausea, and vomiting. 

Option C: Duodenal ulcer pain occurs 1.5 to 3 hours after a meal and is frequently relieved by antacids or food. Gastric Ulcer pain/discomfort may be precipitated by food. Nausea and weight loss are common.

Option D: A hiatal hernia occurs when a portion of the stomach pushes through the diaphragm into the chest cavity. It can cause symptoms such as heartburn, regurgitation, and chest pain, and may require medical or surgical treatment.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to defective
questions.solution:
Respiratory distress syndrome is due to defective type 2 pneumocytes which produce lung surfactants.

Respiratory distress syndrome is a condition seen in premature infants due to a deficiency of pulmonary surfactant in an immature lung.

Pulmonary surfactants are made up of a mixture of lipids, phospholipids, and proteins. The surfactants decrease alveolar surface tension thereby facilitating expansion and preventing atelectasis. In a preterm infant, there is a decrease in both the quantity and quality of the surfactant.

The primary alveoli develop and the production of the surfactant begins by weeks 20-24. However, it does not reach the lungs until later. The surfactant appears in the amniotic fluid between 28 and 32 weeks of gestation. Mature levels of the pulmonary surfactant are present usually after 35 weeks of gestation.

Clinically this condition presents immediately after birth and findings such as tachypnea, nasal flaring, expiratory grunting, subcostal retractions, and cyanosis may be seen.

Antenatal corticosteroids are given to increase the production of surfactants in premature infants.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient who is on medication for benign prostatic hyperplasia was posted for cataract surgery. Intraoperatively, the surgeon noticed a floppy iris with progressive intraoperative pupillary constriction. Which of the following is the most likely drug responsible for the above features?
questions.solution:
The most likely drug responsible for the above features is tamsulosin.

The above clinical scenario with a history of medication for benign prostatic hyperplasia and the intraoperative finding of floppy iris with progressive pupillary constriction is suggestive of floppy iris syndrome. Tamsulosin causes floppy iris syndrome.

Tamsulosin is an α1 receptor antagonist with receptor selectivity at α1A and α1D receptors. This selectivity causes a blockade of the α1A receptor in the prostate. It is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. It has very little effect on blood pressure due to its selective effect on α1A and α1D and hence is not used in the treatment of hypertension.

Some of the adverse effects of tamsulosin include orthostatic hypotension, abnormal ejaculation, and floppy iris syndrome.

Intraoperative floppy iris syndrome is characterized by a triad of the following features:

  • flaccid iris billowing through the surgical incision
  • iris prolapse
  • intraoperative pupillary constriction

Examples of other drugs causing floppy iris syndrome include finasteride, benzodiazepines, donepezil, and duloxetine. Some α1 receptor antagonists like alfuzosin, doxazosin, and terazosin are associated with floppy iris syndrome but have a very low risk compared to tamsulosin.

Other options:

Option B- Prazosin is an α1 receptor antagonist with equal potency to all the subtypes of α1 receptor. It is used in the treatment of hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia(BPH). Prazosin causes orthostatic hypotension after its initial dose.

Option C- Silodosin is an α1 receptor antagonist with more selectivity over the α1 subtype. It is approved in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia with lesser effects on blood pressure. The main adverse effect is retrograde ejaculation. Dizziness and orthostatic hypotension can also be seen.

Option D- Dutasteride is a 5α-reductase inhibitor that blocks the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. It is approved in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Impotence is a documented side effect and gynecomastia is a rare side effect.

Related Pearl: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

questions.text: Which among the following represents the karyotype of a partial mole?
questions.solution:
Image 4 represents a partial mole.

Molar pregnancies arise from chromosomally abnor­mal fertilizations.

Partial moles are formed when two sets of haploid paternal chromosomes fertilize one set of maternal haploid chromosomes. This results in a triploid karyotype (69XX, 69XY, or rarely 69YY). The two sets of paternal chromosomes are contributed by dispermic fertilization or dispermy (two sperms fertilizing one egg).

Complete moles are formed when an ovum containing inactivated or absent chromosomes gets fertilized by a haploid sperm. The zygote then duplicates after meiosis resulting in a diploid karyotype. Complete moles result from androgenesis, which means that both sets of chromosomes are paternal. Less commonly, the ovum with inactivated or absent chromosomes may be fertilized by two sperms (dispermic fertilization).

 

Image 3 in the question represents the normal fertilization of a haploid sperm with a haploid ovum.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female patient who is known to have Bell's palsy presented with dryness in her left eye. Ocular examination reveals mild punctate epithelial defects and dryness of the cornea. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with clinical features of dry eye and unilateral facial nerve palsy (Bell's palsy) likely has a diagnosis of exposure keratopathy. 

Exposure keratopathy is the drying of the cornea despite normally produced tears. It occurs due to incomplete eyelid closure, also known as lagophthalmos.

Lagophthalmos can be caused by conditions such as facial nerve palsy, parkinsonism (reduced muscle tone), lid scarring, and proptosis. 

Clinical features include dry eyes, symptoms, and signs of mild punctate epithelial changes and epithelial breakdown. 

Treatment depends on whether the exposure is reversible or permanent. Reversible exposure can be treated with artificial tears and eye ointments. The eyelid can be taped closed at night or external barriers like bandage silicone hydrogel or scleral contact lenses can be used. Permanent exposure requires permanent tarsorrhaphy.

Other options: 

Option B - Neurotrophic keratopathy is the loss/reduction of corneal sensation that occurs due to loss of innervation by the trigeminal nerve. It may be due to stroke, trigeminal ganglion ablation for neuralgia, diabetes, etc. 

Option C - Mooren ulcer is an autoimmune disorder that results in progressive peripheral corneal ulceration. This is characterized by severe pain and the involvement of the superficial one-third of the corneal stroma.

Option D - Herpes simplex keratitis is caused by the Herpes simplex virus (HSV). The patient complains of ocular discomfort, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity. HSV can cause characteristic epithelial (dendritic/geographic) keratitis or disciform keratitis.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with a history of headache since a few weeks and an inability to visualise his lateral fields. Examination shows the following findings. What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.solution:
The visual field defect in the image is indicative of bitemporal hemianopia, so the probable site of the lesion is the optic chiasma.

Hemianopia or hemianopsia refers to loss of sight in half the visual field. Bitemporal hemianopia refers to loss of sight in the temporal halves of the visual field, seen in lesions affecting the optic chiasma. The most common cause of this is pituitary gland tumours. Other causes include suprasellar aneurysms, chronic arachnoiditis, and suprasellar tumours like craniopharyngioma and suprasellar meningioma.

Damage to the middle part of the optic chiasm affects fibres crossing at the nasal retina of each eye, leaving the uncrossed fibres from the temporal retinas intact. The resulting loss of vision is confined to the temporal visual field of each eye and this is known as bitemporal hemianopia. It is also called heteronymous hemianopia to emphasize the fact that the parts of the visual field that are lost in each eye do not overlap.

Individuals with this condition are able to see in both left and right central visual fields, with both eyes open. However, all information from the most peripheral parts of visual fields (which are seen only by the nasal retinas) is lost.

Other options: 

Lesions at the occipital lobe, optic tract and optic radiation would all cause homonymous hemianopia. Here, either the right or left half of the binocular field of vision is lost, due to the loss of the temporal half of one field and the nasal half of the other.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and the site at which it is used to take samples.

choices.text: Ayre's spatula used at the squamocolumnar junction
Ayre's spatula used at the endocervix
Cytobrush used at the squamocolumnar junction

questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is a cytobrush which is used to take samples from the endocervix for Pap smear.

Ayre’s spatula is used to take samples from the squamocolumnar junction. Given below is the image of Ayre's spatula.

Pap/ Papanicolaou test is a screening test only. A positive test requires further evaluation with colposcopy, cervical biopsy, or fractional curettage.

The ideal time for the collection of a sample is around ovulation, but can be done at any other time as well. 24 hours prior to the test, patients should abstain from vaginal intercourse, douching, tampon use, and intravaginal medications.

Procedure:

The patient is put in a dorsal position and Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced. The squamocolumnar junction is identified and scraped with Ayre’s spatula. Endocervix is scarped with a cytobrush. Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides. The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol and stained with Pap stain or Short stain.

questions.text: Mollaret’s meningitis is caused by _____.
questions.solution:
Mollaret’s meningitis is most commonly caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV). 

Mollaret’s meningitis is a benign recurrent lymphocytic meningitis, caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). It is characterized by lymphocytic pleocytosis in the CSF. Demonstration of HSV antibodies in CSF or the persistence of HSV DNA in CSF can establish the diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Clinical manifestations of Herpes simplex virus

  1. Cutaneous lesions: Fever blister, herpetic whitlow, herpetic gladiatorum, eczema herpeticum. Eczema herpeticum is a generalized eruption caused by Herpes infections in children suffering from eczema
  2. Mucosal: most common site involved is buccal mucosa. It may cause Gingivostomatitis & Pharyngitis, Recurrent herpes labialis.
  3. Ophthalmic: Follicular conjunctivitis, Herpes simplex keratitis, and acute keratoconjunctivitis also occur. 
  4. Nervous System: HSV encephalitis(Temporal lobe involvement), HSV meningitis, Mollaret’s meningitis. 
  5. Genital system: Genital herpes

questions.text: A 52 year old woman presents to the ENT surgeon with a history of vertigo whenever she moves sideways on the bed while lying supine. She is nauseous and feels as if the room is spinning.  Altough the symptoms subside after a few minutes, they return when she moves her head. Which of the following is most appropriate to manage her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The therapeutic maneuver is Epley's maneuver.

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal.

A patient presenting with vertigo should be evaluated for ruling out the central lesions (like a tumor in the fourth ventricle, multiple sclerosis, etc) before confirming the diagnosis of BPPV. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver helps rule out central lesions and also diagnose BPPV.

The therapeutic maneuver is Epley's maneuver.

Epley's maneuver:

Other options:

Option A: The diagnostic manoeuvre used in BPPV is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, the gold standard for diagnosing BPPV.

Dix-Hallpike maneuver:

  1. The maneuver starts with the patient in a sitting position.
  2. Their head is turned 45 degrees towards the ear to be tested.
  3. The examiner quickly brings the patient to a supine position with their head 30 degrees below the horizontal.
  4. The 45-degree head rotation is maintained during the procedure.
  5. Now the examiner observes the patient for nystagmus.

Option B: Glycerol test provides information on the cochlear response to the osmotic changes produced by glycerol in the inner ear. It is used in Meneire's disease.

Option C: Calorie test is a test that uses differences in temperature to diagnose damage to the acoustic nerve. This is the nerve that is involved in hearing and balance. The test also checks for damage to the brain stem.

questions.text: All of the following drugs can be used in the management of hypertension in pregnancy except for?
questions.solution:
Enalapril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor and it is contraindicated in pregnancy.

Enalapril is an ACE-Inhibitor which is contraindicated in pregnancy due to potential teratogenic side effects like renal dysplasia and renal failure.

ACE inhibitors inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to the potent vasoconstrictor angiotensin-II. When given in the second and third trimesters, they can cause severe fetal malformations such as bony malformations, persistent patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), respiratory distress syndrome, limb contracture, etc.

Choice of anti-hypertensives in pregnancy:

Pregnancy-induced hypertension/pre-eclampsia / severe pre-eclampsia Labetalol
Acute hypertension/ Hypertensive crisis IV labetalol, nifedipine, hydralazine
Chronic hypertension in pregnancy Labetalol > methyl dopa.

Anti-hypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy include:

  • ACE inhibitors.
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers.
  • Diuretics (contraindicated as anti-hypertensive but can be given in congestive cardiac failure).
  • Reserpine.
  • Sodium nitroprusside (used only as a drug of last resort in refractory severe hypertension).
  • Diazoxide.

A Fistula is present between the gallbladder and common bile duct

questions.solution:
A palpable gallbladder will not rule out gallstones in Mirizzi syndrome. It is an exception to Courvoisier's law.

Courvoisier's law states that in the presence of a painless, palpable, enlarged gallbladder and mild jaundice, the cause is unlikely to be gallstones. Its exceptions include:

  • Double impacted stones (stones in both the cystic duct and the distal common bile duct)
  • Primary CBD stone
  • Oriental cholangiohepatitis 
  • Mirizzi's syndrome

In Mirizzi’s syndrome, gallstones become impacted in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder due to inflammation. This causes common bile duct (CBD) obstruction and jaundice. The gallbladder is distended and may be palpable.

ERCP, PTC (Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography), or MRCP will usually demonstrate the characteristic extrinsic compression of the CBD. 

Surgery consists of removing the cystic duct, diseased gallbladder, and the impacted stone. In patients whose gallbladder is densely adherent to the common bile duct, partial cholecystectomy should be done.

If left untreated, a fistula forms between the gallbladder and common bile duct (cholecysto-choledochal fistula).

Related Pearl: Mirizzi’s syndrome

Gallstone becomes impacted in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder producing CBD obstruction and jaundice.

  • Surgery consists of removing the cystic duct, diseased gallbladder, and the impacted stone.

questions.text: A middle-aged man has been recently diagnosed with hypertension. He wants to try lifestyle changes before starting with pharmacological therapy. According to the rule of halves, where is he represented in the diagram, if A represents the whole population?
questions.solution:
According to the rule of halves, the person is represented in category C which represents people diagnosed with hypertension but not treated. This is because the patient has not yet started lifestyle management or pharmacotherapy.

Hypertension is a non-communicable chronic condition that is a risk factor for coronary heart disease, stroke, and other vascular complications. It is known to be an iceberg disease and the rule of halves is applied. The rule depicts the disease burden of hypertension in the community.

It states that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population are aware of the condition. Only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated.

Pictorial representation of the rule of halves in hypertension is shown below:

 

Hypertension can be prevented by primary and secondary prevention strategies. Primary prevention includes non-pharmacological measures such as lifestyle changes that are taken to reduce the incidence of the disease. It includes:

  • Population strategy approach aimed to reduce the incidence of the disease at the whole population level
  • High-risk strategy approach is done to identify high-risk individuals 

Secondary prevention includes pharmacological measures such as the usage of antihypertensives in affected individuals. It aims at early detection, adequate treatment, and follow-up of the patients to ensure proper compliance.

questions.text: A young female patient is being evaluated for recurrent first-trimester pregnancy loss. On investigation, the activated partial thromboplastin time was prolonged, and the anti-beta 2 glycoprotein antibody was positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA). 

APLA is characterized by recurrent thrombosis due to the formation of autoantibodies. It generally affects women. APLA should be considered in those under the age of 55 with recurrent thrombosis. The presence of at least one clinical and laboratory criterion is required for diagnosis. 

Clinical criteria: 

  • Vascular thrombosis with one or more episodes of thrombosis (arterial, venous, or small vessel) in any organ
  • Pregnancy morbidity
    1. With the unexplained death of a morphologically normal fetus after 10 weeks
    2. Premature birth of a morphologically normal fetus before 34th week due to preeclampsia, eclampsia, or placental insufficiency
    3. Three or more unexplained spontaneous abortions before the 10th week.

Laboratory criteria: 

  • Positive lupus anticoagulant (LA)
  • Positive anticardiolipin (aCL)
  • Positive anti-beta2GPI antibodies.

Treatment involves lifelong warfarin therapy titrated to a goal INR of 2.5-3.5. Aspirin may also be added at a dose of 80 mg. 

Other options: 

Option B - Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute condition characterized by widespread intravascular fibrin formation in response to activation of the coagulation cascade. It is not associated with LA. In addition, this patient has a chronic history of recurrent DVT and pregnancy loss. Elevated levels of fibrin degradation products are sensitive for diagnosing DIC

Option C - Trousseau syndrome, also known as migratory thrombophlebitis, is a form of systemic hypercoagulability that arises from a paraneoplastic syndrome because of procoagulant factors. There would be multiple venous thromboses that appear, disappear, and reappear in another location. 

Option D - Factor VIII deficiency is seen in hemophilia. It is a bleeding disorder and is not characterized by recurrent thrombosis. It is associated with recurrent bleeding into soft tissues, joints (hemarthrosis), and muscles as a result of trauma or spontaneous mechanism. Lab values show prolonged aPTT.

questions.text: A patient with a history of a road traffic accident 2 years back developed pain and swelling now at the same site. His radiograph images are given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is chronic osteomyelitis.

Chronic osteomyelitis may occur by direct inoculation of the infective organism during trauma (like road traffic accidents). The infection continues to thrive within the bone leading to alternating quiescent and flare-up stages of chronic osteomyelitis.

Necrosis of healthy tissue is an important feature of osteomyelitis. In patients with osteomyelitis, dead cortical bone gets separated from the healthy bone and can be visualized clearly on plain radiographs. This dead bone is termed a sequestrum.

The given image shows an oval-shaped sequestrum and periosteal new bone formation surrounding the sequestrum, known as involucrum. Along with the given clinical scenario, it is suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis of the tibia.

Option A: Osteogenic sarcoma characteristically shows the sunburst appearance and Codman's triangle, as shown below.

 Option B: Ewing's sarcoma shows an onion-skin appearance of the periosteum, as shown below.

 Option D: Multiple myeloma shows multiple punched-out lesions of the bone, as shown below.

questions.text: Identify the site marked in the image given below
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the sphenoid sinus. It drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

Paranasal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present in the bones of the skull. These paranasal sinuses have been divided into two groups:

Anterior group: It includes,

  • Maxillary sinus (Antrum of Highmore)
  • Frontal sinus
  • Anterior ethmoidal.

All of the above sinuses open into the middle meatus and their ostia lie anterior to the basal lamella of the middle turbinate.

Posterior group: It includes-

  • Posterior ethmoidal sinuses: Opens in the superior meatus 
  • Sphenoid sinus: Opens in sphenoethmoidal recess

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense cravings for food. She eats large amounts of food, which is followed by self-induced vomiting. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis in the given scenario of a 16-year-old girl with intense food cravings followed by self-induced vomiting is bulimia nervosa.

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder, often seen in young women. It is characterized by binge-eating episodes, followed by inappropriate, compensatory measures to stop weight gain, like self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, diuretics, enema, and emetic abuse. These binge-eating episodes occur at least once a week and are present for at least 3 months. The patient fears gaining weight and has a relentless drive to be thin. 

The weight is normal in most patients with bulimia nervosa. However, few patients may either be overweight or underweight. There is a risk of dehydration and electrolyte imbalance. 

Treatment modalities are cognitive behavioral therapy, psychotherapy, and antidepressants such as fluoxetine.

Other options:

Option A: Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder that is often seen between the ages of 10 and 30. Typical features are self-induced starvation, voluntary and unhealthy reduction in weight, intense drive for thinness, and fear of becoming obese. These symptoms are usually present for at least a period of 3 months. Associated features can include depression, anxiety, amenorrhea in females, hypothermia, and bradycardia. 

Option C: Atypical depression is a type of depression characterized by mood reactivity, which is brightening of the mood in response to positive events; significant weight gain or increase in appetite; hypersomnia; leaden paralysis; and/or interpersonal rejection sensitivity, resulting in sig­nificant social or occupational impairment. 

Option D: Binge-eating disorder is the most common eating disorder. It is characterized by rapid intake of abnormally large quantities of food over a short period of time, even when not hungry. There are feelings of guilt about the eating episodes, but these patients do not compensate in any way following the episodes of binge.

questions.text: A patient who is comfortable at rest, but has symptoms of dyspnea, fatigue and palpitations on less than ordinary physical activity is classified as ________.
questions.solution:

questions.text: Identify the layer marked as '?' in the histopathological image given below:
questions.solution:
The layer marked in the image is the ganglion cell layer.

The retina is composed of 10 microscopic layers and is arranged as 2 distinctive components - pigment epithelium and neurosensory retina. They are as follows:

  1. Retinal pigment epithelium is the outermost layer that is attached to the underlying choroid. It provides metabolic support to the neurosensory retina and acts as an antireflective layer. 
  2. Layers of rods and cones contain the outer segments of the photoreceptors cells. (rods and cones).
  3. External limiting membrane is a fenestrated membrane through which the processes of the rods and cones pass.
  4. Outer nuclear layer consists of the nuclei of rods and cones.
  5. Outer plexiform layer contains connections between the photoreceptor cells to the dendrites of bipolar and horizontal cells.
  6. Inner nuclear layer contains the cell bodies of bipolar, horizontal, and Muller's cells.
  7. Inner plexiform layer contains connections between bipolar cells and dendrites of ganglion cells.
  8. Ganglion cell layer contains ganglion cell bodies.
  9. Nerve fiber layer contains ganglion cell axons that pass through lamina cribrosa to form the optic nerve. 
  10. Internal limiting membrane is the innermost layer and separates the retina from the vitreous.

Related Pearl: Layers of Retina

  • Outer nuclear layer
  • Outer plexiform layer
  • Inner nuclear layer
  • Inner plexiform layer
  • Ganglion cell layer
  • Nerve fibre layer
  • Internal limiting membrane

questions.text: An unconscious young man was rushed to the emergency department. On examination, his heart rate was 190 beats/min and his blood pressure was 70/40 mmHg. His electrocardiogram is given below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the electrocardiogram (ECG) showing narrow QRS complexes without P waves and pseudo R waves in aVR lead suggest paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). As the patient is hemodynamically unstable, the next step in management is DC (direct current) cardioversion.

PSVT is a narrow QRS complex tachycardia with sudden onset and termination. The patients mainly present with dizziness and palpitations. Evaluation of these patients includes monitoring of vitals and ECG.

Management is as follows:

1) When the patient is hemodynamically stable:

  • Carotid sinus massage can be done. It is avoided if carotid bruit is present and if there is a prior history of stroke.
  • Valsalva maneuver is done if the patient is cooperative
  • Intravenous adenosine is useful in most cases. However, its usage is contraindicated in patients with prior cardiac transplantation. It can aggravate bronchospasm and atrial fibrillation, hence must be used with great caution in such patients.
  • Intravenous calcium channel blockers such as verapamil or diltiazem and beta-blockers are helpful but can cause hypotension.

2) When the patient is hemodynamically unstable, i.e. when the patient has hypotension with unconsciousness or respiratory distress QRS-synchronous direct current cardioversion is done.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias
