questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The type of speech that would be seen in this patient is?
questions.solution:
The image shows quinsy also known as a peritonsillar abscess. Muffled and thick speech, often called “hot potato voice” is seen in peritonsillar abscess or quinsy. 

Quinsy:

Quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

Clinical features: 

  • Sore throat/ Dysphagia 
  • Drooling of saliva 
  • Trismus 
  • Ipsilateral otalgia 
  • Fever 

Management of quinsy

  • Hospitalization
  • Intravenous fluids to combat dehydration
  • Antibiotics - Suitable antibiotics in large  i.v. doses to cover aerobes and anaerobes;
  • Analgesics like paracetamol are given for pain relief
  • Oral hygiene should be maintained by hydrogen peroxide or saline mouthwashes.
  • Drainage by needle aspiration, incision, and drainage or tonsillectomy.
  • Incision and drainage of the abscess: A peritonsillar abscess is opened at the point of the maximum bulge above the upper pole of the tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of the anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula.

Other options:

Option A - Staccato voice or scanning speech is a broken speech seen in cerebellar lesions as well as multiple sclerosis.

Option B - Rhinolalia aperta causes a hypernasal voice.

Option D - Rhinolalia clausa/ hyponasal voice can be seen in adenoid hypertrophy.

questions.text: A patient with a known brain tumor learns that his pituitary stalk has been affected. Secretion of which of the following hormones would likely be increased after the sectioning of the pituitary stalk?
questions.solution:
The secretion of prolactin is likely to be increased after the sectioning of the pituitary stalk. 

Prolactin is unique among the pituitary hormones because the predominant central control mechanism is inhibitory, i.e., dopamine inhibits prolactin secretion. Hence, sectioning of the pituitary stalk (Ex: In head trauma or compressive skull lesions) prevents this inhibition and leads to increased secretion of prolactin. 

Note:

If the pituitary stalk is cut above the pituitary gland but the entire hypothalamus is left intact, the posterior pituitary hormones (ADH & Oxytocin) show a transient decrease because they are initially synthesized in the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus and are then transported down to the nerve endings to the posterior pituitary gland, requiring several days to reach the gland.

questions.text: An MRI of an elderly female patient with new-onset seizures, revealed a large mass with central necrosis and surrounding edema, crossing the corpus callosum into both frontal lobes. Subsequently, she underwent surgical resection of the mass. Microscopy is shown below. Identify the given condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with MRI findings and microscopy showing pseudopalisading pattern is strongly suggestive of glioblastoma or grade IV astrocytoma.

Glioblastoma affects people usually in the sixth or seventh decade. These tumors may arise de novo or may result from a malignant transformation of lower-grade astrocytomas. Mutations of isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH), PTEN, and epidermal growth factor receptor gene (EGFR) are implicated in the pathogenesis. The majority of the tumors (90%) have IDH wild-type mutation and the remaining have IDH mutant type.

Clinically, the patient presents with headaches, seizures due to raised intracranial pressure, or focal neurologic deficits depending upon the site involved. 

Grossly, glioblastomas are found to infiltrate the brain tissue and are poorly delineated. Microscopically, they are composed of poorly differentiated pleomorphic astrocytic cells with nuclear atypia and high mitotic activity. Necrosis and florid microvascular proliferation are characteristic. They exhibit pseudopalisading (a dense arrangement of tumor cells) lining up around the foci of tumor necrosis.

 

They preferentially spread along the condensed white matter tracts such as corticospinal tracts and corpus callosum and can give rise to the butterfly glioma, involving the contralateral hemisphere.

The image given below shows MRI findings seen in glioblastomas. Note the butterfly morphology of the tumor:

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with distal leg weakness, and reduced muscle stretch reflexes, associated with no complaints of tingling or numbness. On examination, there is atrophy of the muscles below the knee. The following clinical findings are seen. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The given image showing muscle atrophy, high arch of foot, and hammer-toes which, along with the other clinical features mentioned above, are suggestive of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.

Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease (CMT) is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. CMT is a syndrome of many genetically distinct disorders.

CMT type 1 is the most common form of hereditary neuropathy. It usually presents in the first to third decade of life with distal leg weakness, e.g., foot drop. The following findings are seen:

  • No numbness or tingling
  • Reduced sensation to all modalities apparent on examination
  • Reduced muscle stretch reflexes
  • Atrophy of the muscles below the knee, leading to inverted champagne bottle legs 

Diabetic neuropathy, primary amyloidosis, neuropathy associated with Sjogren’s syndrome, and rheumatoid arthritis are acquired forms of neuropathies.

Other options:

Option B- Refsum's disease is a hereditary disorder of lipid metabolism. They can manifest in infancy to early adulthood with classic tetrad of:

  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Cerebellar ataxia
  • Elevated CSF protein concentration

They have elevated serum phytanic acid and they are autosomal recessive in nature. 

Option C- Sjogren syndrome is a chronic, slowly progressing autoimmune disease characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands. Predominately seen in middle-aged women. Majority of them present with impaired lacrimal and salivary gland function. Neuropathy associated with Sjogren's syndrome is either sensory or sensorimotor polyneuropathy like mononeuritis multiplex and myelitis

Option D- Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by symmetric polyarthritis. The incidence increases between the age of 25 to 55 years. Chronic inflammation of ankle and midtarsal regions leads to pes planovalgus or flat feet. Other deformities seen in RA are: 

  • Swan-neck deformity
  • Boutonniere deformity
  • Z-line deformity

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the histological image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows transitional epithelium in the urinary bladder.

The deepest layer has columnar cells, the middle layers are made up of polyhedral cells and the surface layer has cells that are large and shaped like an umbrella.

Transitional epithelium is found in the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and part of the urethra. Because of this distribution, it is also called urothelium. In the urinary bladder, it is usually observed that transitional epithelium can be stretched considerably without being damaged. When stretched it appears to be thinner and the cells become flattened or rounded.

questions.text: A corpse is brought for evaluation. On post-mortem examination, a ligature that was completely encircling the neck, horizontal, and below the level of the thyroid was seen. There was no dribbling of saliva. What is the cause of death?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause of death in a case where the ligature is completely encircling the neck, horizontal, and below the level of the thyroid, with no saliva dribbling, is ligature strangulation.

Strangulation is a type of asphyxia where there is neck constriction without suspension of the body. The pressure on the neck is applied either by bare hands, a ligature, or by any other instrument.

When strangulation is done by using a ligature like a constricting band or rope, it is called ligature strangulation. The constricting band is tightened by a force other than the victim's body weight. It is characterized by the ligature mark, which is transverse and completely encircles the neck below the thyroid cartilage. There is no dribbling of saliva. Bleeding may be present in the ears, nose, and mouth.

Ligature and manual strangulations are mostly homicidal. Marks of violence are usually seen on other parts of the body.

Other options:

Option A: Throttling or manual strangulation occurs due to compression of the neck by humans leading to asphyxia. Thumb impression and finger marks may be seen over the victim's neck.

Option C: Gagging is a type of asphyxia due to forcible closure of the mouth by a cloth or closing the mouth and nose and is tied around the head. 

Option D: Hanging is characterized by an incomplete and oblique ligature mark on the neck. It is usually seen higher, between the chin and larynx. Saliva often dribbles from the mouth.

questions.text: The Bragg peak effect is pronounced in:
questions.solution:
The Bragg peak effect is pronounced in protons.

The proton is a heavy and charged particle that gradually loses its speed as it interacts with human tissue. It is easily controlled and delivers its maximum dose at a precise depth and can go as far as 32 cm.

The absorbed dose increases very gradually with greater depth and lower speed, suddenly rising to a peak when the proton is ultimately stopped. This is known as the Bragg peak.

The behavior of the proton can be precisely determined and the beam can be directed so the Bragg peak occurs exactly within the tumor site. Immediately after this burst of energy, the proton completely stops to irradiate and the particles come to rest. 

Proton therapy therefore allows to target tumors inside the body, precisely localize the radiation dosage and spare the patient’s healthy cells, offering a much less invasive alternative to treat cancer.

The Bragg curve shown below plots the energy loss of ionizing radiation during its travel through matter.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is being evaluated for hematuria.  Histopathology showed mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation. The following finding is seen on immunofluorescence. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:

It is the most common type of glomerulonephritis in adults. It is characterized by recurrent hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. 

The systemic variant of IgA nephropathy is associated with Henoch–Schönlein purpura. It is a disorder of children which presents with similar renal manifestations with characteristic IgA deposits in the mesangium in about one-third of the patients.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the dose-response curve shown in the image below?

choices.text: Drug C is a competitive antagonist
Drug C is more potent than drug A
Drug B is more potent than drug A
Drug B is a competitive antagonist

questions.solution:
In the above image, drug B is a competitive antagonist.

In competitive antagonism, the dose-response curve (DRC) is shifted to the right whereas in non-competitive antagonism the DRC is flattened.

Thus in the above image Drug B is the competitive antagonist while drug C is the non-competitive antagonist.

Potency:

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • The more the curve is on the left in a dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency.
  • Thus, in the above image, the potency is drug A > drug C > drug B.

Efficacy:

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug.
  • It expresses the effect produced by the receptors when bound by a certain drug.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.
  • Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is drug A = drug B > drug C.

questions.text: An incidental ovarian mass is found when evaluating a 19-year-old girl for kidney stones. The mass is removed and its contents are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient with an asymptomatic ovarian mass consisting hair, bone, and sebaceous material is a mature teratoma. 

Teratomas are germ cell tumors. They contain embryonic tissues leading to the differentiation of cells along these pathways. There are three classes of teratomas:

  • Mature (benign) teratomas (eg: Dermoid cyst)
  • Immature (essentially malignant) teratomas (eg: solid teratoma)
  • Monodermal (highly specialized) tumors (eg: Struma ovarii)

Mature cystic teratoma, also known as dermoid cysts are unilocular in structure and have a smooth surface. They usually are lined by squamous epithelium with hair follicles leading to the formation of sebaceous material and hair. Other structures like teeth, bone, cartilage, thyroid tissue, and mucous membranes can also be found. 

Most patients are asymptomatic. Some patients may have symptoms because of the mass size of the teratoma. In other patients, ovarian teratomas can result in torsion of the ovary. Other rare complications include rupture of the cyst and spillage of contents into the abdominal cavity. 

Treatment of mature teratomas involves excision in order to prevent complications. Otherwise, mature teratomas are generally innocent. 

Other options: 

Option A - Immature teratomas such as solid teratomas of the ovary are solid and trabeculated. They also contain cartilage, bone, hair, and sebaceous material. There is no structural order. They are generally malignant. Grossly, they have a smooth external surface and are solid on sectioning. There may be areas of necrosis or hemorrhage. 

The following image shows both mature (left) and immature teratomas (right). 

Option C - Struma ovarii is a type of highly specialized teratoma that contains only thyroid tissue. If it is functioning, it may lead to hyperthyroidism. 

Option D - Granulosa cell tumors arise from the sex cords of the gonads. They are solid and generally produce estrogen. They can cause precocious puberty in children, hyperestrogenism in adults, and post-menopausal bleeding. They vary in appearance and range from microscopic to large, solid and cystic, encapsulated masses. If hormonally active, they may be yellow due to intracellular lipids.

The World Health Organization (WHO) has established international standards for normal child growth from birth to 5 years of age. The normalization of the anthropometric measures is done in terms of z-scores (standard deviation scores). The anthropometric measures used are weight for age, height for age, weight for height, BMI, and mid-upper arm circumference.

  • High weight-for-height indicates overweight.

  • Low weight-for-age indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient came with complaints of nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness. There is a history of similar complaints in the family members. They recently consumed food prepared from the contaminated grains shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image showing wheat grains infested with blackish fungal mass are suggestive of ergotism.

Ergot or Claviceps purpurae is a field fungus. Food grains like bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat have a tendency to get contaminated with this ergot fungus. It grows as a blackish mass and the seeds become black and irregular. These get harvested along with the food grains and consumption of this ergot-infested grain leads to ergotism.  

Acute cases present with nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness for a period of up to 24 to 48 hours after the ingestion of ergot grain. In cases of chronic consumption, they present with painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene due to vasoconstriction of capillaries. 

Ergot-infested grains can be removed easily by floating them in 20 percent saltwater. Floatation and handpicking can also be used for the removal.

questions.text: The HIV sentinel surveillance includes all of the following populations except ______________
questions.solution:
Sentinel surveillance of HIV is usually not done for STD clinic attendees.

Sentinel surveillance is used to augment the notification systems used in the surveillance of diseases.

Till 2012-13, STD sites were also included in the HIV sentinel surveillance but from 2014-15, these sites were entirely discontinued, since the STD data had significant biases.

The study population for HIV sentinel surveillance includes:

  • Female sex worker: Women who are engaged in consensual sex for money or payment in kind, as a means of livelihood in the last six months
  • Men who had anal or oral sex with a male partner in the last month.
  • Injection drug users: Men and women who use addictive substances or drugs for recreational or non-medical reasons, through injections, at least once in the last three months.
  • Transgender: Person whose identity does not conform unambiguously to conventional notions of male or female gender roles, but combines or moves between these.
  • Single male migrants: Single male, living at a place other than the place of usual residence without his spouse or family, for the purposes of work and visiting his home town at least once a year.
  • Long-distance truckers: Truckers who travel more than 800 km one way between source and destination.
  • A pregnant woman of age 15-49 years and attending the antenatal clinic for the first time.

questions.text: Two brothers were arguing over ancestral property when the elder of the two suddenly complained of chest pain. He was brought to the hospital. His family members reported that he was previously healthy and that there were no similar diseases in the family members. Echocardiography was done; the image below shows the findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sudden chest pain in a previously healthy man under a stressful situation is suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is also called broken heart syndrome, apical ballooning syndrome, or stress-induced cardiomyopathy. It is characterized by a transient myocardial stunning from microcirculation spams due to a catecholamine surge during stress. It is usually seen in middle-aged women. The patients may present with pulmonary edema, hypotension, and chest pain.

Echocardiography reveals apical dilatation with basal hypercontraction of the heart, resembling a takotsubo (pot for catching octopus). The ECG changes can mimic those of myocardial infarction. Therefore, coronary angiography may be needed to rule out coronary occlusion. 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is a self-limiting disorder, resolving within days to weeks. The prognosis is generally good.

questions.text: A patient in the post-operative ward is poorly compliant with the respiratory exercises and ends up developing respiratory failure as a result. What type of respiratory failure would this be classified as?
questions.solution:
The most probable cause of acute respiratory failure in this post-operative patient would be postoperative atelectasis. Postoperative atelectasis causes type 3 respiratory failure.

Type III respiratory failure

  • Results from lung atelectasis.
  • Since atelectasis occurs commonly in the perioperative period, this form is also called perioperative respiratory failure.
  • After general anesthesia, there is a decrease in functional residual capacity due to a reduction in muscular tone. This leads to airway closure and the collapse of the dependent lung units.
  • Treated by
    • Frequent changes in position
    • Chest physiotherapy
    • Upright positioning
    • Control of incisional and/or abdominal pain
  • Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation - used to reverse regional atelectasis

questions.text: A 6-year-old fully immunized healthy boy suddenly develops a high fever along with difficulty swallowing. The child is unwilling to lie down and sits with his chin up, and mouth open. Noisy breathing is also noted. Lateral radiographs of the neck demonstrate the finding shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a immunized child with high fever, difficulty swallowing, noisy breathing, and a lateral radiograph showing a thumb sign points towards the diagnosis of acute epiglottitis.

Acute epiglottitis is an acute rapidly progressive inflammation of the epiglottis causing obstructive laryngitis and presents with high fever, severe sore throat, tachycardia, systemic toxicity, and drooling as patients are unable to swallow. The patient characteristically leans forward while sitting for ease of breathing.

The diagnosis is often made bedside. On direct fiberoptic laryngoscopy, the typical edematous cherry-red epiglottis is visualized. Neck radiographs reveal an enlarged edematous epiglottis (Thumb sign). The below image shows the thumb sign.

Treatment includes airway management followed by administration of antibiotics like ampicillin/sulbactam, cefotaxime, or ceftriaxone. 

Other options - 

Option A: Laryngeal diphtheria is unlikely to occur in a fully immunized child, and diphtheria is typically associated with membrane formation. 

Option B: Retropharyngeal abscess is seen secondary to infections and usually does not present with fever. Children usually present with a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall, lateral to the midline. It is confirmed by a lateral X-ray of the neck which shows a widening of the prevertebral shadow. 

Option D: Croup is usually gradual in onset and is usually preceded by prodromal symptoms. Also, fever is usually absent in such patients.

questions.text: India is currently in the third stage of the demographic cycle. This is characterized by?

choices.text: Birth rate lower than death rate

questions.solution:
India is currently in the third (late-expanding) stage of the demographic cycle, which is characterized by decreasing demographic gap.

A demographic gap is a difference between birth rate and death rate. The demographic gap is maximum in the early-expanding phase, characterized by a high birth rate and low death rate. As the demography of the country transitions to the late-expanding phase, both the birth rate and death rate fall causing a decreasing demographic gap. Although the birth rate is falling in the late-expanding phase, it is still higher than the death rate, which causes the population to increase.

Other options:

Option A- Birth rate lower than the death rate is seen in the fifth (declining) stage of the demographic cycle.

Option B- Maximum demographic gap is seen in the second (early-expanding) stage, characterized by a high birth rate and low death rate.

Option D- Stationary population is seen in first (high stationary) stage and fourth (low stationary) stage of the demographic cycle.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: A 35-year-old rice farmer presented with a high-grade fever, diarrhea, seizures, tremors, and vomiting. The physician suspects an illness transmitted by the mosquito shown below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The rice farmer presents with features of acute encephalitis and non-specific features like fever, cough, and diarrhea, and is most likely suspected to have Japanese encephalitis. The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquito due to unspotted wings and hunched back, which is a vector of Japanese encephalitis. 

Culex mosquitoes:

They are vectors or carriers for Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, and viral arthritis. 

In the larval stage, they are suspended with heads downwards at an angle, a siphon tube is present, and there is an absence of palmate hairs. They lay the eggs in clusters, and adult mosquitoes have their wings unspotted with hunched back.

Various mosquito larvae are shown in the image below. Siphon tube is present in Aedes and Culex, whereas, it is absent in Anopheles.

 

Japanese encephalitis (JE) is the most prevalent cause of viral encephalitis in Asia. It is a mosquito-borne zoonotic disease caused by Flavivirus. It is transmitted mainly by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

JE is a zoonotic disease primarily affecting animals like pigs and ardeid birds. Pigs are considered the major vertebrate hosts and amplifiers for the JE virus. Humans are the dead-end hosts for this virus. When a mosquito bites an infected pig, the virus is transmitted to the mosquito. The virus, in turn, is transferred to other pigs or humans due to mosquito bites and this cycle continues. Horses are the only known domestic animals that present with signs of JE infection.

The control measures include mosquito control by areal or ground fogging with ultra-low-volume insecticides such as malathion and fenitrothion, locating piggeries away from human dwellings, and vaccinating pigs. Ultra-low-volume fogging is a method of insecticide application where a small volume (<500 ml/hectare) of liquid insecticide is applied to provide maximum killing of disease vectors.

JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunisation Schedule.

  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given condition?

choices.text: It is related to Hutchinson’s triad
There is usually a history of primary Herpes simplex virus infection as a child
High dose topical acyclovir is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
The image shows a unilateral painful, vesicular rash suggestive of herpes zoster ophthalmicus (HZO) caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) within the ophthalmic nerve. Neurotrophic keratitis is a complication of HZV infection.

Keratitis occurs due to corneal nerve damage by the virus leading to decreased sensation, frequent infections, persistent epithelial defect, thinning and even perforation. 

Corneal lesions in HZO (zoster keratitis):

  • Epithelium- superficial punctate keratitis and pseudo-dendritic ulcer
  • Stroma- nummular keratitis and disciform keratitis 

Other ocular lesions in herpes zoster:

  • Uveitis
  • Episcleritis and scleritis
  • Conjunctivitis
  • Acute retinal necrosis
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Anterior segment necrosis and phthisis bulbi

Option A: Hutchinson’s rule is related to herpes zoster ophthalmicus (not Hutchinson's triad ). It states that if the tip of the nose is involved, there will be a significant risk of ocular involvement. This is due to the involvement of the nasociliary nerve. Hutchinson's triad is seen in congenital syphilis.

Option B: There is a primary Varicella-Zoster infection, not HSV(Herpes simplex virus) infection.

Option D: Systemic acyclovir is the treatment of choice; not topical antiviral drops. Oral acyclovir 800 mg five times a day for 7-10 days, ideally initiated within 72 h of the onset of symptoms is the usual regimen.

The image shows Hutchinson's sign in a patient with herpes zoster ophthalmicus.

questions.text: A patient suffers head trauma following which he complains of diplopia. His extraocular motility testing in the 9 gazes is as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of oculomotor nerve palsy (3rd nerve palsy).

The central image shows the eyes in primary gaze where the patient's left eye has deviated down and out. There is also profound ptosis due to the weakness of the levator muscle. Due to the involvement of the superior rectus and medial rectus, elevation and adduction will be impaired. Abduction and depression in the primary position (down and out) due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. All of these findings indicate left oculomotor nerve palsy.

The signs of left oculomotor nerve palsy are summarized in the image attached below. 

Other options:

In trochlear nerve palsy (4th nerve palsy), the superior oblique is affected, causing:

  • The weakness of depression: Mainly seen when the eye is adducted (depression during abducted position is a function of the Inferior rectus)
  • Weakness of abduction
  • Failure of intorsion: Cause of diplopia.

In abducens nerve (6th nerve palsy), the lateral rectus is affected. Due to the involvement of only the lateral rectus, abduction will be impaired.

questions.text: Identify the fluid shown below.
questions.solution:
The fluid shown in the image is ringer lactate or Hartmann's solution.

Ringer lactate, or Hartmann's solution, is a crystalloid made up of sodium 131 mEq, chloride 112 mEq, potassium 5 mEq, bicarbonate (as lactate) 29 mEq, and 2 mEq of calcium. It is devoid of glucose.

It is useful in the following conditions: 

  • Correction of severe hypovolemia
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Postoperative period, burns, diarrhea
  • Correction of hypokalemia
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis.

It should be avoided in severe shock, liver diseases, vomiting, nasogastric aspiration, and metabolic alkalosis. It cannot be used along with blood transfusion since calcium in the ringer lactate can bind with citrate in the transfused blood leading to clot formation. 

Other options:

Option A: Haemaccel is a colloid and contains 145 mmol of sodium, 6.25 mmol of calcium, and 5.1 mmol of potassium. It is mainly used for rapid volume replacement in circulatory shock, burns, and trauma. These release histamine and hence, H2 blocker has to be supplemented. It is also used in heart-lung machines.

Options C and D: Isolyte P and Isolyte M are crystalloids. Isolyte P is commonly used in fluid therapy for pediatrics. One liter contains 50 grams of glucose, 25 mEq of sodium, 22 mEq of potassium, 3 mEq of magnesium, and 23 mEq of acetate. Hyponatremia, renal failure, hyperkalemia, and hypovolemic shock are some of the contraindications.

Isolyte M is used for maintenance. It mainly contains 50 grams of glucose, 40 mEq sodium, 38 mEq chloride, 35 mEq potassium, 15 mEq phosphate, and 20 mEq acetate. It is useful in correcting hypokalemia in patients with good renal function, and acidosis. It is contraindicated in hyponatremia.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is likely to be most abundant in collagen?
questions.solution:
The most abundant amino acid in collagen is glycine.

Collagen is the most abundant protein in the animal world. It consists of three alpha chains held together by hydrogen bonds forming a triple helical structure.

A striking characteristic of collagen is the occurrence of glycine residues at every third position, (Gly-X-Y) repeats.

Proline and hydroxyproline confer rigidity on the collagen molecule. Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are formed by the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues. This hydroxylation is catalyzed by the enzyme prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase, and cofactors are ascorbic acid (vitamin C) and α-ketoglutarate.

Intracellular steps in the synthesis of collagen:

  • Signal peptide cleavage
  • Hydroxylation of prolyl residues and some lysyl residues, glycosylation of some hydroxylysyl residues
  • Intrachain and interchain S–S bonds formation in extension peptides
  • Triple helix formation

Extracellular steps in the synthesis of collagen:

  • Amino- and carboxyl-terminal propeptides cleavage
  • Collagen fibers assembly in quarter-staggered alignment
  • Oxidative deamination of h -amino groups of lysyl and hydroxylysyl residues to aldehydes
  • Intra- and interchain cross-links formation via Schiff bases and aldol condensation products

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: The image below shows a pressure sore. Which stage does this belong to ?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pressure sore with extensive tissue destruction, including damage to the muscle layer and thus it belongs to stage 4.

Pressure sores also referred known as bed sores, pressure ulcers and decubitus ulcers are ulcers that occur due to prolonged pressure on certain sites thereby leading to tissue necrosis. The commonest sites involved are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, heel, malleolus (lateral >medial), and occiput. Paraplegic patients, elderly patients, and severely ill patients are at a higher risk of developing pressure sores.

They are staged as:

  • Stage 1 - Erythema with no blanching and no breach in the epidermis.
  • Stage 2- Partial-thickness skin loss with epidermal and dermal involvement.
  • Stage 3- Full-thickness skin loss with intact fascia but the involvement of the subcutaneous tissue.
  • Stage 4- Full-thickness skin loss extending to the fascia with massive tissue destruction and involvement of muscle, bone, tendon, or joint. 

Management is primarily proper skin care with pressure dispersion cushions, air-fluidized beds, and urinary or fecal diversion if required. Patients who are bed-bound should be turned once in 2 hours. Those in a wheelchair should lift themselves off the seat for 10 seconds every 10 minutes.

Surgery is the last resort and is done after a proper initial debridement and vacuum-assisted closure. Vacuum-assisted closure is a wound closure technique in which negative pressure is applied to the wound which leads to a decrease in edema. This hastens the debridement and formation of granulation tissue. Skin flaps with a muscle are also used for closure.

Related Pearl: Staging of Pressure Sores

 

Stage

Description
1 Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
2

Partial thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
3

Full thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
4 Full thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon or joint

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows a Humby's knife.

Humby's knife is used to harvest a split skin graft. The average thickness of the graft obtained from a Humby's knife is 0.3 mm.

Other options:

Option A: Bone gouge is used to chisel, and remove parts of bone during surgery

Option B: Doyen's retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall as well as the bladder to facilitate better exposure of the lower uterine segment during lowe segment cesarian surgery. It is also used to pull back the soft tissues to widen the surgical field during laparotomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a purine analog used in treating gout?
questions.solution:
Allopurinol is the purine analog, used in the treatment of hyperuricemia and gout, which inhibits purine biosynthesis and xanthine oxidase activity.

Other options:

Option A: Cytarabine is a pyrimidine nucleoside analog which is an anticancer drug used in the treatment of leukemias.

Option C: Febuxostat is a recently introduced non-purine xanthine oxidase inhibitor, equally or more effective than allopurinol in lowering blood uric acid levels in patients with hyperuricemia and gout.

Option D: Capecitabine is a pyrimidine analog that is classified as an antimetabolite agent.

questions.text: You observe a forensic surgeon doing en masse removal of organs during an autopsy. Which of the following autopsy techniques is he performing?
questions.solution:
The en masse removal of organs is done in the Letulle technique.

It is the removal of the cervical, thoracic, abdominal and pelvic organs as a single organ mass. They are subsequently dissected into organ blocks. 

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Rokitansky technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. Larynx and trachea are pulled downward, and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Ghon technique: Like the Rokitansky method, the Ghon method also employs the bloc method of removing thoracic, cervical, abdominal organs. However, the organs are removed 'en bloc', rather than with in-situ dissection. 
  • Letulle technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: A patient started on an antihypertensive presented with the following picture. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The image shows edema over the lips and face and its occurrence following intake of an antihypertensive is suggestive of drug-induced angioedema. Lisinopril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE inhibitor), is most likely responsible for this condition.

Angioedema with ACE inhibitors:

In very few patients(0.1%-0.5%), ACE inhibitors cause rapid swelling in the nose, throat, mouth, glottis, larynx, lips, or tongue. Once the drug is stopped symptoms improve drastically over hours. Angioedema of the intestine can occur very rarely. 

ACE inhibitor-associated angioedema is a class effect, and patients who develop this adverse event should not be prescribed any other drugs within the ACE inhibitor class.

Other adverse effects of ACE inhibitors:

  • A sudden fall in blood pressure can occur following the first dose of ACE inhibitors.
  • It can produce a bothersome dry cough due to the accumulation of bradykinin, substance P, or prostaglandins in the lungs. The cough usually disappears within 4 days of the stoppage of the drug.
  • Hyperkalemia due to K+ retention can occur.
  • Acute renal failure can occur with ACE inhibitors in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, stenosis of the artery to a single remaining kidney, heart failure, or volume depletion due to diarrhea or diuretics.
  • It should be discontinued in pregnant women as it can cause developmental defects.
  • It can also cause maculopapular skin rash in some cases.

Other options:

Option B: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker. Common adverse effects include headache, flushing, and dizziness. Peripheral edema (pedal edema) may rarely occur.

Option C: Atenolol is a beta-1 selective antagonist. Bradycardia, fatigue, and cold extremities are common adverse effects. CNS side effects like nightmares and depression are less frequent with atenolol than other beta-blockers.

Option D: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist. The main adverse effects of clonidine are dry mouth and sedation. Bradycardia and sexual dysfunction are other effects.

questions.text: Identify the organism & the stain used from the image given below :
questions.solution:
The given image shows Helicobacter pylori under Warthin-Starry stain.

H.pylori is a gram-negative motile rod with lophotrichous flagella. The gastric antrum is the commonest site of colonization. Infection is confined to the gastric mucosa in the stomach or in areas of gastric metaplasia and heteroplasia in the duodenum. 

In some patients, H.pylori causes mild acute gastritis lasting for about two weeks. In others, it can cause peptic ulcer disease which in later stages may lead to chronic atrophic gastritis. This is a risk factor for gastric malignancies like adenocarcinoma and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphomas. 

The urea breath test is a rapid diagnostic procedure used to identify infection, as H.pylori has a unique feature of the production of urease.

The given image shows H.pylori on gastric mucosa stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain. The bacteria are present only in the mucus overlying the gastric mucosa and do not actually invade the mucosa.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains These include Eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, Congo red, etc. and are mostly used to stain pathological specimens.
Basic stains.

1.    Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in counterstaining in quellung reaction of streptococcus pneumoniae.  

2.    Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction of anthrax bacilli
Neutral stains

1.    Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

2.    Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and some other spirochete and protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contains more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: Used to distinguish cells by cell-wall type. To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain: Used to distinguish acid-fast bacteria from non-acid-fast cells. Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid – fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Used for rapid scanning of the smear, where the AFB appear fluorescent green against a black background Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "Chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (Anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–Starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor White Staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain Calcofluor white, which greatly enhances visibility of fungal element in tissue or other specimens. It is especially useful for the identification of Mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.   It is also used in staining acanthamoeba

questions.text: An auxiliary nurse midwife conducting a vaccination camp received 2 vaccine vials. One is a pentavalent vaccine and the other is an MR vaccine, which she opened on the day of the camp. She intends to reuse these vials by storing them in proper condition, at her next vaccination camp to be conducted in 2 weeks. What would you advise her regarding the re-utilization of these vials?

choices.text: Use MR vaccine and discard pentavalent vaccine
Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR vaccine

questions.solution:
She can use the pentavalent vaccine and discard the MR vaccine.  According to the open vial policy, the pentavalent vaccine can be reused, whereas MR can not be reused. 

Open vial policy allows for the reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions for up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV and liquid pentavalent vaccine.

It is not applicable for BCG, measles, rotavirus vaccines and JE vaccines.

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be use in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water.

Ensure all opened vials have recorded date and time of opening.

At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable.

All open vials of BCG, measles and JE must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete.

All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register.

Ice packs used should be well sealed.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.
